title: The Best Bakery case- what's the truth
author: BeeDee
post_content: The NCERT <a href="http://www.telegraphindia.com/1040625/asp/nation/story_3414975.asp">has decided to 're-write' history again </a>and revise the textbooks that Murali Manohar Joshi wanted to introduce. All very well, and from my ideological point of view, an excellent move. However, as I will blog in the next few days and argue, this whole business of 'rewriting' history that is problematic. In fact the earlier textbooks (the original ones of Thapar, Bipan Chandra et al), through their omissions and silences actually gave the space for these 'alternate' histories to be written. This is not to say that all alternate histories are equally legitimate. There is after all, 'good' history and 'bad' history, to be judged on the basis on how accurately one can draw reasonable conclusions from the evidence placed before oneself. And no one is arguing that Joshi is a 'reasonable' person! But what is heartening about the NCERT's move is that it seeks not to introduce a standardised book for each Class, but a series of books or reading materials, that children can draw upon. This means that you will have one or two core textbooks, but for those further interested in the subject, the NCERT will provide some guidelines on what else they could read. Considering how boring and appalling the CBSE history exams are, this could only be a Good Thing.

title: Trying to get back to this blog
author: BeeDee
post_content: No excuse really for not blogging for so long...unless you count Court 1 at Wimbledon as a genuine excuse! I've spent the whole day trying to construct a reading list for my next thesis- a starting point, rather than a reading list would perhaps be a better term. Anyway, this exercise actually revealed a number of excellent sources on South Asian history, along with a number of other disturbing ones. I won't catalogue these now, but shall go on to say something about <a href="http://www.telegraphindia.com/1040624/asp/frontpage/story_3410611.asp">this news item </a>that has been bothering me for a while. On the face of it, Jemima and Imran's divorce is a matter fit for tabloids. However, read that article carefully and you will see all the racist bias of the British media being revealed. The stereotype of Islam, and by extension Pakistan being an oppressor is being bandied about. From what little I know of the country, Jemima would hardly have lived without an air conditioner (!) unless Imran is peculiarly miserly. High society in the subcontinent lives in lavish luxury that most people in the developing world will only be able to dream of. So my guess is that Jemima probably lived in a huge house, with servants at her disposal, every amenity she wanted, and simply got bored because she missed her London life. Fair enough, marriages have broken up for lesser reasons, but to villify an entire country, it's culture and by implication it's religion because this marriage didn't last, is utter rubbish. Somehow the whole notion that Jemima has been 'released' (as if it is not marriage that is a bondage, but marrying into a Muslim family that is), is quite repugnant. All thoughts on the matter would be very welcome.

title: 9/11 documentary
author: BeeDee
post_content: I'll try and spend an hour everyday blogging about the most important political developments from India. Having looked at the dearth of websites on Indian politics, I think this is necessary. There's a selfish reason as well- as someone who wishes to specialize in South Asian politics in the future, this will be an extremely useful exercise. I invite all forms of constructive comment, so please feel free, as this blog develops, to express your views.

title: oldness
author: nowherefast
post_content: <span style="font-family:arial;">so i moved to charlotte, nc. i didn't think that things would be this hard when i first came here. i really wanted to move away but being away from everyone was a little hard for me to deal with. i've spent many nights sad that i won't hear the next word that my niece will say or the next funny thing that she will do. i miss not being able to go out and chill with my friends. i thought things would get better after i got my job.... but as many of you know she did it again. yes the whole reason that i have moved down here was for the one person that i have loved more passionately then anyone. the move was really for her parents to open up a restaurant. moving away from everyone for something i didn't really belive in was hard for me to deal with. before i moved away things were great between us. i had no doubts that things would last even though i knew that everyone else thought that i was stupid for doing it. love i guess does stupid things sometimes. the drive down was great. the weather was even better. things did get a little rough when i couldn't find a decent job. for about two months i was at home rather depressed that i wasn't going anywhere. she did do her best to help but i still felt lost. things just went a little haywire when she didn't want to spend the night with me after i didn't see her for a couple of days. during that time i started my job and the 3rd day that i was there my car was hit by a stupid guy and i just needed someone. i got mad about her not being there for me and things got out of hand. this is the second time that when i needed her the most she walked away with out any feeling what so ever. i know i know i haven't been with her to see if she has cried like i have or if she feels anything but right now i have to go by what i see. so there you have it the quick story.</span>

title: Homespun Symposium XII
author: Nixon Casablanca
post_content: Call me ignorant, naive, Chester, whatever, but I had never heard of this term before yesterday, when <a href="http://www.yahoo.com">Yahoo</a> featured <a href="http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&cid=1804&amp;ncid=1804&e=1&amp;u=/washpost/20050211/tc_washpost/a15511_2005feb10">THIS STORY</a> about a blogger being fired for bad-mouthing her employer on her blog.<br /><br />You need not scroll down too far to see a small rant about my own employer, and I know of several other blogs I read that frequently complain about where they work.<br /><br />While I try to keep my comments limited to things I wouldn't mind saying to my boss's face, or slip into the 'suggestion box' at work, some others have gotten a bit more therapeutic than I have in their posts.<br /><br />This brings up the whole "Free Speech" vs. "Free Enterprise" debate, that'll make any red-blooded American's cowboy hat spin. Quite honestly, I'm on the proverbial fence with this one. I'm an 'at will' employee where I work, which means if they suddenly decide that I'm too fat, too white, too Republican, too much of an OU fan, too ugly, or just really really want to hire someone else to fill my position, they can tell me goodbye at any second. Luckily, I'm in an industry that few people want to work in, and with high turnover, so any happy, loyal employee such as myself has pretty good job security. (Yes, I really do love my job!)<br /><br />But if I started posting lies and half-truths, or even whole truths that paint my employer in a bad light, would they be justified in firing me? And just who are they firing? "Nixon Casablanca" (not my real name.) Yes, that' s my real picture, but couldn't I just as easily post as someone else? Or use a fake picture? Or post as a pet armadillo? <br /><br />I don't blog on company time, mainly because we have no internet access at work. If we did, I probably would, but only because I mostly work graveyard during which time we watch the kids sleep (and make sure they don't wake up and try to escape, stab eachother, etc.) We do have a LOT of paperwork to keep us busy, but we still manage to have several hours of idle time a night, which is usually filled with reading or light television watching.<br /><br />So, I've reached no conclusion, but then again, neither did the news story. Where do YOU stand?

title: petitePiNkmoon
author: petitePiNkmoon
post_content: <div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;"><span style="font-size:85%;"><strong>The more things change, the more they stay the same...</strong> </span></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">I'm not sure who the first person was that said this. Probably Shakespeare. Or maybe Sting. But at the moment, it's the sentence that best describes my tragic flaw: my inability to change. I don't think I'm alone in this. The more I get to know other people, the more I realize it's kind of everyone's flaw. </span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">Staying exactly the same for as long as possible, standing perfectly still... It feels safer somehow. And if you <em>are</em> suffering, at least the pain is familiar. Because if you took that leap of faith, went outside the box, did something unexpected... Who knows what other pain might be out there waiting. Chances are it could be even worse. So you maintain the status quo. Choose the road already traveled. And it doesn't seem that bad, not as far as flaws go. You're not a drug addict. You're not killing anyone... Except maybe yourself a little. </span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"></span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">But, when we finally do change, I don't think it happens like an earthquake or an explosion, where all of a sudden we're like this different person. I think it's smaller than that. The kind of thing most people wouldn't even notice unless they looked really close. Which, thank God, they never do. But you notice it. Inside, to you that change feels like a world of difference. And you hope that it is. That this is the person you get to be forever... that you'll never have to change again. </span></div><div align="justify"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">- - E.B.</span></div>

title: The Twenty-fifth
author: Jon
post_content: Hey guys, what’s up? This is Jon and I’m here for another entry of YMU.<br /><br />I had a good weekend. My school was showing Ray and I saw it on Friday. Definitely Oscar worthy now that I’ve seen it for myself. I’ve been reading The Color Purple for my African American Lit class. It’s different. It’s told in prayers. I like it. I gotta see the movie after I’m done.<br /><br />Now about the topic. Today I went to church and I was feeling a little bad about a few things. Lately I’ve been feeling that I don’t have time to things I want to do. It’s always homework. I do my best not worry and trust God in everything, but it seems easier said than done most of the time. During worship I prayed to God to give me encouragement. Next thing I know one of the disciples had a verse that came to his heart and it spoke to me. 2 Corinthians 12:7-10. Paul was going through a rough time and the Lord said to him “My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.” Paul realized that even though he was feeling week he was going to rejoice in Christ’s strength and let him take over. That’s something that I need to do. Having apprehension and all this stuff won’t make your problems any better. You just have to bring them to Jesus and trust that everything is going to be brighter.<br /><br />I do have a bit of bad news. There was a shooting at a mall in my hometown, Kingston, NY. My mom told me about it today. It was one gunman and he injured a man in the leg.  Please pray for that man that everything turns out all right. He's in critical condition.<br /><br />I want to leave on a good note, so seeing as how Valentine’s Day is tomorrow, I have a special poem I wrote for the occasion. It’s called Real Love.<br /><br />My mind was boggled with woe and doubt<br />My body double over by a massive amount<br />I started to teeter and began to quit<br />Defeat was something I had to admit<br />But someone grabbed on and started to pull<br />Soon I was up and saw you in full<br />You comforted me giving assurance<br />That you’ll be there for the next occurrence<br /><br />I strolled down a path of darkness and forbid<br />I tripped and fell and scurried and hid<br />Your eyes filled with anger and mouth filled with scold<br />But you wrapped me up close in your loving hold<br />When you fixed my scrapes I didn’t understand<br />Tell me why you’re here I said with command<br />You looked in my eyes and in a sweet voice<br />You said I’m here because that is my choice<br />I love you and it hurt to see you in pain<br />Then I had a strange feeling that I yearned would remain<br /><br />A sense of joy exploded inside<br />And my long journey had its demise<br />I had traveled to seek a real, true love<br />When all that was needed was to look above<br /><br />I’ll be back with more soon. Until then this is Jon saying, “God’s love is sufficient.”

title: Bathing Suits
author: The Patriot
post_content: Every year, when a major hurrican is about to hit the coast of the United States, the news media is there giving us wall to wall coverage. We have all seen the "brave" weatherman (or just the guy that drew the short straw) in a yellow rain suit standing out in the storm with his microphone in had trying to describe what it is like in 60+mph wind and rain.<br /><br />Before it hits, they cover the evacuation operations and show people boarding up windows preparing for the storm. They interview people who are leaving, asking them where they are going and if they are afraid their house will be damaged when they get back. <br /><br />But one thing I hear every time, one comment from a citizen that occours every time a hurrican hits. Even last year when four hit Florida in a row. I don't understand this comment. Maybe it is because I do not live there and live where things like this or other natural disasters do not occur.<br /><br />The comment that bothers me is when someone says that they had to drive to the next town to find a generator or that there was a rush at the hardware store to buy generators. What, they didn't buy one the last four times? Or did they buy one, but need a different one for this particular hurricane. What happened to the one they bought the last hurricane? I would think that if you lived where the treat of hurrican is always there, people would already have a generator or a plan of escape.<br /><br />I am not going to say these people are stupid, but come on. Every time, the news goes through the same old story, same lines, same consultants. And when they talk to people in the path of the hurricane, it is the same story every time. I had to search everywhere for a generator.<br /><br />Well, there it is. I am watching Fox News and there is the weather man standing in the rain trying to describe how hard the rain is falling and how hard the wind is. His rain suit is yellow. I don't know why it bothers me. Maybe because it seems just so stupid. It is a HURRICANE! Of course the wind is blowing. Of course it is raining. Of course the waves are pounding.<br /><br />Ok. That is enough of my ranging<br /><br />This is One Man's Opinion

title: In Celebration: Freaky Flowers
author: Fin
post_content: People are starting to notice it. I'm blogging less. Which is bad.<br /><br />There are reasons, though. Firstly, I've been up to my neck in chemistry, physics and mathematics homework. Thank the lord for me choosing media studies, which has managed to lighten the workload. I have to admit that I do actually enjoy doing those homeworks, because they give me a chance to <a href="http://www.natnif.com/ms/" target="_blank">unload some of my creativity</a> (mostly when it isn't asked for, and usually in the form of nice, logical print design).<br /><br />Secondly, I've had a copy of the Sims 2 delivered to me by Amazon. Because I am such a procrastinator, I've just been playing on it all the time, and when I haven't been playing on it I have either been at school, doing the homework, eating, washing, or sleeping.<br /><br />Aaah. That's the life!<br /><br />I would definitely recommend the Sims 2 to anyone who wished to waste about a week of their free time. It's a very good game.

title: Premiere Web Designer Indeed!
author: Fin
post_content: At our nice little school, the <a href="http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&q=define%3A+sixth+form&btnG=Search" target="_blank">6th form</a> students are <s>forced</s> expected to do the school a service or two.<br /><br />It's all based in the ingenious logic of the school's administrators, who have cleverly worked out that if we do something to help our fellow students out, not only will they improve, but we will be able to write something impressive out on our <a href="http://www.google.com/search?q=define%3A+ucas&sourceid=firefox&start=0&start=0&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8" target="_blank">UCAS</a> university application forms.<br /><br />This usually consists of helping out underachieving (or, indeed, overachieving) students to improve in maths, science, etc. But I have decided that my time is a tad too valuable to be wasting on teaching a 12-year-old how to find <i>x</i> in a <a href="http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&q=define%3A+quadratic+equation&btnG=Search" target="_blank">quadratic equation</a>.<br /><br />I have decided to pass down my gritty knowledge of the internet and design to a group of kids in years 9 and 10 (who are going to be about 13 to 14 years old). It'll be done in the form of a few after-school sessions, and hopefully they'll be working towards producing a few (well designed!) web pages each.<br /><br />I don't know about you, but I think that sounds a little bit more interesting than just doing quadratic equations (despite their importance). On top of that, it might just catch <a href="http://dictionary.reference.com/search?r=2&q=elitist" target="_blank">Oxford</a> or <a href="http://dictionary.reference.com/search?r=2&q=elitist" target="_blank">Cambridge's</a> eye when it comes to the university crunch.<br /><br />I love <a href="http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&q=define%3A+google&btnG=Search" target="_blank">Google definitions</a>.

title: A Swarm of Cows
author: Fin
post_content: <img src="http://newsimg.bbc.co.uk/media/images/39970000/jpg/_39970612_law203.jpg" alt="" border="0" style="float:right; margin-left:10px;">The British equestrian eventing team has <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/equestrian/3577172.stm" target="_blank">won twice today</a>.<br /><br />Firstly the mixed team won a bronze in a gripping finish, while Leslie Law won silver on her horse, Shear L'Eau.<br /><br />It was dramatic, but the wins bring the Great Britain score up to <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/medals_table/3536512.stm" target="_blank">two silver medals and four bronze medals</a>, placing us 24th on the <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/medals_table/default.stm" target="_blank">Medals Table</a> at the end of Day 5.<br /><br />We're in for a few more medals this week, notably a possible gold from the <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/badminton/3577038.stm" target="_blank">GB badminton pair</a> who have made the finals and are guaranteed a silver.

title: Getting Excited!
author: Fin
post_content: <a href="http://www.bustertests.co.uk/" target="_blank">BusterTests.co.uk</a> is gaining momentum, and I have started to plan out a few new tactics for making the site popular.<br /><br />The main tactic to to advertise heavily on the site. The adverts aren't pop-ups or pup-unders (for that would break the webmaster code), but simple banner ads at the top and in the middle of the tests and results. They occur ever four questions.<br /><br />But here is the clever part: it only costs &pound;0.04 to advertise a website on Google for the search terms "gcse revision" and "gcse bitesize" (the single-most searched thing when it comes to 'GCSE').<br /><br />I haven't started the adverts yet, but it sure is cheaper that I thought it would be.<br /><br />The second thing that I was thinking about is the whole notion of 'brand identity and experience' - what does busterTests stand for? What feelings to users get of busterTests? How can I make them like it?<br /><br />I am developing my ideas all the time, and I have to do so rather quickly for them to be applicable, but I am thinking towards the direction that busterTests should be a cheeky website. I want it to stand out from other boring sites (like bitesize) and make it a fun and engaging site that allows the users/students to progress at their own pace, whenever they want. I want them to think that busterTests is cool, and so that organic marketing can occur, and the site will be spread by word-of-mouth.<br /><br />More on this later.

author: 陈老师
post_content: heee...went to watch phantom again today with cuiyan...<br />Enjoyed the show more this time round...though cuiyan commented that she enjoyed the first time more...<br /><br />PS: heee....cuiyan fell asleep during the show...and she thought i did not know...haaha...maybe she was too tired....<br /><br />Really really enjoyed the scene at the roof top of the Opera House, Christine and Raoul:<br /><br /><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">RAOUL:<br />No more talkof darkness,<br />Forget thesewide-eyed fears.<br />I'm<br />here,<br />nothing can harm you - my words will warm and calm you.<br /></span><p></p><p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">Let me beyour freedom,<br />let daylightdry -your tears.<br />I'm here,with you,<br />beside you,to guard you and to guide you . . .<br /></span></p><p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">CHRISTINE:<br />Say you love me<br />everywaking moment,<br />turn my head with<br />talk of summertime . . .<br /></span></p><p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">Say you need me with you,<br />now and always . . .<br />promise me that allyou<br />say is true - that's all I askof you . . .<br /><br />RAOUL:<br />Let me be your shelter,<br />let me be your light.<br />You're safe:<br />No one will find you<br />your fears are far behind you . . .</span></p><p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">CHRISTINE:<br />All I wantis freedom, a world with no more night . . .<br />and you<br />always beside me<br />to hold me and to hide me . . .</span></p><p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">RAOUL:<br />Then say you'll share with me<br /><span style="color:#6600cc;">one love, one lifetime . . .</span><br />Let me lead you from your solitude . . .<br />Say you need me<br />with you here,<br /></span><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">beside you . . .<br />anywhere you go,<br />let me go too -<br />Christine,<br />that's all I askof you . . .<br /><br />CHRISTINE:<br />Say you'll share with me<br />one love, one lifetime . . .<br />say the word and I will follow you . . .<br /><br />BOTH:<br />Share each day with me,<br />each night,<br />each morning . . .<br /><br />CHRISTINE:<br />Say you love me . . .<br /><br />RAOUL:<br />You know I do . . .<br /><br />BOTH:<br />Love me -<br />that's all I ask of you . . . </span></p><blockquote><p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">super romantic! i will surely melt if someone says this to me... heee....</p></blockquote></span>

title: Memorial Day/Mom's birthday
author: george
post_content: We've spent the last 6 weeks nursing two injured Basenji's back to health. Basenji's are an African Hound dog. They are used for hunting small game. Our 4 year old 'senji's, Bob (25 lbs) and Lucy (23 lbs) decided they didn't like Jake, our 120 pound Lab-Rottie mix. They proceeded to open a can of whup ass on him. It didn't work. Jake cleaned their clocks. Lucy had a front leg broken and foot nearly chewed off. Bob had major muscle damage to his upper rear leg, his penis was bitten off and belly ripped open. Our Vet managed to repair them to near perfect condition. This was the first time Bob had attacked Jake. Lucy tried it two years ago and received injuries to her head, neck and chest. Basenji's are not known for having good sense. We did not buy these dogs. There's no dog in the world worth $600-$1000 each. All our dogs have been strays. Four years ago on Memorial Day weekend my wife opened the front door to get the newspaper and they were curled up on the porch bench. They ran in the house, jumped on the sofa and went to sleep. They had no collars, tags or microchip. We spent a month trying to find their owners without luck. Basenji's are really weird dogs. They are like a cat in a dog costume. They don't bark but make a noise like a human yawn sound. They will eat nearly anything that will fit down their throats. Bob's favorite treat is oranges. Lucy likes cucumbers with blue cheese dressing.

title: Third Year Anniversary
author: Jeff Robinson
post_content: Third Monk Records continues to develop artists and release product on an international scale.<br /><br />Cool.<br /><br />May 21, 2005 will see the Detroit release (national release to follow within 60 days) of the Penumbrae debut 11-song CD entitled "One Way Drive".  Careful work since September has made this disc what it is and the band sound brilliant.  A 5-piece quintet bridging the sonic gaps between Phish-Pink Floyd and Radiohead.  Basic tracks were cut at the Tempermill Studios in Ferndale, Michigan and ensuing overdubs were done with the Third Monk mobile unit at various locations around Metro Detroit.<br /><br />Since the disc was mastered by Gavin Lurssen at the Mastering Lab, songs have already been aired on WSDP-FM, WHFR-FM, WRAX-FM and the band have performed live on the nationally syndicated Mitch Albom show as well as in the studios of WHFR-FM at Henry Ford Community College.  Further non-comercial radio airplay and a fall tour to college campuses in the midwest are in the cards for the band.  Let's wish them the best!<br /><br />Thanks to everyone who participated in the iTunes/Pepsi promotion.  With the deadline for use of Pepsi product caps with free downloads passing on May 23, 2005, we are grateful to anyone who had the opportunity to download Third Monk Records artists for free.  Songs from Third Monk Records artists remain available at all paid download sites from iTunes to Aol.com to Audiolunchbox.com.<br /><br />After the analog tape scare we had back in December, it is a great, great thing that Quantegy tape has been bought by 2 past employees.  The analog tape domain is precious and without it, the record making process would be seriously hindered.  Even in the face of the Digital Audio Workstation, the essence of analog tape can still be an essential ingredient to produce amazing  recordings of great songs.  Better still to think that Emtec (BASF) is back in the fray and ATR Services in Pennsylvania will be making their own analog tape.<br /><br />The music industry should continue to regain it's strength in the next 5 to 10 years while it recovers from the attack of the evil 3-headed hydra- namely Corporate Radio, illegal MP3 downloading and the advent of the Digital Audio Workstation.  With great trepidation, we should all be concerned and closely monitor the Elliot Spitzer Payola investigation in New York State and encourage legislation to be passed in Washington, D.C. to eliminate the ridiculous concept of songs as 'paid' advertisements.  As for the rest, everyman is empowered with their Digitial Audio Workstations and the industry finally has a grasp on how to make money selling mp3s.<br /><br />Let's hope for the best!

title: Label First Year Anniversary
author: Jeff Robinson
post_content: In March of 2003, it will have been 2 years since Third Monk Records came into existance.<br /><br />Last fall saw the release of Los Angeles alt country singer/songwriter Adam Austin. After several years working as a set dresser on many of the biggest Hollywood films, Adam Austin befriended Hollywood film director Sam Raimi (Evil Dead, Evil Dead 2, Darkman, For love of the game, The Gift) while working on the superhero action movie "Spiderman". Taking an interest in the music of Adam Austin and believing strongly in Adam's artistic vision, Mr. Raimi helped finance this debut release. Borrowing members of the Lucinda Williams band, Adam has created a sound which hearkens to best of Crosby, Stills and Nash. Third Monk Records is very excited about this release!<br /><br />Currently, Third Monk is developing Detroit based act 'Step 13'. A solid pop/rock act in the style of Matchbox 20 or Coldplay, Third Monk is culitivating the necessary focus to a very talented band. New music should be available in the coming months.<br /><br />In the past 2 years, Third Monk has also served in a much more altruistic sense in a role that may help improve the music industry. Working as a watchdog of sorts with regard to the Corporate Radio/Payola situation that has become prevalent since the signing of the 'Telecommunications Act of 1996'. Coming up against the problem headlong with the Matthew Harrison disc "Charmed" at commercial alternative radio and finding out from various Program Directors that it would cost approximately $500-$1500 per new ad at a commercial radio station, Third Monk made the decision to work closely with the Los Angeles Times and ABC News to bring this issue to light. Obviously as an independent artist collective with modest roots, Third Monk could not afford the half million dollars it would have cost to make Matthew Harrison an overnight success nationally. Third Monk naively proceeded thinking the strength of the music would prevail and simply stated what we found out is this- music on public owned airwaves should not be 'paid advertising'- nor should it ever should be. More disturbing and at the detriment to the art, the broadcast conglomerates that have licensed these signals from the F.C.C. continue to abuse them on a daily basis. They play songs which have been paid for with absolutely no disclosure to the listenership about the practice.<br /><br />Third Monk filed complaints about this situation in 2001 with the F.C.C., Senators John McCain, Hillary Clinton, Joseph Lieberman, Harry Reid, Orrin Hatch, Babara Boxer, Dianne Feinstein and Representative Billy Tauzin. Third Monk also filed with the Attorney General in the state of California. Concurrent (and/or since) the exposure of this problem, Wisconsin Senator Russ Feingold has drafted the 'Competition in Radio and Concert Industries Act' which was put before the House on January 28, 2003. The passage of this Bill is absolutely essential for the improved health of the music industry. People who are quick to blame the internet for the demise of the music industry fail to realize that it's the constriction at the main outlet source for new music that is at fault. With playlists taking on a 'national' scope instead of a 'local' viewpoint, indiosyncracies and local taste are sacrificed for money. Local programmers lose their ability to program and what songs get played is determined by what songs the radio station can bill for via their indie promoter.<br /><br />On a brighter note, Third Monk Records will begin to develop the sale of MP3 singles via this website. Focusing on material that Third Monk has cultivated, MP3 singles will be priced between $.99 and $1.49 and payments will be able to be made through Paypal. Anyone with interests in purchasing any of the existing Third Monk material via such means can make that request through the e-mail link on this site. <br /><br />A link to the hearings - <a href="http://www.senate.gov/~commerce/">Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation</A><br /><br />Read <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20040202171457/http:/abcnews.go.com/sections/2020/2020/2020_payola_020524.html" target="_self">ABC's 20/20 article on Third Monk Records</a><br /><br />Read <a href="http://events.calendarlive.com/top/1,1419,L-LATimes-Search-X!ArticleDetail-43083,00.html" target="_self">L.A. Times article about Third Monk Records</a>

title: Genocide?
author: the bizn0rtch
post_content: First posts are always awkward.  Especially when you don't know what direction your site/blog/whatever is going to take.  The first post dictates the future content, theme, audience, and whatever random item that people will wind up reading when they come to the page or read the column.  And right now, I have no idea where this thing is going to be taken.  I just know that this is going to be a total gateway into each and every chaotic, random, bittersweet moment that occurs.  Add a dash of blatant honesty, strong opinions and whatever wit I can force out.  Good lord, I hope I don't bore the masses (or lack thereof) to death.

title: so how's things?
author: J
post_content: it's so nice to hear everyone's good news! congrats on the new bambino, nathaniel, and i'm happy to hear that all is well with you too chrissy (oh, i guess i have to get used to calling you christine!). it has been one busy summer for me and erik. some of you know that we went to our college reunion (we even stayed in a dorm) and to estonia to meet erik's relatives for the first time. being there was incredible. it felt a lot like another planet to us, but a very friendly and beautiful planet. erik has it set in his mind now that i'm somehow going to land a teaching job at tartu ullikool (the university of tartu). i keep trying to remind him that i have enough to worry about going on the market this fall without having to learn estonian on top of it all! i guess it's good to dream though. now that i'm done with summer teaching, it's back to the dissertation. but we are also planning a few little trips to see friends this august. it would be great to get together with all of you too. i hope everyone is doing well and that we can make that happen soon. until then, take care!

title: Presidential Politics
author: bemused
post_content: The presidential campaign is turning out to be a scumbag throwing contest. George Bush was saddled with a weak economy and a world of terrorist killers.  What is the motive of these killers.  Are the bag covered heads a sign of cowards and they butcher an unarmed, bound civilian.  I have issues when people say we should leave this war.  The war will then come to us and more twin towers.  Who do they blame then.  I truly believe Ted Kennedy's remarks comparing our current struggle against terrorist to Viet Nam as the catalyst that caused the deaths of over one hundred soldiers in April.  Comments or opinions like his should be hehind closed doors and not thrown out as political garbage.  Our enemies see weakness in those like Ted Kennedy and the candidate he supports John Kerry.  I would like to see the journalist look into the Awards & Decorations writings at the time he served.  I would like an interview with the officer that wrote up the papers to submit for his awards.  I also would like to know the statistics of how many awards were given to the men and women on his boat during his four month tour in Nam.  Would those statistics show that John Kerry and his brothers received more than the average for that short of tour.  Till Later.........

title: Sympathy
author: efatima
post_content: Dreams show us the interior landscape of the mind, the contours of our fears and wishes.  Dreams can be warnings or indications, beckoning us to a new level of learning or a new aspect of life that we must learn to face.<br /><br />The journey towards greater authenticity and innter connectedness is not an external adventure only.  Of course, we must move out into the world, utilizing our gifts and making real our dreams.  At the same time, we need to face our inner deamons - whether they be fears of failure and humiliation, repressed rage, narcissism, or even an excessive mistrust of people.  Dreams, especially recurring drams, may invite us into this inferno, reminding us of the inner work before us.</p><div class="blogger-post-footer">efatima's journal</div>

title: Burden Dropping
author: efatima
post_content: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/webmonk/35394536/" title="Photo Sharing"><img src="http://photos31.flickr.com/35394536_a75e6c290a_m.jpg" width="240" height="166" alt="Remember Him?" /></a><br /><br />I just couldn't help wonder.  Usually in Dubai, its very rare find homeless.  Morever this gentleman is from Pakistan.  <br /><br />So Baba (father), aren't you are far away from home, I said.  <br /><br />He smiled and in a very humble manner, clasping his shakey hands with tears in his eyes, said "I have a very beautiful family, six sons ... and they are quite busy with their own, after my wife died, it didn't matter where I went so am here and I'm self employed too"  His greateful spirit lit his eyes as he went on about how lucky he is to his pride, his honor and a health that still keeps him on his feet.<br /><br /> While, I was intently listening to him, he then suddenly stopped and guided me into the shade, saying the sun was too harsh on me. <br /><br />I just frooze ... in awe.</p><div class="blogger-post-footer">efatima's journal</div>

title: Cory (mtngant)
author: Cory
post_content: What a great bowl season we had this year. Great games and an awesome National Championship game.<br /><br />The Ducks performance was the only downer. We should have won. We played poorly and sadly I have to point to the coaching staff and their decisions.<br /><br />As for the rest of the top games, wow, Ohio State really impressed me in the Fiesta Bowl against Notre Dame, the Buckeyes are impressive. The Sugar Bowl, it looked like after the end of the first half that they would both score 60 points, amazing offenses. It was a fun first half of football. Of course they slowed down in the second half and it was a battle to the end.<br /><br />All of the BCS bowls were battles, the Orange Bowl, wow! Three overtimes! The missed field goals, the intensity was great, I was sure glad Kevin Kelly came through with his third chance to win the game. I am not sure he would have lived to old age if he would have missed another. Paterno and Bowden are the two winningest coaches in D-I football battling it out for over 4 hours (79 years old and 76 years old respectively). It was cool to watch.<br /><br />Then there came the Rose Bowl for the National Championship. I was saying before the game, this is the most significant football game of the century. Texas and USC, all the stories to be told, wow. Texas ranked number two all season, had an amazing year, routing most all of the teams they came up against. After the game commentators were asking if Vince Young (runner-up Heisman candidate) might be the best quarterback ever! He is amazing, he ran for 200 yards and He threw for 267 yards, in the Rose Bowl for the National Championship! This Young’s second year in a row winning the Rose Bowl, his combined yardage and amazing …. 839 yards in two Rose Bowls.<br /><br />"That," USC coach Pete Carroll said, "is an extraordinary football player."<br /><br />"Vince is truly one of the great competitors to ever play college football," coach Mack Brown said Wednesday night. "He has got a tremendous amount of confidence. He just exudes that confidence."<br /><br />And the USC Trojans … Matt Leinart comes back passing up tens of millions of dollars this year to go for his 3rd National Championship in a row. He was the Heisman winner in 2004, the top player in the whole nation. This year Reggie Bush, running back for USC, wins the Heisman and he deserved it he is like no other, he runs by defensive players like they are 7th grade girls. Two Heisman winners on one team playing for their 3rd National Championship, guarding a 34 game winning streak, they had not lost since 2003!<br /><br />Now the game, wow, they battle to the final seconds. There was no way to know the final outcome until the buzzer rang. Intense. Wow. That was fun.

title: Ode to the Blue Bike
author: Cory
post_content: The following is a portion of a e-newsletter I recieved from the Petersons, missionaries from our church:<br /><br />Saul is one of the finest young Christian men we know. He entered the military to be able to study medicine and eventually use that for the Lord. About 6 months ago he felt convicted to leave the military and prepare himself for full-time Christian service. Saul shared that when he was in the military they would sleep with their weapon, learn how to take it apart and assemble it in the dark and carry it with them at all times. They knew it inside and out. He said for the next month he wants to do the same with his spiritual weapon (the Bible). He wants to spend as much time in the Word as he can and carry it with him wherever he goes, sleep with it, etc. "Why should we know a physical weapon better than our spiritual weapon?"<br />Please pray for these youth who attended [the Youth Leaders Retreat]. They have the potential to change the youth of Mexico and God believes in them just like he does in you and I.<br /><br />TZOALLI'S BIRTHDAY<br />One of those who attended the retreat is Tzoalli who celebrated her 30th birthday a couple of weeks ago. Tzoalli works for Johnson & Co. here in Mexico and has a heart for evangelism. She has a sister who is a Christian but her brother and father are not. She has led several of her friends to the Lord and is working on others. This year she decided to give a birthday brunch for herself. But she didn't want it to be just a regular birthday party but an evangelistic one. So she asked some friends of hers who have a huge backyard if she could use it for the event. She invited half Christian friends and the other half non-Christian friends and family that she has been witnessing to. She asked all of her non-Christian friends ahead of time to be specifically praying for those who would be coming. She had a beautiful brunch catered with little place cards with scriptures on them. She had some friends sing some Christian music, she shared a testimony of what Christ had done in her life and she had Rodney share a short devotional thought.<br />It was a meaningful time and those who were Christians had a great opportunity to get to know those who weren't and share in a casual environment. Please pray for Tzoalli and her continued witness to her friends and family that she will see the fruit of her efforts.<br /><br />Below are two pictures from the retreat plus a picture of Tzoalli sharing at her birthday brunch.<br /><br />Your Partners in Ministry,<br />Rodney and Linda Peterson<br /><br /><a href="http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/1950/409/1600/rodney%20p%20teaching.jpg"><img style="CURSOR: hand" alt="" src="http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/1950/409/320/rodney%20p%20teaching.jpg" border="0" /></a><br /><a href="http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/1950/409/1600/mexican%20group1.jpg"><img style="CURSOR: hand" alt="" src="http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/1950/409/320/mexican%20group1.jpg" border="0" /></a> <a href="http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/1950/409/1600/mexican%20testimony.jpg"><img style="CURSOR: hand" alt="" src="http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/1950/409/320/mexican%20testimony.jpg" border="0" /></a>

title: Already in heaven?
author: Cory
post_content: Is the church/youth group to entertain those who attend or is it to make disciples?<br /><br />Are we to make disciples or converts or church members?<br /><br />What does it mean to make disciples?<br /><br />What is a Disciple of Christ? Answers will be given on Sunday night in a couple weeks.<br /><br />I ran across a good article recently titled “Jesus Isn’t Cool” (<a href="http://www.christiancentury.org/article.lasso?id=1219">http://www.christiancentury.org/article.lasso?id=1219</a>) and a good Blog in response (http://www.internetmonk.com/archives/2005/09/020017.html), with good comments and then a 30 minute podcast(?) (<a href="http://www.oneplace.com/ministries/the_white_horse_inn/Archives.asp">http://www.oneplace.com/ministries/the_white_horse_inn/Archives.asp</a>) that even though I don’t agree with all these guys’ theology or even church methodology, they make some good comments about what the church is all about. And it’s not entertainment. Click on the broadcast titled “My Kids are Bored in Church.”<br /><br />Some say, “What you win them with is what you will keep them with.” This means if someone becomes a Christian (or church member) because of a fancy presentation, concert, game night, or good snacks ... that is what they will expect the church to be, if it changes they are no longer interested.<br /><br />What should our main things be?<br /><br />The following is a paragraph from the “Jesus Isn’t Cool” article:<br /><br />“One student … participated in his church’s “”40 Days of Purpose”” campaign, hoping that an exploration of Rick Warren’s popular book The Purpose Driven Life would help. Instead, he reached this conclusion: ““I don’t understand why you need God for a sense of purpose, self-esteem, or whatever … lots of people have that without God.”” This young man was on to something.”<br /><br />What does he mean by this?<br /><br />What is God calling us to be?

title: Lori Gant's blog
author: Cory
post_content: New Orleans…it is amazing how bad it is down there. Very sad stories. I can’t imagine losing family, friends, home, all possessions, neighborhoods, everything familiar. And "Fats" Domino is missing.<br /><br />My prayers are that the survivors might find God and a true relationship with Him through Jesus Christ is all this. God is good all the time! Even in tragedy He is working.<br /><br />However … who’s idea was it to live 5-10’ below sea level? What were they thinking … with a 20 mile long lake lurking over them just beyond a levee? Whose idea was that?<br /><br />So now we have 1000’s dead and billions and billions of property damage. Who’s going to pay for it? We are. Our government will give billions. Our insurance companies will pay out billions. Therefore, our taxes will go up and insurance rates will go up. So who pays for these people’s lack of judgment, you and me.<br /><br />We, in the northwest, live in an area of the country that has virtually no natural disasters that cost the rest of the country, but we pay for them to live in hurricane country below sea level. Where is the fairness in that?<br /><br />Is it a good idea to rebuild these areas of New Orleans that are below sea level? I think not. Move north, man.<br /><br />I like what JACK CHAMBLESS, ECONOMICS PROFESSOR, VALENCIA COMMUNITY COLLEGE said to FOXNEWS in response to the question “You don’t believe one taxpayer dollar should go toward rebuilding the city of New Orleans?”:<br /><br />“Well, if we look at Article One, Section Eight of the United States Constitution — and I encourage all Americans to look at that before we start opening up our tax coffers to pay for all of this — we have every obligation to provide for New Orleans in terms of charity, private charity from one person to the other.<br /><br />But the founding fathers never intended, Article One, section Eight of the Constitution, never intended to provide one dollar of taxpayer dollars to pay for any disaster or anything that we might call charity. What we now have is the law of unintended consequences taking place, where FEMA has come into New Orleans, a place where, ecologically, it makes no sense to have levees keeping the Mississippi River from flooding into New Orleans, like it naturally should.<br /><br />Now with FEMA bailing out Louisiana, bailing out Florida and lowering the overall cost of living in these places, we have people with no incentive to leave. And the law of unintended consequences means that more people are dying with every one of these storms. They're becoming more and more expensive, more and more property loss, just because the federal government has violated the Constitution to provide for these funds.”

Parting Shot<br />===========oursponsor===========<br />YOU COULD WIN AN ELECTRIC GUITAR FROM THE NEWSBOYS!<br />The Newboys are giving away an electric guitar (an Epiphone G-310 SG to be exact, a $415 retail value!) You can also download FREE chord charts and devotions to the songs Devotion and Presence. You can even view an exclusive WorshipTogether.com at the "webisodes"—a teaching video on how to play the songs!<br />Sign up for the guitar and watch the webisodes:<br />http://artists.sparrowrecords.com/newsboys/contest<br /><br />Download the FREE chord charts and devotions:<br />http://www.youthspecialties.com/free/newsboys<br />=================================<br />1. SOMETHING FOR YOUR HEART<br /><br />Here's a brief reflection on the song "Meant to Live" by Switchfoot<br /><br />"We were meant to live for so much more.<br /><br />Have we lost ourselves?<br /><br />Somewhere we live inside."<br /><br />I once heard a preacher say, "We need to learn to live from the inside out." I think he was right.<br /><br /> Look at the words of Jesus:<br /><br />"'Whoever believes in me, as the Scripture has said, streams of living water will flow from within him.' By this he meant the Spirit, whom those believed in him were later to receive. Up to that time the Spirit had not been given, since Jesus had not yet been glorified" (John 7:38-39).<br />Notice that life comes from the inside out, not from the outside in. So many of us have this mixed up. We try to get stuff, relationships, fame, or power to feed life into us, but none of those things can do that. The only source of life is found in God.<br /><br />"Jesus answered, 'I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me'" (John 14:6).<br /><br />You can find life only in Jesus Christ, in a living relationship with him, through the Holy Spirit. You can draw life from him every day. His Spirit dwelling inside of you can bring life even in the most deadly of situations.<br /><br />In the song "Meant to Live," Switchfoot sings about finding the life we were meant to live. You can only find that in the plan God has for your life. And that plan is right there, in your heart. As you fellowship with the Lord in his Word and in prayer, his Spirit will reveal that plan to your heart. Then you will know the life you were meant to live.<br />(Suzy C.)<br /><br />Daily Reflections from Solid Sounds, copyright 2005 The Good News Broadcasting Association, Inc. (Solid Sounds). Used by permission. To receive daily Reflections by e-mail or to read on-line, visit: <a href="http://www.solidsounds.org">http://www.solidsounds.org</a><br /><br />2. FORGETTABLE FACT<br />Moses, Aristotle, Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin all stuttered.<br /><br />4. POTENT QUOTABLES<br />There is no more blessed way of living, than the life of faith upon a covenant-keeping God--to know that we have no care, for he cares for us; that we need have no fear, except to fear him; that we need have no troubles, because we have cast our burdens upon the Lord, and are conscious that he will sustain us.<br />- C.H. Spurgeon<br /><br />The law of God and also the way to life is written in our hearts; it lies in no man's supposing, nor in any historical opinion, but in a good will and well doing.<br />- Jacob Bohme<br /><br />Is life worth living? title: Bridges of Reconciliation
author: Cory
post_content: Ducks v. Huskies<br /><br />Aric got tickets and invited me to go with him. I finally got to go to a duck game at The PIT!<br /><br />What an awesome game.<br /><br />Before the game we were talking, I made the statement, that I thought with the talent this team has, they could beat any team in the nation.<br /><br />Well ... they were playing the 11th ranked team in the nation. The Ducks led basicly from start to finish of the regualation periods. What did-them-in, was their very poor free throw shooting and that overtime period.<br /><br />The Huskies have a problem with fouls and I think 3-4 of their players fouled out, however they have a deep enough bench to play a very good overtime to win the game.<br /><br />But if we would have simply made those 15 foot shots. Arrgh that is aggravating.

title: Saved - the movie
author: Cory
post_content: For those of you uncouth enough not to know, noodling is another word for hand-fishing, mainly for catfish, which is apparently legal in only four states: Oklahoma, Louisiana, Mississippi and Tennessee.<br /><br /><em>A little about the 2001 documentary on the sport:</em><br />Shot on video and film, “Okie Noodling” follows three main groups of Oklahoma hand fishermen. Each one has their own take on what noodling is all about and what the secrets are. One of the noodlers has been mentioned prominently in the past, even having appeared on David Letterman, though I apparently missed that episode. They each come from very small towns in the backcountry and their passion happens to be catching giant catfish with their bare hands. One of the first shots of the film shows the self-proclaimed noodling champion up to his neck in dirty, placid river water, grimacing and then pulling to the surface a three-foot long, 35-pound catfish that has its mouth around his hand. You can also see the man’s fingers coming out the gills, which is how he gets a grip on the fish. According to the director’s commentary, this shot has elicited many a gasp from film festival crowds, and it is indeed a good way to start.<br /><br />From: <a href="http://www.audiorevolution.com/dvd/revs/okie_noodlingp1.html">www.audiorevolution.com/dvd/revs/okie_noodlingp1.html</a> 2.9.05<br /><br />Also: <a href="http://www.okienoodling.com">www.okienoodling.com</a>

post_content: The Future is NOW at BBC!<br />This is a “regular” e-mail update to keep churches and friends informed and in the know!<br />February 2, 2005<br /><br />For the last 60 years the Mission of Boise Bible College has been:<br />To raise up a leadership for the Lord’s church by:<br />Preparing students for full-time Christian ministry;<br />Preparing students to serve as Christian leaders;<br />Preparing all students with spiritual enrichment.<br /><br /><br />· GOOD NEWS: Student Count is up for second term! In fact this is the highest spring semester student count in history! Most colleges including BBC usually have a lower count the second semester. We had 14 new students for spring plus some students returned that had taken time off.<br /><br />· Mission Emphasis is the week of February 7th. We will have special chapels each day featuring speakers emphasizing the breadth of missions work, locally, throughout our own country and around the world. It promises to be both inspirational and informative.<br /><br />· Speaking of Missions - Our business manager Mark Stevens and the Eagle Christian Church Praise Team are headed to the Hunan Province in China February 23rd through March 9th. They will do a series of concerts in schools, universities and various settings. Pray for them as they travel and that through music, word and deeds they will be able to share Jesus with the Chinese people.<br /><br />· Building Expansion Update: We had an excellent meeting with the architects, design engineers and our electrician this week. Plans for our expansion are moving ahead quickly. Packets of information are in the process of being sent out to our supporting churches. We had two churches this last month that agreed to support a dorm room @ $12,000 each. One church is sending an additional $200 per month for the next five years and the other has agreed to send in the full $12,000 now. Praise God for this commitment to training leaders for ministry! If you need more information on how you can help, contact our Development Office.<br /><br />· President of BBC, Dr. Crane is excited about the record number of applications already received for next year. He is thankful for the generous gifts from our supporters and anxious to find room for all the students next year. His words, “We must build now to have room for all those interested in studying to become ministers. Please consider a gift to Boise Bible College.”<br /><br />· The music group “Crossing Guards” were at Capital City Christian Church and at Buhl First Christian Church in January. In February they are scheduled to be at Mini-Cassia Christian Church in Heyburn Idaho, First Christian Church in Emmett Idaho, First Christian Church in Dayton Washington and in Lewiston Idaho at Orchard Christian Church.<br /><br />Recommended books for youth and children leaders from Bill Krause, Children’s and Youth Professor:<br /><em>Transforming Children into Spiritual Champions</em> by Barna<br /><em>Family-Based Youth Ministry</em> by DeVries<br /><em>Leadership &amp; Self-Deception</em> by the Arbinger Institute<br /><br /><br />· BBC men start the basketball season well . . . we have two teams playing in the local men’s church league. They started the season playing against each other and in a well played game the white team scored more than the blue team. The second week saw both teams winning. Thanks to Professor Dale Cornet acting as coach for about the 25th straight year! New comer David Davolt is helping “coach” the white team.<br /><br />Thanks for your Partnership with Boise Bible College, together we are making a difference as the world sees and hears the Good News of Jesus through our collective efforts.<br />David Davolt<br />Director of Development<br /><br />Check out our web site: <a href="http://www.boisebible.edu/">http://www.boisebible.edu/</a><br /><br />Consider Setting up a Gift Annuity for Boise Bible CollegeA “Gift Annuity” is an excellent method to plan your future and provide a generous gift to Boise Bible College. A gift of $10,000 will provide a fixed income to the giver for their lifetime. The rates vary with age - @ 80 years old you would receive 8% annually or $800 @ 65 years old you would receive 6% or $600 annually. There are substantial tax benefits the year the gift is given and some savings each year there after. Your gift is another method to provide for educating ministers for the future. It is always best to check with your tax advisor or accountant to take full advantage of all tax benefits.<br /><br />(If for any reason you do not wish to receive this update or have another e-mail that we should use – notify by return e-mail.)

title: No suicide yet...
author: T
post_content: Well things are toddling along. I went on BBC London last night to discuss the next day's papers witha very funny woman called Stella Duffy and the DJ, both of whom are ludicrously quick and hilariously funny. I was a bit stuffy alongside and my lack of encyclopaedic knowledge about showbiz didn't help. But whatever, the highlight of the evening was the cab ride home. I was driven by a Bulgarian guy who had made and lost fortunes in Bulgaria and told me a few explicit truths - summed up as 'don't waste your youth worrying'. I've often been under the impression that life is sending me clues, very much in the way omens are sugested by Paolo Coelho in the Alchemist. Except I don't believe in a higher power - at all - and so it makes it easy for me to ignore these impressions I get. But the truths are getting clearer and louder - I can't keep ignoring the evidence that I am wasting my life. I am pissed off - I am pissed off with my flatmate, who is also pissed off with life, I am pissed off with my job, where the confidence has drained out of me to an unrealised extent. I am pissed off with my inability to get out of bed to get to work on time, my inability to organise my life at all, my inability to get and hold down a relationship. I have all that anyone could want - I look reasonably nice, I'm quite intelligent, quite witty. I'm not the best at anything, but I have talents. Yet I find it so difficult to do or say anything at all. My only role among my friends is as a kind of eccentric. Maybe I have CJD. I'm still wearing my Dad's shirts. I never iron them. Myt trousers don't fit. Blah fucking blah - I bore even myself. Basically my life is barely tolerable. But I need to try to make money somehow. I like learning Arabic. I like salsa but it's hard to keep from thinking it's an exam rather than a pleasure. I DON'T KNOW WHAT TO DO. And I certainly don't know why I am putting all this up on a website next to a photo of me (well; noone is reading so it barely amtters). How postmodern, showing all the workings, except I don't feel like anything is working at all. and I feel the longer it doesn't the further away any prospect of realising any potential recedes. I am so used to failure now, personally and professionally, that I am slipping into a role of a bitter, disatisfied person whose creative synapses have withered through lack of use. I retain a certain arrogance, thinking wrongly that I could have been a prince, but under that increasingly brittle shell I am hollow. One day I will just collapse and the pieces will simply blow away.

title: The Germans
author: T
post_content: Just got in from the most horrendous club in London. I really cannot stand it. I must have been there 15 times and I've only pulled once. I suppose I can get away with namechecking it here on the grounds that it is fair comment - my honestly held opinion (it is) on a matter of public interest (it may be free before 9 but you should know that the drinks are not cheap). Strawberry Moon's. There. I haven't been there for 2 years after taking a vow. But my flatmate - who has got lucky there many a time - has just split up with his girlfriend and fancied trying top get laid. No luck for him either... Date tomorrow. I am looking forward to it. Such a lottery though - i have no idea what she looks like and so much hangs on that...

title: Rob's brother is a dick and the tree party
author: Dana
post_content: I was in Rob's bedroom, and Melissa was there. We both were taking a final exam for some teacher. It was a pretty hard test, and at one point the teacher came in the room to check on us. She left, and told us we had only 20 minutes left. She shut the door behind her, and I started freaking out because I didn't think I could finish it. Melissa and I started talking, and Melissa told me one of the answers. She didn't really *say* it, she was singing it, over and over again. As she was doing this both our parents walked into the room. Melissa didn't seem to notice, and she kept singing the answer. I tried to shut her up, but our parents saw that she was giving me an answer. The teacher walked in a few seconds later, oblivious that Melissa gave me and answer. However, my dad told her! The teacher became VERY angry, and grabbed our tests from us and told us that we failed the class for cheating. I started crying and begging her to reconsider, saying that we were not cheating. I really did not believe that we had cheated at all. I was so afraid I would not graduate on time because I would have to retake the class.

title: Dad's Ukulele
author: Dana
post_content: I was in the middle of downtown Chicago, and for some reason I was in this pool of lake water or river water, I'm not sure why. There was a little floating platform, and on it a paper bag. I had all these M&Ms, and was trying to get them all in the paper bag. Some of the M&Ms would fall, though (for some reason putting them in the bag was a very difficult task) and go in the water. They floated, so I would scoop them up quickly so not to lose a single one. I felt like each one had feelings, and I didn't want any of them to get lost! They had little voices and would scream. The red ones I associated with Rob, and especially didn't want to lose those. I don't know if I ever got all the M&Ms in the bag, because it kept tipping over and they would all spill out.

title: Biting Hamsters and Smores
author: Dana
post_content: I was married to Rob, and had a little baby. Rob also had a mistress who was my nanny/mothers helper/nursemaid (this dream seemed to take place in a whole other time and place). We lived in this log cabin in bufu, and Rob was some kind of political guy. Basically, he once loved me, but he became important with the French, and pretty much wanted to leave me. I was really upset, and I decided to go and tell him that his mistress had cheated on him. He was in another cabin in a very dark forest, with all these other political French people. I was wearing a long hooded cloak. Anywho, I went into the cabin, and he was sitting on chair surrounded by people. I told him that his mistress had cheated on him with the sheriff, who was sitting right next to him. Rob had this very angry look on his face, and ordered that the mistress be tied up and punished. I started to yell because he was not punishing the sheriff guy. I turned around to leave, and told Rob that I loved him. He made some smart ass comment, and I left, crying.

title: DJ, and Picture People
author: Dana
post_content: In my dream, I came home from work and was mortified to see that there was all this hair growing on my upper lip, like a mustache! It was also on my nose. It was this very fine, silky, white and gray hair, and it was several inches long! I took out my electric trimmer and shaved it off. That's all I really remember.

title: Shopping, witches, airplanes, and Casey's
author: Dana
post_content: I decided I must not have taken my meds yesterday, and took them today, so I am feeling moderatly better now. I had crazy dreams last night. I dreamt I was in some quaint little town, and I was in a little cottage like house, and I had my hermit crabs. Then I was a little bird, and I was with some other little bird (I'm not sure who it was) and we were in another cottage style home/bookstore (think Beauty and the Beast) in the middle of a busy, but very sunny and cute, town. I was very tiny and we were flying around and trying to escape. There was normal sized people, and this woman with a snake. I was thinking that the snake was very poisonous and she should not touch it, but she was too ignorant to realize it. I flew out the window with my friend as I heard her screams as the snake attacked her throat, and she fell on the ground dead. We flew towards a huge river. The distance was very dark and foreboding. There was another city on the other side of the huge river, but this city was dark and in the middle of war, and a city of the future. We stopped on this long island in the middle of the two cities, which was just a huge forest. A huge storm was coming, and a tornado. The tornado was part man, though. He came running in our direction. We were still birds, and we flew to the southernmost tip of the island, and for some reason flew under the water, and grabbed onto some reeds. The tornado/man came, but we were underwater and holding tight to these water plants, so we did not get blown away. Next we found ourselves in the city of war. It was rather futuristic, and people were running through the streets screaming. These huge robots were lumbering about and blasting things with lasers. We flew to some tall building, and entered. I ceased being a bird here, and I was at work at the mall. However, instead of PP, it was some sort of Victoria's Secret. I was rearranging some wig rack (?) and all the managers were talking at the registers. Suddenly, the one manager called me over. "You didn't say hello or goodbye to the customer that was just in here. I would like you to leave" she told me. I apologized and said I didn't even see the customer. Then she was like "You need to have a better look" in this really bitchy voice. She said my panty hose were incorrect to company standards, and then asked to see my nails, and said they looked terrible, even though I said I was wearing their brand of polish. She kept saying "You need to leave now", so I was just like "fine, whatever, I'll leave". I didn't really care. She was such a bitch. I left, and somehow ended up in this warehouse/factory like building. It was very gray and full of metal and machinary. I found a group of people my age, who somehow knew who I was and were expecting me. Apparently there was a war and they were part of small resistance (why all my withdrawal dreams seem to involve wars and small resitances, I don't know). I joined, and we did lots of stuff with computers, and one day they opened up these huge gates. We were very, very tiny in comparisson. These gates were about as big as the entire warehouse wall. I looked out, and it was an endless blue sky and below, a huge bright blue ocean. We were about a mile up, but on the bottom of this huge building. Holding this massive building up were these huge stilts that reminded me of PVC tubing. We were very tiny, and we were fighting this war against these much larger people. It had a Waterworld feel to it. That's the end of my dream.

title: Disabled
author: Dana
post_content: All last night I had these crazy, extremely vivid dreams. My first dream was that I was some sort of priestess, and I was doing all these powerful magical spells. I was in the Casey's parking lot, and I was walking a circle, barefoot, around Dan, Kevin, Diane, Laura, and Mary Grace. I was dragging a sword in the ground around them, and it was making a golden circle around them. But the magic was so incredibly intense, I couldn't take it, it was running through me and I thought I would pass out, and I woke up so exhausted, like I had just run 50 miles. And there were all these weird symbols floating in front of me. Plus, I was dripping in a cold sweat. So, I went back to sleep. This time I had this dream that I was watching a movie, but I was in the movie and it was real at the same time. The Taliban or the Nazis or some general bad guy had taken over the world, it was WW3. I was in Chicago with my family and we were few of thousands of people trying to escape the city. But the bad guys were running around and shooting everyone and there was blood everywhere and we were trying to get across all these bridges. The bad guys got us and chained us and hundreds of others to this huge metal contraption and dropped it in the lake and we all drowned. But I kept seeing versions of this over and over again, my family and my boyfriend were murdered repeatedly in different ways along with thousands of others...it was part of a three part movie. The other parts took place in Italy where some people were putting up a resistance, and then somewhere in the Middle East where the pope and all these guys in turbans were running this mass genocide. It really was an awful, awful dream. I woke up again sweating. So, I went back to sleep after waking up from my everyone-dying dream. I had some more crazy dreams where I thought I was awake, but I couldn't move or wake up.
