mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;  mso-style-noshow:yes;  mso-style-priority:99;  mso-style-parent:"";  mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;  mso-para-margin:0in;  mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;  mso-pagination:widow-orphan;  font-size:11.0pt;  font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";  mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;  mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;  mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;  mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;} </style><![endif]--> <br /><div class="MsoNormal"><i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">Dear Family and Friends</span></i><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">, </span></div><div class="MsoNormal"><br /></div><div class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">The years honestly just fly by……<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">weren’t we just writing this letter?<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Wasn’t Patrick just entering pre-K and Anna just learning to walk</i>?<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>And yet, here we are, writing again with Patrick about to complete his first semester at Harvey Mudd College (HMC) in Claremont, CA and Anna now looking for what college she might like to go to…..<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">how is that possible??</i></span></div><div class="MsoNormal"><br /></div><div class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">Patrick is happily ensconced at HMC, which lives up to its tagline as…. <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">“the most amazing college you’ve never heard of</i>.”<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>The search/application/acceptance process was “interesting” (<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><u>read</u>:</i><span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>exhausting, nerve wracking, exhilarating) as all parents who have been through it can attest.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Patrick “<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">knew</i>” he wanted an engineering program <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">at a large school</i>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>He applied to many schools and was accepted at great schools including Duke where, in our minds in mid-April with the 1 May deadline approaching, he was going.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span><i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">However</i>.... there was <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">this one school near LA</i>where he was accepted but had not visited.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Fearing that Patrick would not be totally comfortable with the Duke decision without visiting all schools where he had been accepted, Shannon and Patrick decided to take a last minute visit to LA….. <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">so, Patrick could “cross HMC off the list</i>” and move forward with Duke…. <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">or that is how they sold it to Karen.</i><span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>So, 4 days before the decision deadline they flew to the West Coast and visited Harvey Mudd.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Patrick <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><u>really</u></i>liked it, which meant they now had to tell Karen, “<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Remember how we were crossing HMC off the list?</i> …..<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">well</i>, it has moved to the top of the list and Patrick is <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><u>NOT</u></i> going to college 92 miles away but rather 2,402 miles away.” Karen is still left wondering if the deciding factor wasn’t when the tour guide told them that the Honor Code at HMC was simple and straight forward – students must always act as responsible individuals and that the only “rules” on campus were those instituted only after a <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">demonstrated</i>need for them.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Some examples:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>“<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">All pranks must be reversible within 24 hours</i>.”<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>“<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">No flames can be higher than the buildings</i>.”<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>“<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">No projectile can leave campus</i>.”<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Patrick was <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">sold (hardly a surprise to those of you who know him well!)</i>, committed to HMC on 1 May, and has not looked back.</span></div><div class="MsoNormal"><br /></div><div class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">Anna, a junior, is getting mail/emails from schools and, so, we get to start over again.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Her interests are very different than Patrick’s, although she excels at math and science, she will undoubtedly follow her interests and look for strong humanities and arts programs.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>We all think a smaller school is best for her…. <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">which probably means she will end up at a big school</i>! <span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp;</span>Anna spent 3 weeks at an art program in Vermont this summer and <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">absolutely loved</i> the experience, including the chance to spend a little time with her cousins who live nearby.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Her cousins certainly hope she goes to college in New England.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>In addition to a very challenging academic schedule, Anna is involved in varsity tennis, winter cheer leading, orchestra and honors art.</span></div><div class="MsoNormal"><br /></div><div class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">A key highlight of our year was an extended summer trip to Vietnam and Cambodia.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>If you are asking “<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">why those two destinations</i>?” you are asking the same question Shannon asked.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>In mid-2012, Patrick announced to Shannon, “We are going to Cambodia in 2013!”<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>To which Shannon replied “No, we’re not!”<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>“Yes we are.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span><i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Mom said so</i>!”<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Apparently (<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">unbeknownst to Shannon</i>), Karen told both children years ago that the year they graduated from high school they could pick the destination for the family vacation.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Patrick chose Cambodia because of a long-standing fascination with Angkor Wat (one of the wonders of the world).<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>We spent three great days in Siem Reap near Angkor Wat and the other amazing Khmer ruins and added Vietnam to the itinerary because of the fabulous history and culture.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>It was truly a great vacation with a perfect mix of culture, food, scenery, history and relaxation.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Anna is mum about where she wants to go for “her trip” in 2015, though she is getting lots of suggestions from the rest of the family.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>We vetoed the idea of her going on a separate vacation which -- as a 17 year old girl -- sounded just perfect to her.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span></span></div><div class="MsoNormal"><br /></div><div class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">Shannon entered his 60<sup>th</sup>decade, turning 50 in August.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>In an attempt to prove he is still young and active he has scheduled a scuba diving trip with Anna and a ski trip with Patrick.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Shannon also <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">added another</i>milestone… his 2013 international work travel was even heavier than usual.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>So, this year he flew his <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">millionth mile on Delta (!!) </i><span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp;</span>– We are not sure if that is a good or bad thing.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>But we are eager to learn if the alleged “perk” of a Porsche ride across the tarmac in Atlanta if you are late for your flight is real or urban lore.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>We will keep you posted.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Karen feels that she spends more time with our beloved dog Tesla than any of the others but is always thrilled when we end up with a “full nest” –an increasingly rare experience these days.</span></div><div class="MsoNormal"><br /></div><div class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">Patrick can be very thoughtful with his gifts: <span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp;</span>for Shannon’s 50<sup>th</sup> he shared a list of 50 memories of Dad and for Mother’s day, he made Karen some jewelry, feeling obligated to announce, as she opened the gifts, “Don’t worry…. <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">all the materials used are non-toxic</i>!”<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Anyone who knows Patrick and his elements collection knows that that statement was relevant<i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">….and necessary! </i></span></div><div class="MsoNormal"><br /></div><div class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">We have now been lived in Winston-Salem for more than 20 years, the longest we have ever lived anywhere.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>If you had told us in the early 90s that we would still be here in 2013, we would have thought you were crazy.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>However, having raised two kids and held multiple different jobs in different industries, we feel incredibly fortunate to be where we are with the friends and the family we have.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>We wish all of those would come and visit!<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">&nbsp; </span>Happy Holidays and best wishes for 2014!</span></div></div>

title: the answer
author: infinity
post_content: <strong>The Answer:</strong><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br />WHO ARE WE ?<br />WHAT IS THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THE HUMAN EXPERIENCE?<br /><br /><br /><br /><br />What is time?<br />What is the purpose of time? does it begin or end? Does it move? Is it static? Is today tomorrow´s yesterday? What is humanity´s role or purpose in this static continuum?<br /><br />Civilizations appear and disappear. We appear and disappear and between one event and the other, time gives us its precious gift, the gift of existence. Life, death , growth, decay, happiness, joy, decease, sadness, healing, wealth, our own survival depends on time. Everything depends on it. Everything changes between one event and another. With the passage of time everything changes, even static things age in constant flux and transformation. We are not the same creatures we started out being nor are we the same persons we will become. We transform. One being completely different in body and mind. Evolved from simple to complex through growth. We are an expression of time, change and evolution.<br /><br />Is evolution, growth, transformation or time creations of a higher power or a mindless universe ?<br />These writings do not attempt to deal with those questions, they only attempt to establish certain links and correlations between them: Evolution takes time. Time expresses itself through evolution. Evolution is a transformation.<br />Time is all.<br /><br />Evolution and transformation come about as an expression. The Human expression exists through inter-dependent phenomena. An expression with an ultimate goal: Full development. In social evolution the goal is to express a human being fully self-contained, physically and intellectually with no further need of corrective after thought devices like laws or archaic arithmetical monetary systems to deal with each other. What for? if each human is complete and total, developed through: Knowledge. Extensive education, as much as each person desires. A social minimum> 20 years? 25? 30?<br /><br />A society that exists in time like anything else; evolves. It makes its developmental pattern from simple to complex automatically through growth and change . The goal of any society is to make things better through some means or other. If its members are not allowed to fully develop, intellectual corollary systems will be developeded to fill in the vacuum. Social institutions, correctional specially, will obligatorally be developed through the evolutive mechanism. Laws will have to be created and enforced depending on what was not fully acomplished in the preceding evolutive step. If in the human relations area; laws, courts, police forces will fill in the vacuum. If in the spiritual area, religions will fill in the vacuum.<br /><br />To survive on this planet, humanity has experienced the hard way to interact and exchange within itself and with every specie on it, one way or another. The earliest was the barter system; with the animal kingdom: I´ll keep you, I´ll feed you, I´ll take care of you, in exchange -- Ill take your hide or your meat. With the plant and mineral kingdom it has been basically the same exchange plus, we have learned not to pollute or we will not be able to breath.<br /><br />In bartering, if there are human beings not fully develloped, who do not understand the laws of equilibrium, ( equal exchange ), in other words think that they can or should get something for nothing, then social evolution will take over and fill the void: it will develop systems that will force them if not to undertand at least to make them live in relative harmony with the imposed laws, regulations of the corrollary corrective systems.  <br />Among the developed systems: the monetary system.<br /><br />If knowledge is not diseminated equally among the members of a society and some remain somewhat ignorant or completly ignorant of their roles in their group or society, geographical area, planet, space in time, history or universe and if barriers like language or distance seem insourmoutable like in societies early development, the monetary corrective system will become an evolutionary necessity.<br /><br />Money: An artificial mathematical exact systems of transaction, to help with the vacuum that ignorance produces. If the individual does not know how to deal with the rest of the group, rules will be imposed on him.<br />The monetary system depends on its own inherent rules and regulations that must be adhered to for it to work, for as in any mindles system it works on his own terms.<br />If a corrective system like the monetary one is used, societys highest potential has not been reached.<br /><br />Money performs at its best in concret terms, with tangibles. It does not understand or deal with feelings, morals or ethics. Usualy, morals suffer like in the following example: we are always chasing after the better deal. The more for less deal. In shopping, we want more for less, to the point that we are willing to turn a blind eye if a product has to be manufactured in a less developed country where labor is cheaper even if the working conditions are sub-human.<br />Another aspect of money or mathematical transaction that is almost imposible to understand is the disconnect.<br /><br />The disconnect relates to when something has or appears to have no connection with another, example: Addiction to drugs. Nine out of ten drug addicts at the time they purchase them do not relate to the chain of events unleashed at that moment, specially when many of the events will happen to other peoples in other lands far away from them in time and space.<br /><br />The "more for less" aspect is especially difficult to assimilate specially when dealing with intangibles like the ones mentioned above, it engenders a host of problems and is based soley on mechanical transaction, a transaction that is sometimes not easily understood by a not sufficiently developed or evolutionized or knowledgeable person. In that sense, if we continue to have under educated people we will have the same problem. The numbers game can be manipulated in other ways by those who know.<br /><br />More work from employee: for less wages.<br /><br />More price: for less quality.<br /><br />And on , and on , endlessly.<br /><br /><br />The more for less theory is applied throughout the system, inflation is a vital part of it and we are constantly trying to catch up with it. Quality of life is forced to be cheepened in every respect. It is the only way the system can work.<br />New language emerges such as: Corporate Economic Restructuring. Whereby the company must produce more with less workers and cheaper materials and thousands of jobs and lives are erased and destroyed.<br /><br /><br /><br />UTOPIA (Does it exist?)<br /><br /><br />There is no such thing as social human utopia.<br /><strong>It is the ultimate goal of evolution ( any evolution ) to attain perfection</strong>. Eventually language will include words like cheat, steal, rob, even the word truth only in a historical context "when man was underdeveloped and there existed social corollary suport systems to fill in .<br /><br />Basic law of time: Relativity.<br />To the cave man democracy is utopian. To us they are undeveloped.<br />Obviously the best society is one based on truth and trust alone with no need for correcting systems like money because clearly; if you are fully and totally developed, you will always do what is ethically and truthfully correct and to the end : Truth is the great equalizer.. A trust that comes about becaues you know that whatever anybody says or does (exept for mistakes or lack of knowledge which will be aknowleged and quickly corrected) must be true and ethical because there are no hidden purposes, pressures or agendas.<br />Only mankind strives to understand concepts of time and evolution in its relentless persuit for perfection. The only question is : How much time will it take us to fully accept that fact and how long are we to make the intervening steps of understanding and acceptance:<br />days,<br />years,<br />millenia?<br />It is hard for us to imagine or accept from our point of view, a more different world but it is only a question of relativity.<br />If and only if EVERY AND EACH human being on this planet is fully develloped socially through knowledge and education so that we have no need for corrolary systems like:<br /><br /><br />* Money<br />Religion<br />Law<br />Law Enforcement<br /><br /><br />*These 4 concepts will only exist in history books.<br /><br /><br />The only motivation needed for a fully developed person to act is the eagerness to participate in an environment that is truthful, fair, exiting and willing to share all its physical, spiritual and intellectual riches. Social and cultural evolutions are intrinsically linked to their environment. All three are depndent on each other and develop accordingly, to a certain extent they react automatically.<br />If corrective systems are allowed to exist for too long, they become the norm and they grow and develop themselves and with beings as sophisticated, sensitive and social as human beings, they bring around the problem of invisible social barriers and intellectual barriers like political division and money division.<br /><br />If a well developed colony of ants or bees who had reached the peak of their development were to be put in the same predicament, they would soon find themselves in our same situation> at odds with each other.<br />As long as we hold on to our knowledge vacuums where some members of our societies remain undeveloped, socialy we will not be free.<br />We will remain slaves to our inability of seeing beyond the next curve.<br /><br />The only way out is to lift up from ignorance every single child alive, everywhere in this planet.<br /><br />The answer is : Knowledge through education. So we do not have to deal with the corrective systems.<br /><br />No money.<br />No religion. ( Spirituality, Yes)<br />No Laws.<br /><br />No need for any of them. If every single one of us is illuminated inside by knowledge.

title: "Toilet Humor"
author: FrozenMonkee
post_content: <span style="font-size:85%;"><span style="font-family:arial;"><strong>Begin burst transmission...</strong><br /><br />"Geez...What luck. The janitor finally comes in, scrubs all the blood out of my basin from when that asshole sprayed his bloody urine all over me, and he gives me a brand spanking, never-been-pissed-on, perfectly circular vanilla-scented urinal cake. And guess what. No more than 22 hours later, I'm baptised in diseased blood all over again...except this guy looked a little worse. He comes stumbling in, muttering something about "those God-Damned Monkees", and starts running in circles, with blood pouring out of every visible orfice. This guy was cuckoo...Or a cokehead. I kind of felt sorry for him...At least until he stuck his head in me and dripped his crimson sweat all over my FRESHLY WASHED PORCELAIN, THANK you very much! However, if I understood him correctly, his spinal column had dislodged itself and was slowly inching out of his ass. That can't be comfortable...God I almost feel sorry for him again....Almost. Oh well things could be worse, I guess. See that toilet in Desparado? Yeah, things could be worse...But why couldn't I have been accidentally installed in the Ladies' room? Is that too much to ask? I'm growing tired of gazing at old, uncircumsised men and their unproportionate, not-very-circular testicles. I want women...Oh well. I still smell the vanilla. That's got to count for something." -from <em>The Book of Shapes</em><br /><br /><strong>--end transmission...</strong> </span></span>

title: The Internet: What Lies Ahead?
author: Jungian
post_content: In the early days of the internet, social networking, where real exchange, sharing and communication between people took place was limited to newsgroups and email.<br /><br />Now the internet has taken on a whole new evolution. I like to call it “people power”. What used to be called consumers have become the Internet producers. It stared with message boards, went on to P2P, online gaming, photo sharing and finally nuevo journalism or blogging. It gives social networking a whole new direction. The act of sharing be it their day, thoughts, opinions or photos, these new producers are dictating where the Internet begins and ends. The new producers of content will inevitably take over from mainstream media.<br /><br />In the process of sharing is where a gateway to the future of the internet was revealed. When each person began to reveal their truths and realized that there are more similarities between people than there are differences. This awareness has created a power stream and thus a shift in the collective consciousness. A new form of thought leadership is bound to emerge from this. But unlike the lone figure standing on a pedestal speaking for his people, this it will be the collective voice of all humanity. And the microphone thru which they speak will be the INTERNET.<br /><br />That can never be a bad thing. Because for once decisions will be made collectively. In the process of doing so, the connection the internet provides will show that ultimately we want the same things.These communities are already talking and the power brokers are listening. With this change, it begs the question, what will the Internet become?<br /><br />The internet will become the channel and the reference point for every new invention. It will become an ecosystem that states what we want, what we need, and how we need it. The way businesses deal with this will be the challenge. Because previously, an invention was made and marketed and only after getting feedback was it improved upon (Microsoft is a good example) and then it went on to be called innovation. This time around, the winning invention is the one that was commissioned by the producers of the internet. Not literary commissioned, but as natural progression that comes when millions of people around the globe share their views, thoughts and opinions about what stays and what goes.<br /><br />It will not only shape the economics and politics of the world but lift the collective consciousness of humanity to level never before experienced. With blogging and other forms social networking, there is now a source where almost every human mind is plugged into. This source is an invaluable tool that will make a difference whether we like it or not.

post_content: <div align="right">شاگردی از استادش پرسيد: عشق چيست؟استاد در جواب گفت: به گندمزار برو و پر خوشه ترين شاخه را بياور. اما در هنگام عبور از گندم زار به ياد داشته باش که نمی توانی به عقب برگردی تا خوشه ای بچينی!شاگرد به گندمزار رفت و پس از مدتی طولانی برگشت. استاد پرسيد: چه آوردی؟ و شاگرد با حسرت جواب داد: هيچ! هرچه جلو ميرفتم خوشه های پر پشت تر ميديدم و به اميد پيدا کردن پر پشت ترين تا انتهای گندمزار رفتم. استاد جواب داد: عشق يعنی همين!شاگرد پرسيد: پس ازدواج چيست؟استاد به سخن آمد که: به جنگل برو و بلندترين درخت را بياور. اما به ياد داشته باش که باز هم نمی توانی به عقب برگردی!شاگرد رفت و پس از مدت کوتاهی با درختی برگشت. استاد پرسيد که شاگرد را چه شدو او در جواب گفت: به جنگل رفتم و اولين درخت بلندی را که ديدم انتخاب کردم. ترسيدم که اگر جلو بروم باز دست خالی برگردم.استاد باز گفت: ازدواج يعنی همين!! </div>

title: Meu mundo
author: paulinha
post_content: <div style="text-align: justify;">É seguro dizer que eu nunca deixei de pensar em você. A verdade é que nunca houve um dia, desde que eu te conheci, em que isso não ocorresse.&nbsp;<span style="background-color: white;">Não seria diferente depois que você tivesse partido.&nbsp;</span></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><span style="background-color: white;"><br /></span></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Quando algo assim acontece, por muito tempo as lembranças nos assombram. E mesmo as melhores, as mais felizes são extremamente dolorosas.&nbsp;<span style="background-color: white;">Exatamente por isso, coloquei você em um cantinho escuro da minha mente.&nbsp;</span><span style="background-color: white;">C</span><span style="background-color: white;">redito tal atitude ao meu instinto de sobrevivência.&nbsp;</span><span style="background-color: white;">Foi um período extremamente confuso.&nbsp;</span></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">O que, no fundo, eu não gostaria de admitir era que você havia se tornado uma parte da minha história. E o que somos nós, senão o produto de nossa história? Logo, você também virou um coeficiente da minha equação e ao apagar você, eu estava simplesmente apagando parte de mim. E como eu poderia desejar ser inteira?<br /><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><span style="background-color: white;">Fui eu quem te disse que o amor é capaz de superar tudo, até mesmo a morte. Pro seu mundo exato, tanta subjetividade era extremamente inquietante. E você preferia dizer que eu era ingênua, uma romântica e dava muita importância ao que dizia meu coração, quando, à seu modo, você era tão mais romântico que eu.</span></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><span style="background-color: white;"><br /></span></div><div style="text-align: justify;"></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Hoje, com mais convicção que antes, volto a repetir: o amor, meu querido, vence tudo. Sobrevive até às corrosões do tempo. Intacto. Move, inclusive, montanhas de orgulho, em não querer dar a você a sua devida importância por simples medo de sofrer.</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Se eu pudesse te encontrar agora, eu diria simplesmente que eu o amo, com a mesma certeza que sempre tivemos que seria pra sempre.<br /><br />Diria então pra você ir sem medo, que poderia seguir o caminho que Deus desenhou pra você, ainda que isso significasse nunca mais nos ver. Porque, da mesma forma que estar perto não é o mesmo quer estar junto. Estar longe, não é o mesmo que estar separado.</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">E se eu pudesse, enfim, redizer o que eu te disse na última vez em que te vi, desejaria simplesmente que você seja, sempre, imensamente feliz e que mesmo quando tudo parecer impossível, nada tema, pois o amor é capaz de tudo, de nos resgatar dos mais profundos abismos, de renovar nossas forças quando tudo parece acabado, de nos elevar aos céus.&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><i>"O Amor é paciente, é benigno; o Amor não é invejoso, não trata com leviandade, não se ensoberbece, não se porta com indecência, não busca os seus interesses, não se irrita, não suspeita mal, não folga com a injustiça, mas folga com a verdade. Tudo tolera, tudo crê, tudo espera e tudo suporta. O Amor nunca falha."</i></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Por isso, de todas as atribulações, de quaisquer mundos, asseguro-te: você há sempre de encontrar abrigo na certeza de que não há nada mais fortificante, nem renovador do que a pureza do amor verdadeiro e a paz que ele nos traz.<br /><br />Que assim seja.</div>

title: #1 - Às vezes...
author: paulinha
post_content: <div style="text-align: justify;">Hoje, quando me levantei às 6h30 da manhã, com uma disposição anormal para o horário, devo confessar, não sabia o dia que me esperava pela frente.&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Comecei a preparar meu café da manhã, fiz minha maquiagem (o dia já começa divertido), escolhi um vestido preto simples, um sapato de oncinha porque... né? É preciso quebrar a formalidade excessiva dos vestuários executivos. Me dirigi ao cartório.&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Encontrei minha prima-vó e é sempre um prazer revê-la. A mocinha que me atendeu não parava de digitar ao celular, os clientes contrariandos depois de pagar tantas taxas para concluir o inventário, mas pessoas seguraram a porta e responderam ao meu dia, então eu estava feliz.&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Depois de 2 meses,&nbsp;finalizei o inventário extrajudicial (que civilizado!) e tive que esperar 2 horas além do previsto.&nbsp;Alguns coisas que não posso comentar publicamente, me deixaram bem chateada. Foi tão desanimador que a energia pareceu se esvair de mim. Cheguei na academia e não consegui treinar pelo horário, já estava tarde. Ok, acho que foi melhor, eu estava muito cansada dessa semana.&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Resolvi ir ao banco ajudar minha tia com alguns problemas. A agência estava abarrotada. Pegamos telefones de dois gerentes e fomos embora. Cheguei na casa de minha avó, onde almoço todos os dias. Tive que acalmar a pobrezinha porque um oficial de justiça falou ou ela entendeu errado sobre um processo recém setenciado, então me dediquei alguns minutos a acalmá-la.&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Sei lá, eu estava me sentindo extremamente cansada. Não sei explicar. Felizmente, como a&nbsp;cidade já estava em clima de feriadão, aproveitei o embalo e tirei um belo cochilo durante a tarde. Fui para a estética tentar fazer corrente russa, mas acho que como a energia estava muito bizarra, nem isso deu certo. Enfim. Conversei com meus tios e minha mãe, problemas, problemas, problemas. A sexta-feira parecia maldita.&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Em pouco, umas velhas amigas começaram a chegar para fazer aula. Batemos papo, fizemos uma aula de Body Jump bizarra. Tenho impressão que essas aulas ajudam a nos aproximar, você sabe... situações de sofrimento intenso aproximam as pessoas. Como estava sem carro, peguei uma carona com uma amiga que estudou comigo no primeiro ano da faculdade! E estamos com vários planos em comum, inclusive, estamos estudando Francês! Quem sabe não seremos colegas de Mestrado na França?!&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Por essas amizades, que apesar do tempo em que passamos longe, nunca esmorecem, sou extremamente grata. Por essas pessoas com objetivos e sonhos em comum, que aparecem nos momentos em que você mais precisa de um empurrão, sou mais grata ainda! :)</div>

title: Por que amo Fernando Pessoa.
author: paulinha
post_content: <div style="text-align: justify;">Eu sei que todos temos instintos e impulsos. Sei que muitas vezes são eles que determinam como agimos, mas... quando eu escuto que somos feitos de medos intrínsecos e parâmetros culturais inconscientes... eu acho tão esquisito!</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Posso explicar: se há uma coisa que julgo importante. A mais. Troquem tudo por ele: o autoconhecimento. O autoconhecimento é o código para desvendar todo o mapa da sua pessoa. E é a melhor coisa que você pode fazer por você mesmo.</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Quando você começar a agir contra os seus valores, uma luzinha vermelha vai piscar loucamente na sua mente te dizendo: "Ei, cara. Por que você está agindo assim?". E naquele momento, você vai se perguntar: "É... por quê?". E talvez você descubra que não há absolutamente nenhuma razão para agir daquela maneira. E vai simplesmente parar. </div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Temos instintos, impulsos e parâmetros inconscientes? Sim, mas não somos isso. Não somos definidos por eles, assim como não somos definidos pelo medo.  Nenhum deles é tão poderoso quanto parece. Só não é difícil enganar alguém que não tem fé em si mesmo. Somos capazes de perceber e discernir. E não é por acaso.</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Todos nós temos nossos demônios. E precisamos enfrentá-los. É trabalhoso, mas quer saber? Há algo especial em viver sabendo que você é capaz de qualquer coisa, de superar qualquer adversidade ou de lidar com as situações mais inimagináveis.</div><div style="text-align: justify;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify;">Há algo muito especial em ser invencível. E quando derrotamos os nossos demônios, é exatamente isso que nos tornamos. </div>

title: GOOD ENOUGH
author: Christiaan
post_content: <a onblur="try {parent.deselectBloggerImageGracefully();} catch(e) {}" href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/_jF35zbc06JY/Sb7FrE6KgcI/AAAAAAAAAHc/zpcgjeB9ulo/s1600-h/explosion.jpg"><img style="float:left; margin:0 10px 10px 0;cursor:pointer; cursor:hand;width: 400px; height: 320px;" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/_jF35zbc06JY/Sb7FrE6KgcI/AAAAAAAAAHc/zpcgjeB9ulo/s400/explosion.jpg" border="0" alt=""id="BLOGGER_PHOTO_ID_5313901954186510786" /></a><br />São Francisco - Americana processa Apple e pede US$ 225 mil em indenização pela explosão do tocador dentro da calça do filho de 15 anos. Uma mulher de Ohio, Estados Unidos, entrou com um processo contra a Apple na semana passada, alegando que o iPod Touch de seu filho explodiu, causando queimaduras. Por conta disso, ela pede 225 mil dólares de indenização pelos danos. Na ação, ela explica que o iPod Touch de 16 GB de seu filho de 15 anos estava no bolso da calça, durante uma aula. De repente, o garoto teria ouvido “o barulho de um estouro e imediatamente sentiu uma sensação de queimadura em sua perna”. Foi então, segundo o documento, que ele percebeu que “o equipamento estava em chamas”.

title: SHOWS EM ANDAMENTO
author: Christiaan
post_content: - Carmanguia está dando um tempo já q todos os integrantes andam ocupadíssimos.<br /><br />- Em Dezembro/04 gravei um DVD com o Moska q ainda não foi mixado. Tocamos eu, o Dunga, Sacha Ambak e Ramiro Mussoto. O DVD teve participação do Jorge Drexler e o grupo de percussão infantil Bate Lata.<br /><br />- Em Janeiro toquei num show alternativo da Zélia Duncan cantando coisas q ela gosta de ouvir em casa no Bourbon Street, São Paulo.<br /><br />- Também em Janeiro finalizei a produção do disco de estréia da Cecília Spyer ainda sem nome q ficou muito interessante. Cecília fez belas composições pro disco, entre elas, uma parceria com o Dadi e outra com Alvin L.<br /><br />- Esta semana irei masterizar o novo disco do Línox q irá se chamar “Positivo”. Participaram da gravação: Max e João Vianna, Marcelo Mariano, Dunga, Billy Brandão, Eduardo Souto Neto, Lui Coimbra, mais os músico q tocam na ótima banda do Línox. No repertório, uma versão da canção “Flake” de Jack Johnson (“Foco”).<br /><br />- Daqui a uma semana começo a produção do novo disco da Zélia Duncan com lindas parcerias dela com o Lenine, Moska, Itamar Assumpção e minhas é claro! Vamos gravar e mixar o disco na Toca do Bandido com o técnico Álvaro Alencar.

title: ELVIN JONES
author: Christiaan
post_content: O meu novo quarteto instrumental está soando muito bem. Estamos tentando criar algo diferente do q se entende por música instrumental aqui no Rio. Em São Paulo não existe esse problema. Lá existe uma cena alternativa muito criativa com a música instrumental. Lembro uma noite depois de um show q toquei com o Lulu Santos no Palace (agora é Garden Hall, ou Credicard Hall ou alguma porra de Hall!!), saí com alguns amigos pra tomar um choppe e fomos pra algum barzinho inócuo. Inócuo?? Pó, lá tava rolando o maior som com uma formação totalmente original. Um Sax tenor, uma trompa, um trombone, baixo acústico, piano e vibrafone! Nossa, estava soando lindo!! Quando é q se vê algo assim no Rio? Aqui vc vai negociar com alguma casa noturna e nego já vem falando sobre cheque caução. What?? Negociei então com uma casa relativamente nova q fica na Lagoa. Partitura é o nome. Lá espero criar uma relação de parceria com a casa. Pedi logo q me dessem um mês, deixando o meu 4teto tocar toda quarta-feira pra gente poder criar um bochicho. Música instrumental onde se ouve Beatles, James Brown, Led Zeppelin, Egberto Gismonti, John Scofield, The Meters e composições próprias. Acho q vai dar pé. Nossa temporada começa em Junho. Está começando a soar direito. Temos uma combinação interessante: um negro, um nordestino, um carioca e um holandês/uruguaio/carioca. Sempre curti música instrumental com um conceito sonoro. Um som ao mesmo tempo ensaiado porém livre para a criação espontânea. Weather Report, o famoso quinteto de Miles, Medeski/Martin e Wood, a parede sonora de John Coltrane (ahhh Elvin Jones, que maravilha!!!!!!). Sei q estou sendo ambicioso, mas não custa nada tentar, né?

title: BLOG NOVO, VIDA NOVA
author: Christiaan
post_content: Quem visita meu site deve ficar um pouco intrigado com o conteúdo. Existe um coerência entre os assuntos no q diz respeito à minha profissão. Tem a página de composição, outra como baterista, como produtor musical, outra pra minha nova paixão q são os violões de colo havaianos, e aí surge meio isolada um página de Aikido. Uma luta!! Os q tem aversão à luta ou violência devem ficar enojados por desconhecerem o q o Aikido realmente se propõe a trabalhar. Por outro lado, os amantes da pancadaria devem ficar achando, “ih, tinha q ser um músico pra fazer uma luta não competitiva”. Ontem mesmo fazendo uma busca na Web sobre o Aikido no Brasil me deparei com um “post” q alguém tinha colocado num site alegando q “o Aikido é uma luta boba,  coreografada, sem sentido e imprestável para a defesa pessoal”.  O Aikido é uma arte marcial. Acreditem. Não é uma prática bonitinha pra todo mundo se harmonizar e comer arroz integral olhando o pôr do sol! Se vc estiver procurando por técnicas de defesa pessoal pra machucar alguém e controlar UMA PESSOA, sugiro a prática do Jiu-Jitsu ou Vale Tudo ou até mesmo o Box tradicional. Agora vamos parar um segundo pra pensar. Não é muito melhor evitar uma briga do q levá-la às últimas consequencias? Não é muito mais importante vencer sem haver derramamento de sangue. Não seria melhor treinar uma arte onde vc desenvolve o sexto sentido, lutando contra TRES OU MAIS PESSOAS?? O Aikido tem tudo à ver com a minha música: é para unir e não segregar, é para sentir e não intelectualizar e é para trabalhar a agressividade sem machucar. Alguns anos atrás joguei fora alguns prêmios q tinha recebido ao longo da minha carreira como músico, arranjador e produtor. Uns troféus ridículos q me irritavam toda vez q os via na estante. Melhor instrumentista: Christiaan Oyens. Melhor fascista: George W. Bush. Que saco!! Foi tudo pro lixo! Não me agrada a idéia de estimular a competição numa disciplina espiritual como a música. Às pessoas q inventam estes prêmios não estão entendendo! E qual é a única arte marcial q não permite competições? O Aikido!

title: NOVAS...
author: Christiaan
post_content: Toda semana recebo CDs de artistas procurando um lugar ao sol. Compositores, cantoras, interpretes e instrumentistas procurando se firmarem num mercado cada vez mais escasso e desiludido. Ouço tudo q me mandam e procuro sempre responder com sinceridade e incentivo porque quase todo o material q recebo tem potencial. Só fico irritado quando vejo q o trabalho foi feito pra ser “comercial”, ou quando o release q acompanha o disco fala em um trabalho “comercial”. Que chatice!! Música não se presta a esse fim. Por isso é q as grandes gravadoras estão agonizando, por causa dessas formulas cretinas que pessoas incompetentes, pessoas q não entendem bolhufas de música, criam. Não estou aqui dizendo q todo mundo q trabalha dentro de uma gravadora é incompetente. De jeito nenhum. Conheço muita gente boa, bacana, inteligente e com muita sensibilidade musical trabalhando nas multinacionais. O inimigo número 1 da música (e arte em geral) é a ganância. Um trabalho musical para ser bem sucedido tem q vender, tem q ter aceitação. Agora daí pra sair copiando uma coisa tentando fazer outra parecida só pra capitalizar, isso é cretino. Lembram da época q apareceu o Padre Marcelo Rossi?  Ele chegou a vender mais de 2 milhões de discos! Naquela época eu estava me reunindo com diretores de gravadoras, pra mostrar o trabalho de uma cantora/compositora q eu estava produzindo. Meu, parecia q eu estava falando pras paredes! Perguntei a um deles o q estava acontecendo. “Ora, precisamos urgente de um Padre”! Quer dizer então q aquilo não se tratava de uma ideia original de um pessoa atendendo seus fieis e obtendo seu merecido sucesso?? Qualquer Padre bastaria? Esta história é apenas um exemplo do q a ganância pode gerar numa empresa ou num mercado: estupidez, paranóia e sucessivos equívocos além de levar tudo e todos para um infindável abismo “comercial”. Ah sim, a cantora q mencionei, nunca consegui seu contrato.

title: Roses
author: Manish
post_content: From WSJ Posting  - 11/18<br /><br />The total package. Almonds, honey, orange blossoms and earth. Luscious, with oranges, almonds and stewed peaches, but not at all heavy. Very smooth, with a lemon-meringue finish.<br /><br />Golden and green-tinged. A nose of nectar -- pears, apples, orange blossoms and peaches -- and roasted mixed nuts: walnuts, almonds, pistachios. Mouth-coating, with ripe apricots, great acids and egg-white fluffiness on the long, clean finish. Surprisingly light on its feet.<br />[nowides] OUR FAVORITES<br /> <br />[Tastings]<br />In a tasting of Sauternes from the excellent 2001 vintage, these were our favorites.<br /><br />Sigh. Wait, where were we? Oh, here: Every year around this time, we're asked something like this: "I'd like to get a bottle of wine for a friend who's really into wine, but he already buys good stuff by the case, so what could I possibly give him?" This year, here's the answer: a bottle of Sauternes from the well-regarded 2001 vintage, which is just arriving in stores now. This is a gift that will show research and good taste, and it's truly one that will keep on giving for many years, but we'll get back to that.<br /><br />There is no sweeter gift than Sauternes, and we mean that literally. Sauternes, from the Bordeaux region of France, is the world's greatest sweet wine. (The name, sometimes spelled Sauterne, was appropriated by some American wineries for sweet, simple wines, but they're unrelated.) It is made from grapes -- Semillon and Sauvignon Blanc, sometimes along with Muscadelle -- that have been allowed to remain on the vine in misty conditions until they are attacked by botrytis cinerea, the famous "noble rot" that shrivels the grapes and concentrates the juice into a rare and remarkable nectar.<br /><br />Leaving the grapes on the vine until they are attacked by mold is obviously risky -- in fact, some Sauternes producers don't make any wine at all in troubled years. And harvesting those grapes and making this wine is labor-intensive and expensive. So these wines should cost a fortune, but, on the whole, they don't, we're happy to say, because sweet wines generally aren't in vogue.<br /><br />Genuinely Exciting<br /><br />But here's the thing: True wine lovers know the real value of Sauternes, and that's why this is such a great present. While many of the world's sweet wines are flabby sugar bombs, Sauternes is not. Think about the ripest, freshest, juiciest piece of fruit you've ever tasted. Sure, it was sweet, but the primary taste was fruit, not sugar, and the sweet tastes were probably balanced with some tartness and good acidity. That's the wonder of Sauternes. Its abundant acids, great earthiness and ripe fruit taste like juicy, fresh-from-the-tree-or-vine fruit, not like sugar. In a good Sauternes, the smell itself is both sweet and nicely acidic, making it mouth-watering even before it's sipped. At their best, these wines are genuinely exciting.<br /><br />Did we say earthiness? Heaven knows this is hard to explain, but in the very best Sauternes -- and especially the famous Chateau d'Yquem, the greatest Sauternes -- we sometimes feel as though we're drinking nectar that's been filtered through rich earth. It's that elemental -- and unique.<br /><br />The 2001 Yquem, which has been widely praised, hasn't yet been released. (It might be available for Christmas, at $400 a bottle or more.) But many other Sauternes from 2001 have hit the shelves, so we figured we'd pick up enough for a large tasting to see how they are. We set no price limit, so we ultimately spent up to $129.95, though most of the wines were less than $50. We bought wines labeled Sauternes and labeled Barsac, which is one of the villages of Sauternes and is allowed to use its own name. The wines of Barsac are generally considered somewhat lighter and perhaps a little more elegant than many wines labeled simply Sauternes.<br /><br />We are sometimes told that fine French wines aren't available in California -- can you imagine? -- so we made a point of buying most of the wines for this tasting there. We tasted the wines blind in flights over several nights, and we're here to tell you: These are delicious, memorable wines. Wine after wine offered a luscious nose of orange blossoms and brioche, a rich taste of fruit, earth and nuts, and a lingering finish of sweet, ripe fruit that sometimes left us at a loss for words. Or perhaps we just didn't want to speak and risk losing the state of mind that the taste had induced.<br /><br />Golden Tastes<br /><br />During the tasting, John asked Dottie how we could describe Sauternes that might convince a sweet-resistant wine drinker to give it a try. Dottie thought for a moment and replied: "It's like the sun. There's a gleaming richness to it. It tastes golden. It's smooth, with a sweetness that bursts in your mouth and then surprises you with such a clean, bracing finish." As we said, sigh.<br /><br />We ultimately couldn't pick just one wine for our best of tasting. Two wines, both of which we rated Delicious, qualified for the top spot: Chateau de Malle, the wine we described above as "the total package," and the other one above, Chateau Nairac from Barsac, which had the fluffy finish, something you will just have to experience to fully understand.<br /><br />But this is important: These wines won't be at their best for many years. In fact, our advice for new parents who want to lay down wine for their child is always Sauternes because it ages so well for so long. Not only that -- and, for your present, this is particularly important -- but the wine gets more and more beautiful to look at as it ages. Even in youth, Sauternes is beautiful in its clear bottle -- golden, sometimes with green highlights. With each year, the wine gets even more stunning, with its gold becoming dark and richer-looking. Long before the bottle is open, it has already given such joy. So this holiday season, give your friend a bottle of 2001 Sauternes, but be sure to write something like this on the label: "Happy holidays 2005. May your life, like this wine, get better every year."

title: Ireland is calling!
author: Cheryl
post_content: In yesterday's Omaha World Herald there was an article that regarding how the news people take one story and repeat it over and over again. I couldn't agree with them more. Anymore it seems as if the same story runs day after day after day. How many times or how long do we really want to hear about Charles and Camilla's wedding, what she wore, that the Queen shunned her sons wedding, etc...... Do we really have that little in life to focus on that we have to keep reliving the same story day after day?  I think that the journalists could be a bit more creative in their stories.  It ends up being like a never ending novel!

title: Shoe Buying
author: Cheryl
post_content: Our church is having a book sale.  The books that are being sold have been donated by our congregations members.  Last night we were browsing through some of the books for sale and I started to wonder why folks would give away some of the books that were there, i.e. Little Golden Books, Curious George, recent Oprah Book Club books.  We are avid readers in our family, each one of us normally having at least one if not two books going at the same time.  To say that we get restless if we don't have something to read is an understatment.  But, our problem is, and it is evident by the scads of boxes that we have, we just can't give books away.  My husband and I still have several of our college textbooks left- although they are probably out of date, but the human body doesn't change that much so an Anatomy and Physiology book is still in vogue. To us, they are a precious comodity.  Who knows when you might want to read it again, or share it with a friend, or start a book club!  So, as you can see I have a difficult time understanding why someone would want to get rid of their books! But, then again I started thinking--- if it weren't for those folks that want to get rid of their books, I might not have anything to buy on Saturday for a cheap price.  So thanks to all of you that donated to our book sale for filling my already overfilled shelves here at home!!!  You guys rock!

title: Where does the time go to?
author: Cheryl
post_content: Good Morning America ran a story this morning about folks with spinal cord injuries being able to experience activities they normally would not be able to participate in.  Thanks to an organization called "Life Challenges" it allows these folks to find freedom from their wheelchairs and the restrictions they face because of their disability!  How awesome it was to watch them on T.V. experiencing sky diving from 13,000 feet and having the time of their life.  It isn't about being disabled, but being able and all about living life to the fullest!  Personally I think anyone that sky dives is pretty brave, and so my hat is off to these very special brave sky divers and cudo's to "Life Challenges" for providing such an awesome opportunity to them.

title: New Longer Rant/Rave Up
author: CRAIG
post_content: Emerging from Atlanta in the mid '90s, the Rap duo known as OutKast released a handful of genre-bending CDs before hitting it "big" with the release of <em>Stankonia</em> in late 2000.<a name='more'></a><br /><br />Their long-awaited follow-up, the double CD <em>Speakerboxxx/The Love Belo</em>w, was released in the fall of 2003 and was an instant hit thanks mostly to the song "Hey Ya!." The collection plays less like a double set though, and more like two solo releases (although the duo both contribute to each CD), packaged together and featuring the name OutKast. <em></em><br /><em></em> <br /><em>Speakerboxxx, </em>Big Boi's contribution is, dare I say, the least adventurous of the two. It contains hyper-kinetic rap, hip-hop, R and B and is most notable for the hit "I like the Way You Move."<br /><br /><em>The Love Below, </em>Andre 3000's collection contains 20 tracks that for the most part are impossible to label. A mixture of rap, R and B, rock, jazz and other contemporary styles, <em>The Love </em>Below is a gutsy release from the duo that has, for the most part, appealed to the rap crowd. "Hey Ya," changed all of that. So did the follow up single, "Roses." OutKast became a household name and reached heights few artists will ever see.<br /><br />Although <em>The Love Below</em> contains many lasting tracks, the most memorable is "Take Off Your Cool," a simple two and a half minute long duet between Andre and Norah Jones. Driven by a sole acoustic guitar (although bits of keyboard pop up in the background), the song sets the mood quickly with a series of open chords lazily strummed by Andre while the duo playfully scat. Jones' vocal after the intro is sultry and inviting. It's also repetitive. The song has few lyrics yet never seems lacking.<br /><br />The song's beauty is its simplicity. And I really can't say it any simpler than that. <br /><br /><iframe style="width:120px;height:240px;" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" src="//ws-na.amazon-adsystem.com/widgets/q?ServiceVersion=20070822&OneJS=1&Operation=GetAdHtml&MarketPlace=US&source=ac&ref=tf_til&ad_type=product_link&tracking_id=alwthelasinli-20&marketplace=amazon&region=US&placement=B001416PMG&asins=B001416PMG&linkId=IXVF5QNM6VOOM7OX&show_border=true&link_opens_in_new_window=true"></iframe>

title: Snow baby
author: Unknown
post_content: Hi Everyone,<br /><br />Greg and I headed to Palo Alto on Sunday to watch the 2008 Amgen Tour, which is a bike race throughout California.  The race started about 2 blocks from my work, so we thought it would be cool to see the streets shut down and the spectators all around.  The weather was great and we had free parking at my office, so why not check it out??<br /><br />My boss Brendan is really into biking, so he took these photos.  He was in a VIP tent (cuz he's that cool), so we didn't get to talk to him... but you'll see that Greg and I did say hello.<br /><br />I don't know who any of the riders are, but it was nice to stroll the streets of PA and Stanford University.<br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><a href="http://bp2.blogger.com/_wCtex9PWf-U/R7tsCiJrelI/AAAAAAAABtc/naDYJrLcEDA/s1600-h/DSC_0140.jpg"><img style="float:left; title: happens all the time
author: lindsey gail
post_content: I almost wrote a post about board games.  Why?  Because I wanted to write about something happy.  I want to be silly and childish.  I just spent the afternoon with smug marrieds and I want to ignore the woman in me that secretly wants to be a smug married too.  I mean really, I have it much better because I don't have to lay in bed with a snoring lout, I don't have to pretend to be courteous when I want to be rude, I don't have to kiss morning scruff, I don't have to bat my eyes and say yes I want to be fat, have my boobs saggy and drippy while my lungs get squished, my stomache gets kicked, and I'm stirring a pot of macaroni over a dirty stove.  I don't have to know what being in love feels like...  I make myself crazy and miserable enough as it is, thank you very much.

title: Follow-Up to Rolling Hills
author: Kathryn
post_content: It seems that everywhere in today's world we are faced with situations that have to be dealt with morally and ethically.  Simple positions, without  responsibility still require moral decisions.  Even As a bartender w are faced with these types of decisions.  We are told that we can not accept gifts or extensive tips from our customers, yet everyday I see my fellow cast members leaving with flowers and stuffed animals.  That certainly isn't a personal jet used for a lavish vacation, but are we looking at the future person who will abuse power given it?  And how do we positively influence these people?  Is their even hope?  They know what is right and what is wrong, yet they continue to work for their own self interest.  People in society constantly amaze me.  We give power to CEO's and they continue to use their influence and power on board members and others to get what they want.  How can we fix this?  We know what is right and wrong.  We have outlines and definitions of the morals in health care and the conflicts of interest.  We need to avoid hiring people who may put their own interest before that of the company.  But how do we identify these people?  Anyone can get through an interview with all the right answers given the proper research. I guess all we can do is limit power until we gain trust and positively influence others in our work place.

title: When you are in distress, do something different...
author: Zodiachus
post_content: I am still crying damn it, and it's an hour since you left. It's crazy, I haven't cried this much since... I never had I think.<br /><br />But it's not the kinda tearing apart self-pity crying, and it's not the crying that comes with a big black hole like when you have lost someone. It's the kind of crying that's like a big exclamation mark after the wonderful summer we've had together.<br /><br />I missed you when we were apart for two hours, and the weekend you were in Örebro was relatively easy to cope with because there came a monday after that weekend. This is bigger and I don't know what to do with myself.<br /><br />I've rolled up my sleeves, and the orange is waiting for me. I've also made a thermos of the tea that you bought in the beginning of the summer (chocolate and... whiskey?)<br /><br />When the train left I couldn't contain myself anymore. I had to go sit down, because standing up wasn't a good idea at that point.<br /><br />Later when I was waiting for the bus, I saw the sunrise, and god was it ever beautiful. It was like a big shining smile rising over the horizon. At that moment it felt like someone reassuring me, like it was communicating that all will be fine. It feels a little presumptuous to assume that we would have a sunrise dedicated to us, and nevertheless I feel that that was exactly what it was.<br /><br />Dangit! I'm still crying and it's making it damn hard to see what I type!<br /><br />Ooooooooh GOD I am looking forward to seeing you next time.<br /><br />I wish you well on your Dublin adventures, love. Remember that I believe in you. You're the best. Forever and ever. Amen.

title: Outbursts!
author: Zodiachus
post_content: He was laughing. It was a hearty belly-laughter. I smiled, because his joy rubbed off on me. We were standing at a crossroads. The landscape around us was open and the air was dry. At a distance the forest shot up from the ground like a green wall. The two roads were leading into the woods, one to the east and one to the north.<br /><br />Now he was smiling at me, red hair glowing in the setting sun.<br />"Well that is an easy question, my friend."<br />"Tell me the answer then", I exclaimed, delighted that there was a solution to our problem.<br />"Not so fast", he said. "I will guide you, but I won't tell you what to do. Now what would be the purpose of that?"<br /><br />Him and his games. If anything can be turned into a lesson or a game, be sure that he will do it. I took a drink of water from a bottle we had brought. <br /><br />"Sooo...", he said, the smile broadening. "What shall we do?"<br />I shrugged. I didn't know - that's why I asked him in the first place.<br />"Begin at the beginning", he suggested.<br /><br />I must have had a pained expression on my face, because he laughed again. <br />"Come on - try!"<br />"Alright. We began... At home", I said.<br />"Good. And then?"<br />"We got on the bus. And then the train."<br />"Continue", he encouraged me.<br />"A couple of hours later we got off the train, asked for directions and began to walk. The road down by the hotel and later the dirt road through the forest. We passed a couple of farms and a place where someone kept bees. Then we walked for another twenty minutes or so, and now we are here."<br />"Great!", he said as if that cleared everything up.<br /><br />"So I know how all this began", I said. "How is that going to help?"<br />"Think for a minute. How come you know all this?"<br />"Know what?"<br />"How we got here!"<br /><br />I was tempted to sit down and just forget everything for a while. He knew what I was thinking and started walking towards a cliff by the road. After a few seconds I followed him. He sat down on the cliff. I sat down and stretched out on the smooth surface. The sunset turned the sky red above the dark green silhouette of the trees. I don't know for how long we sat in silence.<br /><br />"I know how we got here because we have already done it", I said under my breath. He heard me.<br />"Good", he said as if had known exactly when I was going to speak. He turned his head and his blue eyes looked into mine. "So how will we choose path?"<br />"By analyzing the past and try to draw knowledge from that? How are we going to do that? We have never been here before."<br />"No, no, no!" He shook his head. "If you did everything like you did it in the past you will end up where you began. Is that your goal?"<br /><br />Surprisingly, the question didn't seem rhetorical. I knew that if I said yes, he would instantly change his course and help me get back.<br />"No. We agreed that would travel there, didn't we?" I looked at him. "Didn't we?", I asked again.<br />"So we did, my friend. But then you see that we cannot let the past decide where we go. That would only lend us the same experience over and over."<br /><br />I thought. Then what was the point of making me think of the past? Riddles! Would that he at least once could tell me something without these riddles!<br /><br />"We didn't know the journey before we began, but now we do."<br />"Both right and wrong", he said.<br />"What? What was right and what was wrong?"<br />He leaned back.<br />"You are right, in the sense that we didn't know the experience of the journey before we began. We didn't know how the seat of that particular train would feel, or exactly who would sell us the ticket. We didn't experience the beauty of this sunset beforehand.<br />    But wrong, in the sense that we did indeed know the journey." <br />"What, you mean that we planned to travel?"<br />"Perhaps. What was in your mind when you decided to go on this journey?"<br />He leaned forward and looked me in the eyes.<br />"Think back. Wasn't the journey there?"<br />"Oh I see! Yeah, kind of. But like an idea. Nothing as tangible as the experience of it."<br />"But when you stood there in the beginning, where did the journey exist?"<br /><br />I thought. It didn't exist right then. That was the point, I was about to go on it. It didn't exist in any way that I know of.<br />"It existed in here!", I said and touched my temple.<br />"Wrong. There is nothing in there."<br />"What?"<br />"True. Ask a surgeon when you meet one. Any surgeon can tell you that when you remove the layers upon layers of brain, there is nothing in there."<br />Okay, so he was joking in that special way of his. <br />"Look-"<br />He interrupted me.<br />"There are only three places where your journey could have existed."<br />"Three? What places?"<br />"Well, where is it now?"<br /><br />I realized what he was going for.<br />"Aha! The past!"<br />He smiled.<br />"Trick question, it exists now of course. Didn't you listen to me? 'Where is it now?', I asked. You are in it."<br />"Yeah, but what is done is done. That path which we walked lies behind us."<br />He held up a finger.<br />"Look for the point. Don't miss the point."<br />He waved his hand in the air as he talked.<br />He said, "The real question is, how did you know the path before you walked it?"<br />He folded his arms and sat back, waiting.<br /><br />I closed my eyes and went back. To the beginning, as he had told me. I remember having a feeling growing, a feeling that I wanted to go on a journey. I remember it taking form over the course of a few days. I couldn't quite see how it got there, that notion. It's almost as if it suddenly just was there. Like in snuck up on me. Then I remember planning, preparing. For what? For the journey. At the moment I wasn't sure if I had just made up the thought of a journey, just creating it, or if it was there waiting for me.<br />"I don't know", I said. "You have lost me I'm afraid. It seems the very idea of a journey was just there one day, like it had crept in my mind, hidden. One day I just saw it there."<br />He leaned forward again.<br />"Saw it where?"<br />I hesitated. Three places. Back then it didn't exist in the past, of course. It wasn't present, like it was now.<br />"In... the future!"<br />"Right you are!"<br />He looked extremely pleased with me. Or perhaps with his ability to nudge me around.<br />"Come!", he said and stood up quickly. He ran over the small cliff and jumped down the last bit. He stood in the middle of the crossroads as I came up behind him.<br />"Now do it again", he ordered.<br />"How do I do it?", I asked.<br />"Well, now you know it. The magicians' way of choosing the path. Now do it."<br />I frowned at him. Then I stopped. I looked at the sky. The sun was a mere hint of colour far away. A dark blue sky had opened up above me without me noticing. Stars shone above. I looked down at my feet, and then slowly followed one of the paths ahead with my eyes. Suddenly I noticed something I hadn't seen before. Footprints in the sand. Someone had walked here before. <br />"That's right", he said. "That is how the magician knows his path. When you don't know your path, you just have to look into the future and then follow your own footsteps."<br />"How did they get there?", I asked.<br />"Why you put them there of course!", he exclaimed. Then he added, "In the beginning."<br />He beamed at me. I glared at him, but couldn't quite keep the smile from my face. As usual.<br />"You...", but I lacked words. Before I could think of any, he had lifted me of the ground, turned me a full circle and put me down in the direction of the footprints. As if I was light as a feather. Peering impishly at me, he began walking backwards down the road. <br />"Come!", he said and turned around. "Hurry! So much to see! So much to do! So many riddles to create for you!"

title: My Katrina Garden
author: Ray Seyfarth
post_content: <span style="font-weight: bold;"><span style="font-size: 180%;"><span style="font-size: 130%;">Katrina produces something good</span></span></span>After Hurricane Katrina, I had no house damage though most houses on my street had plenty.  I did have a magnolia tree in the backyard which had split near the ground during the storm and half of it was leaning for an hour or so.  Then the wind shifted and the tree righted itself.  It looked OK, but I thought it was probably not really healthy.<br /><br />I also had a pine tree which had been leaning since I moved in in 1990 toward a neighbor's house.  Her house had been damaged by her own pine trees during Katrina and she had all the trees removed.  I decided that I should remove the pine tree and the magnolia.  This left me with more sunshine than ever and some nice piles of wood chips.<br /><br />I thought the wood chips might be good for compost and the extra sunshine might be nice for growing some vegetables.   Now I know that wood chips take a long time to decompose.  Anyway I made a couple of compost bins out of a roll of rabbit cage wire and started composting wood chips mixed with dirt.  I planted some bell peppers, jalepenos, okra, squash and tomatoes.  They ended up being in poor soil and the wood chips were pitiful compost, so they were weak plants.  I misjudged the amount of sunlight in that spot.  I got no squash at all.  I probably got 2 or 3 okra pods, a dozen small bell peppers, a couple dozen small tomatoes and maybe 4 dozen small jalepeno peppers.  My neighbor gave me some cucumber plants and they produced perhaps a dozen cucumbers.<br /><br />My neighbor enjoyed watching me work and helped me out a bit.  He's 90 years old and still gardening.  He kept giving me veggies all summer.   I received more veggies than I grew, but I was happy to have started a relationship with my neighbor and enjoyed his produce.  We had a lot of tomato and cucumber sandwiches.  I started enjoying adding jalepeno to the sandwiches.  The Katrina garden was a little pitiful but I did have some nice food to eat and something positive to do.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold;"><span style="font-size: 130%;">Better Compost<br /></span></span><span style="font-size: 100%;">The first section of my garden had been in the area where my older son played basketball.  There was hard packed sandy soil.  Adding wood chips and planting in partial shade was altogether pretty silly.  I started cutting grass and composting grass clippings with some dirt.  After I had some better compost, I started digging a new area for planting.  I chose a little better. The new spot had grass growing and was in the sun.  The dirt looked much better and the compost was better.<br /><br />I planted yellow squash, cucumbers and okra in the second little plot.  I ended up with very large leaves on the squash plants and even had modest success with enough food to make it interesting.<br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: 130%; font-weight: bold;">Fruit Trees<br /></span><span style="font-size: 130%;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;">The wood chips made poor compost for veggies, but I thought that perhaps they would work with trees.&nbsp; I think they work best with "wild" type trees and vines.&nbsp; So far it seems that wood chips are great for muscadines.</span></span><br style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;" /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold;">Ph Meter</span></span></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: 100%;"><span style="font-size: 130%;"><span style="font-size: small;">I have tried 2 different fairly cheap pH meters in my yard with total failure.&nbsp; I think that I will be forced to guess and over time learn what works in my area.&nbsp; I am fairly convinced that I have acidic soil, so I try to add lime depending on the plant's needs.&nbsp; </span></span></span>

title: Well, I'm Back.
author: Rightous Guy
post_content: Well... I have nothing overly exciting to post. 'Cept that today was "alright". Nothing slap-on-your face great happened... But thank goodness that this weekend is over. Phew. I have write an 'In-class Essay' tomorrow for English... It's dead stupid. 76 minutes to write something intellectual about <em>Othello</em>? I'd have better odds against a fool with a machete. Speaking of fools. I know lots of them. For instance; there was a car accident today at school. This kid who lives up my road (I think he hates my guts...) he probably screeched out of the car park, like most of the drivers try to do and got barrelling down the road off to some unknown restaurant in order to purchase some desired greasy, fatty food for lunch. And then, come storming back to school, in the company of foolish friends and finish up the rest of the day absorbing knowledge like a sponge. Not. It was funnu though because I was walking home for lunch (I like two seconds away) and I heard a tremendous clatter and instantly thought "Hah, it would be funny if someone went into the ditch." Only to hear ten minutes later from my thick as two short plants brother that someone had. Upon my return to school, he was sat on the bonnet of his faded red Jeep Cherokee with a solumn look upon his sunglassed obscured face. Indeed the noon-hour today happened with great incident.

title: Happy 2005!
author: K.G.
post_content: Tis the day to celebrate the Presidents...and I am cleaning my house.  I guess that in itself is a tribute to the life in the US. I never have enuf time to keep my house and room cuz I am friggin busy keeping busy. ay yay yay.  Theres a couple things I have observed that have been on my mind.<br /><br />BRIDGE! I love Bridge and its goals.  This program at Davis is meant to inspire Filipino students, if not all students, to pursue higher education.  I went to their 10th annual showcase this Saturday cuz my sister said they were inviting past board members.  I haven't been out to anything Bridge in so long so I thought hey, why not.  My sister and Stephen came too...yay one of my best guy friends and former board member.  WE felt old, as expected.  There were too many singing groups, also as expected.  But they were pretty good!  The one thing I was irritated with the whole night was the MC.  The guy MC kept talking about his after party and drinking/getting drunk at the after party, and being "moist and wet" from watching the performers.  1) There were parents there.  2) PYC youth were invited (all of high school age)  3) There was even a young performer there age 12 that was watching the show too.  What the hell kind of message are they sending to these kids? It makes it look like Bridge is trying to encourage kids to come to college cus its fun and you get to drink.  What is this? It's one thing for the performers to talk about that stuff, but the MC-- that reflects poorly on Bridge....upsetting.<br /><br />Whew...next more pressing thing.  I have a performance this Sunday.  It's a hula performance and it's making me alil bit nerviosa!  This Sunday, Feb 27  at 12pm at the San Ramon Multicultural Festival.  It should be fun and it's free for all watchers hehe.  So cmon out!  I rarely have nething that I want people to come out n watch...AND it's free woohoo!.  I'm nervous, I just hope I don't get too nervous during the show.  So practice practice practice..whew should be vewy intewesting hehe....gotta go clean some stuff now...whew!
