title: Gone, FANITO, good-bye
author: Bright Eyes
post_content: <div align="left"><br><br><br /><strong><span style="font-size:130%;color:#ff0000;">"Sniff... Sniff... Cough... Wahoo"</span></strong><br><br><br />Ahh long time no see. I gotta say I do still love my blog, it’s always there for yah even if you’ve neglected it... your few readers however... well the blog is still there though. Plus it doesn’t complain or ask for anything in return... except well id be pretty ticket is some blogger gave me a hideous layout with hearts and black and red font.<br /><br />My neglect comes with a good excuse sickness – <strong>Tegan and Sara concert</strong> – sickness – sickness. A) people who go shopping when their sick should be shot. The only thing they do is spread their disease around. Working in retail I have to continually wash my hands worried that the countless sick people that into the store during flu season will spread their disease. They fondle the merchandise and peruse the shelves – do they ever buy anything? no. Why? Because they are sick, they don’t care about decorating their home, they are just so tired of being sick they get bored and think, HEY i’m healthy enough to leave me home... WRONG. You are not, stay at home, get the rest of your family sick, I don’t know you, and I don’t want your germs. So it’s inevitable with my endless hand scrubbing that I would get sick. I would however understand it if they were shopping because they needed to buy a present or some urgent reason why they would leave their homes, but that’s never the case. So to all you sick people who go to movies, and go shopping, or to a restaurant while your sick STOP it you selfish wank.<br /><br />Moving on... </div><div align="left"> </div><div align="left"> </div><div align="left"> </div><div align="left"><strong><span style="font-size:130%;color:#ff0000;">Tegan and Sara "Waahoo"</span></strong></div><div align="left"> </div><div align="left"><br /><img alt="Tegan Quinn" src="http://img30.exs.cx/img30/4844/tegan28dd.jpg" align="left" border="1" /> Last Wednesday was the Tegan and Sara concert at reds. It was fantastic it was the first time I had ever sent hem play live which is amazing because I have admired them since their hit “The First” got radio play. So Matt and myself trot out our houses around 5pm to go pick up the tickets that we ordered online months ago. When I got there the lady at ticket master said If I would have been a minute later my tickets would have been printed out at Reds, and given away to another customer... kind of a bullshit system if you think about it, and I still doubt that, that would be the case. So with the tickets in hand we headed to West Edmonton Mall only to look at the tickets to see the doors opened at 8pm. Since it was around 5:30 at the time I suggested we waited and went to Matt’s house to kill time there. Instead we went to the Mall thinking it would be better to kill time there... we were wrong. We ate yummy subs and then walked around mindlessly – since both Matt and I are broke it was a bit tedious. Now I really wish we went to Matt’s house just because walking around and then waiting in line only completely drained us of all energy (damn I’m getting old). We met some friends in line who were there and ahead in line (yes we butted I’m an ass get over it). We only had to wait about 30 minutes in line before they started to let people in. Little did we know reds went through the first 20 people in line and took their tickets ahead of time to stop people from budding sop when we got to the security the guy bumped us to the back of the line. So I was pissed right off, since the lined had progressed about 200 people back. So we waited about 30 more minutes again, by the time we made it back our other friends told us he took the tickets of the people behind us – so the guy was just having a power trip, and wanted to be an ass. That’s Red’s for yah. </div><div align="left"> </div><div align="left">The crowd in reds was pretty diverse, packed with teenage Emo kids and some older people around my age. So by this time I was getting pretty pumped, Reds played clips from America’s Funniest Home Video’s on their big screen while we waited, and finally Lindy came out to play. Now I don’t really understand why some band’s pick the openers they do. By rights an opener should get people pumped, not be too long, but long enough to expose their music and vibe to the crowd, entertain them for the time it takes to do so, and still get them pumped for the show ahead. Lindy did none of these things. There was little stage charisma, and their musical style seemed like wannabe Belle and Sebastian, the band itself spent more time looks at their instruments and the floor than conversing with the crowd. Their set seemed long and drawn out, leaving the crowd to converse with themselves and wonder when their suffering would end. Well, actually that’s been a little harsh; they weren’t horrible they just seemed like one of those bands that would be better via CD. SO by the time they were done, I was completely drained, having been standing for 4 hours now, and being old and sick. It was pretty neat to see both Tegan and Sara come out to watch Lindy play their set. I was so surprised to see how short they both were, which only made them look more cute. Plus you could completely get the vibe that they don’t think their huge celebrities with ego, they had no problem coming out to watch their opener. So once they got on set all my tiredness and aches went away and was replaced with musical bliss. All I have to say is wow. I was so happily surprised at how great they sounded live, even better than they do on album. They seem to be able to play anything from electric guitar to keyboards and acoustic. Both the twins switched in and out during their set between instruments. Reds however has some sound issues and their techies had some mic issues, so the fact that they sounded amazing over all that I was extremely impressed. They carried themselves on stage with perfection. They have immense charisma with their band mates and themselves. Plus they carry and aura towards their fans that they are truly grateful for the support and had mentioned many times throughout the show that, that was indeed the case. Apparently that show was the biggest crowd they had played too that was just them headlining, which I thought was pretty neat. I also thought it was pretty cool when someone yelled out a song request from the crowd and mentioned it was their Birthday, so Tegan got everyone in the crowd to yell happy birthday until she saw everyone yell. Comparing them to other female artists I had seen live they treat each and every fan as if they would treat a friend, they have absolutely no ego, which makes their live shows quite enjoyable. Especially because you don’t need all that crap, you don’t need rehearsed “talking to the crowd bits” they talked naturally, and once they played you saw their passion for the music which must be so hard to do night after night playing the same songs. They do it in a way that you believe that they make music that they love, and it makes u love it even more. I would love to see what a cd with the production quality that Jennifer Lopez gets staring T&amp;S because their live range was amazing, and it just doesn’t show on their albums.<br /><br />Their set was a mix of new and old, with quite a variety. They also finished the show with a song I had never heard before which was a treat. All in all I give it a 5 star show. not only am I thankful I got the chance to see them live, but also that there is someone out there so talented that actually has a fan base that allows them to make music. They are only going to get bigger and bigger, whether or not they ever make a huge success in the Much Music world. Go see them now. Check out their site for the rest of Canadian tour dates, and get all your friends to go with.<br /><br /><br /><strong><a href="http://www.teganandsara.com/index.php">Official Site</a></strong><br /><br /><br /><br />ps. “I told u so” – Grammy awards (friggin U2)<br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><strong>-J</strong> </div>

title: Okanagan Wine Trip '07 - Day 1
author: CalgaryWineGuy
post_content: Day 1 - May 25th<br /><br />Well, here we go again for my annual jaunt through the Okanagan wine country.  Having done this twice before, I have a better feel for where to go, where not to go, and how to pace my trip.<br /><br />Armed with my trusty laptop, this time around I can blog as I go and give you daily updates - just like a real journalist would!<br /><br />I left Calgary just after 10AM.. After a quick stop in Golden for some lunch, I made it into the Okanagan around 4:00PM local time.. Since it was early enough and it was on the way, I figured I'd stop in at Arrowleaf cellars - a great way to start my trip, being that they're one of my favorite wineries here..<br /><br />I tasted about 5 of the usual suspects:<br /><br />White Feather - their house white blend - a nice quaffable white - not a lot of depth here, but great for patio season.<br /><br />Red Feather - my favorite wine here - their Rose blend - after some sweet-talking, I managed to get my hands on a half a case of the as yet unreleased 2006 vintage (already a silver medal winner) - primarily Pinot Noir and Chardonnay this year.   Looking forward to the hot weather to drink some of this!<br /><br />Chardonnay - a decent Okanagan chard - very little oak, unlike so many of the bottles coming out of California<br /><br />Solstice - their red blend, primarily Merlot and Zweigelt.. I wasn't blown away, but I'm usually not by their reds.  They just seem better at the whites and rose.<br /><br />Vidal (I cant remember the name - its new for them) - it's an off-dry white - the grapes are picked at the same time as the one they use for their late-harvest vidal, so you can guess that the sugar content is pretty high to start with.  I assumed that they fermented it for a bit longer to get the excess sugar out - this seemed to be confirmed by the relatively high 13.6% alcohol content..<br /><br />All in all, I walked out of Arrowleaf with a case of wine for myself and some friends..<br /><br />After Arrowleaf, I headed straight into downtown Kelowna to check into the Royal Anne Hotel - I like this hotel - reasonably priced, and just a block from the waterfront.  And - it's a nice 5 block walk away from...<br /><br />Bouchons Bistro.  Ahhhh...<br /><br />Once again, my love affair with this restaurant has been rekindled for another year.  I walked in a little before 7, and as always, the owner / Maitre'd was out front to greet me - showed me to a table on the patio.  Over the next 90 minutes, I was back in culinary heaven..   I started out with French onion soup simmered with Chablis, paired up with a glass of Alstian Geuwurtztraminer.   Following that was a duo of duck leg confit, with some mushrooms sauteed with pork belly, some seasonable vegetables, and of course the obligatory pommes frites (this is a brasserie style restaurant after all).. I paired that up with a glass of Quail's Gate Reserve Pinot Noir, which worked nicely.   I followed up the main course with a chilled lavendar souflee with passionfruit puree, paired up with a glass of their house sauternes.   Add on an espresso, and I was 'fini'.<br /><br />I followed up that fabulous meal with a trip to the casino.. I think I will now write a book of my experiences, titled "How to lose at blackjack like a professional".. Up until tonight, I didn't think it would be possible to lose so much money while holding 19 or 20 in your hand.  Fortunately, the other gents at the table were having similar luck.<br /><br />So, now its time to retire for the evening, and prepare for Day 2.   Saturday is my day to conquer the southern Okanagan, and hopefully squeeze in a couple more good meals to boot.<br /><br />Cheers!

title: Ride Me, Dazzler
author: Timmo
post_content: Game 14... Tues Aug 9th, 2005<br /><br />It was a game that the Dazzlers more-or-less needed to win against the first place Panthers. A victory wouldn't guarantee promotion to the next division, but a loss would more-or-less knock it on the head.<br /><br />But the omens weren't great from the beginning: nervous emails flying around in the hours running up to the match;uncharacteristic squabbling out on the field in the first few innings; Isaac cracking his rib just a few days before; the trip down to south London which always seems to send everyone's internal compass doo-lally as soon as they cross the river; plus the Yankees not being able to get a handle on those damn Bosox... it all proved too much, even for a Dazzlers team that arrived early for some pre-game warm-up and practice, riding high on the wave of an exciting win the week before.<br /><br />And so, against the background of sun-kissed young lovers sunbathing and frolicking shamelessly on an unusually beautiful evening as the streaming sunshine blazed through the leaves and onto the rich green grass of Clapham Common, the team took the field to... come to think of it, what the hell were we doing playing softball in the first place???<br /><br />The details aren't important. In fact, it's probably better not to go into them. The mishandled ground balls, the overthrows, the scoreless innings at the plate... whatever. There were some bright spots, like Amy's sizzling liner down the 3rd base line in the top of the 1st; Sam's sky-high tape-measure shot to left field that almost hit the Space Shuttle on its way back down to earth; Rob's fantastic grab in deep, deep right-center field (even if it was obviously only due to the magic little pair of white shoes that he had just put on).<br /><br />Mostly, though, it seems all a blur. And an unfair end to what had been a great season, in an unexpectedly competitive division. But if it is any compensation, it wasn't just that the Dazzlers got beat by a better team. There was a little bit more poetry in it than that. The opposing first-place Panthers were the development team the year before Tony and Gerard put the <br />Dazzlers together. They had that little bit of extra seasoning that the Dazzlers will hopefully pick up next year. They were one year more mature, been round it one extra loop, this was their 3rd stab at it. Their time had come. They were ready to reap the benefits of the hard work they had invested, the experience they had accumulated. I mean, c'mon. they're a great bunch of people and they deserved it, didn't they? Ah, um, didn't they...?<br /><br />Finsbury Dazzlers 3 1 3 0 0 0 1 - 08<br />Sumatra Panthers 8 3 4 6 1 4 x - 26

title: I can't believe I've not updated for so long!
author: Eeyore
post_content: Sorry I've not updated for so long! It really is most shameful of me, and I'm sure you won't make do with the excuse that I've been very busy! I will try and remember as much as I can of what has happened since my last post, but those of you who know me well will know that my memory isn't the best in the world, so forgive me if I leave anything out and have to edit the post at a later date!<br /><br />I guess the main bit of news since my last update is that a couple of weeks ago, I was rejected without an interview from the university of my dreams, Oxford. I was absolutely devastated at the time, though I'm beginning to see it in a more philosophical light now. I was at school when I got the news; first thing on a Friday morning, and we'd been let out of English early, so I went to the common room, which thankfully was nearly empty. I got a text from my dad saying that a letter had arrived from Lincoln College, so I phoned him and asked him to open it and read it out to me. Imagine, if you will, how stunned I was when he read out the words:<br /><br /><span style="color: rgb(255, 0, 255); font-style: italic;font-family:Georgia;" >"Unfortunately, in view of the overall competition for places this year and after consultation with other colleges, I am sorry to have to tell you that we shall not be able to offer you a place at Oxford and that your application is no longer under consideration by any of the colleges here."<br /><br /></span>My initial reaction was to think that it was some kind of awful joke on my dad's part. But no, that would be too cruel. The next thing I did was to burst into tears, run out of the common room, sign out of school ill and wander in a dazed, aimless fashion in the direction of the station (still crying my eyes out and attracting some weird looks from passers-by), to go home. I phoned Alan, who was too shocked to say anything. I didn't stop crying for about an hour and a half. I phoned Jason, who was very supportive and sympathetic and advised me to go out and buy a new pair of shoes, which I did.<br /><br /><span style="color: rgb(102, 51, 255);">Change of font colour as it's now over two months since I wrote the above! My lovely Alan is in Japan for *five weeks* and the time difference means that we don't get to talk very much, and thus I have time on my hands and am resurrecting this blog. More on that later, in the meantime I had better update you with what's been going on since that fateful day when I was rejected from Oxford!<br /><br />My teachers did all they could to try and persuade Lincoln College to give me an interview, but alas, to no avail. It was a sad day when we finally had to give up hope, but with hindsight I'm feeling more philosophical about it - in a way, I'm quite relieved that I didn't have to go through the pressure of the infamous Oxford interview, not to mention that if I had got in, I would probably have got very fed up with the amount of work after a while. I'm glad I won't have to go through all that stress, when going to university will be stressful enough as it is.<br /><br />I have had offers from Reading and York, a rejection from Warwick (more on this later!), and I'm still waiting to hear from Durham and Nottingham. My plan initially was to take a year out and reapply to Cambridge, but I've now realised that would be a waste of time, and having been on an open day to Reading University, I've decided to go there. I don't need GCSE Spanish to go there, so I've dropped that and now I get to come home at 11.30am on Thursdays (as opposed to 5.15pm!), which is brilliant! The good thing about Reading is that I can live with Alan whilst doing my degree, which will be excellent. Again, more on this later!<br /><br />The main event since then has been my trip to France over the Christmas holidays. That was quite an experience! Having said goodbye to Alan (always a horrid moment) when he went to France before Christmas, I then joined him in France on December 28, sailing from Portsmouth to St Malo on a cheap overnight crossing. Remarkably, I managed to find my way around the ferry without getting lost, and I met Alan at St Malo the next morning without event. We went to Mt St Michel (I would post photos if I knew how!), a lovely kind of island thing joined to the mainland, with a monastery on top. There was a small street winding round the island leading up to it, and the place had a great atmosphere, like the kind of place you might see on a Christmas card. Unfortunately, my enjoyment of it was hindered slightly by excruciating period pains, and I have a photo of me looking very glum sitting in the main chapel in great pain!<br /><br />That afternoon, we drove back to Alan's parents' place, which is near Vannes in Brittany. I was *so* nervous! I don't speak any French, and they don't speak any English, which just made it worse. I must confess that it took me several days before I started to relax, though there were moments when I was able to be myself a bit more (such as after dinner, when Alan's mum produced loads of Alan's baby photos - sooooo cute! And when Alan's brother, his wife, Alan and I played a kind of board game and I won, even though it was the first time I'd played... don't think Alan was too pleased, as he's played it lots of times but never won!).<br /><br />The food was rather an ordeal! I don't eat that much at the best of times, so faced with meals the size and richness of those, I was not a particularly happy bunny! Perhaps the worst moment for me in terms of food came when a bowl of shrimps arrived on the table. Whole shrimps, with their little eyes staring up at me. The idea was to pull their heads off (gross gross gross!), then peel the legs and shell off, before dipping them in mayonnaise and eating them like that. I was horrified, and looked round to see what everyone else was doing, and they were all tucking into them heartily, so I had no option but to do the same. I found the shells to be very weird, so that I couldn't tell whether they were really hot or really cold... or maybe it wasn't the nature of the shells, maybe it was just me. Anyhow, I was proud of how I handled them, gritting my teeth and bearing it, with bread to help them down. I'm not overly keen to eat them again though, I must say!<br /><br />After staying a couple of days in Vannes, we went to a little village called Binic, on the north coast of Brittany not far from St Malo. This is where Alan's sister and her family live, and where we stayed two nights to celebrate the New Year. The festivities commenced at around 8pm, when we had several courses of food (including more shrimps, alas!) which I thought would never end, culminating in ice cream served with a liqueur which is meant to help you digest quickly so that you can go on eating more! Alan's sister and I didn't have any of that as we don't drink alcohol, but everyone else did. I couldn't believe that! I was relieved, then, when at about 11.30pm we went for a walk to the beach to let off some fireworks. I needed a break from all that eating! The kids were really excited and were being very noisy, and I frankly just wanted to spend some time alone with Alan! We couldn't though, which kind of pissed me off to be honest, but nevermind. After midnight, we went walking round the village, the kids yelling "bonne année" all the way. I thought people would get annoyed with them, but a guy leant out of his window and shouted </span><span style="color: rgb(102, 51, 255);">"bonne année" back to us!  It was a great atmosphere, and certainly my most memorable New Year's Night so far.<br /><br />When we got back, it was loud music, the kids going insane dancing to it, and then more food. By this time I was beginning to get really rather pissed off, as I was tired, I'd already eaten far too much food, and I really wanted to be alone with Alan. But no, I had to endure several more courses, and by the time we eventually got to bed at about 3am, I was exhausted and as soon as we were behind closed doors I started crying again, *is ashamed of self*. To add insult to injury, we were sleeping on a horrid old camp bed, which took ages to pump up and then gradually deflated over the next few hours meaning that we had to get up in the middle of the night to pump it up again. Not only that, but every single tiny movement one made produced a massive noise! I think they must have given it to us as some kind of joke!<br /><br />The next day we slept in until about 1pm, which was a source of amusement for Alan's family. I forget how we spent the afternoon, but as some people left I remember beginning to feel a bit more relaxed, and having fun with Alan's nephews and niece. In the evening after the kids had gone to bed, we adults sat down for a meal (yes, more food!!), only for the lights to start switching on and off before finally not coming back on at all! Looking out the window, the entire village appeared to have had the power cut too, so everywhere was pitch black! This was soon followed by the children getting upset, because they were frightened of the dark. Alan's sister and her husband managed to find some candles, and we sat down by candlelight (was actually really quite romantic!) to continue eating. Typically, having spent some minutes lighting all those candles, the electricity returned a couple of minutes later and the lights came back on!<br /><br />The following morning we said goodbye to Alan's sister and her family and started the bit I was really looking forward to - the journey to Paris. Six hours or so of time spent just the two of us! On the way there, we drove through Versailles, which was absolutely awesome! It was dark by the time we got there, and the palace was lit up and looked fabulous - I definitely want to go back for a proper visit some day! The streets were all lit with Christmas lights, and it looked wonderful.<br /><br />We arrived at Alan's brother's house a little later that evening, and I liked it because it was a lot quieter following the noise of Alan's sister's kids (though don't get me wrong, they were great - just in moderation!)! We spent those last two days in Paris, which is the best city I've ever been to (but I agree, I've not visited that many!). We saw lots of very famous places, and I was ashamed of myself for acting like a tourist and getting all excited over seeing the Eiffel Tower for the first time! We went right to the top, and the view was breathtaking! We then went to the top of the Arc de Triumph, which was considerably harder work than the lifts which take one to the top of the Eiffel Tower - it was a spiral staircase, which seemed to go up, and up, and up forever! I had the misfortune of having hiccups all the way up too, so there was me out of breath and the sound of my hiccups resonating through the stairwell thanks to the stone walls and floor! However, the struggle up those stairs was worth it for the spectacular view of Paris by night, including the Eiffel Tower lit up! It was really wonderful, and I didn't want to leave!<br /><br />Other places we went to in Paris included Montmatre, which had an amazing atmostphere, what with the guy sitting playing the harp (gave the place such an air of culture!) and all the artists waiting to paint/draw people's portraits. The view of Paris from there was spectacular, too. We went round Notre Dame cathedral, which was also very impressive, as well as seeing the Moulin Rouge (from the outside). The street which the Moulin Rouge is on is extremely dodgy, as it is lined with sex shops - more than I've ever seen in my life! (ok, confession time... I don't think I'd ever seen a sex shop before then! :-0) I actually felt quite scared to be there after dark (we had to so that we could take photos of the Moulin Rouge when it's all lit up... though we took some pics of the sex shops too, just because there were so many!)!<br /><br />I'm sure there are other things I meant to write about Paris - it was certainly a packed couple of days! I loved Paris and didn't want to leave - two days weren't long enough, that's for sure! I hope to go back some day, though in the meantime there are many, many other places I'd like to visit, so I won't waste time by revisiting somewhere I've already been for now! We managed to get an earlier ferry home to England, sailing from Calais, though it was in the middle of the night and the ferries were running late due to adverse weather conditions. Once on board, we headed for one of the lounges, where having had a cup of hot chocolate Alan went to sleep, and I was left not really knowing what to do, as I hadn't thought of bringing a book, and I'm not fortunate enough to be able to sleep whenever and wherever I want! I had a look round some of the shops on the ferry, and made the mistake of trying on some perfumes. Why was this a mistake, I hear you ask? I'm sure it would have been fine had it been the daytime (ie, had I been able to see outside so that I could see the motion of the ship), but as it was the middle of the night I couldn't see the horizon, and whilst initially the up and down movement of the ship thanks to the rough sea was fairly exciting, the novelty soon wore off and I began to feel very sick. The heady smell of the perfume just made me feel ten times worse, and as soon as we were back in the car, I washed it off with bottled water! I shan't be making that mistake again!<br /><br />My overall feelings about the trip were good: it was quite an experience, and there were some very memorable moments. I did wish on many occasions, however, that I had been able to spend more time alone with Alan, as we did in Cornwall. It was great to meet his family at last, despite the communication problems, but given the choice I would certainly have opted for a holiday for just the two of us! We are planning on going to Italy over the summer, which I'm greatly looking forward to. I really want to see the world!<br /><br />I had better say a few words about one or two things which happened before I left for France! My dad took my friend Hannah and me to see Handel's Messiah in Bath just before Christmas, which we both enjoyed greatly. It was nice to see so many people I know (including the evil guy I dated a few times a couple of years ago, Nathan; though he was pretty charming on that particular occasion), in particular Jason (who was conducting) and my best friend from choir, Claire. I loved the music, and it was nice to go to a concert as a member of the audience for a change!<br /><br />The end of term at school didn't really feel like the end of term, and was distinctly lacking in the Christmas spirit which had been such a feature of the previous year. This was because our sadistic headteacher banned anything to do with Christmas, even down to tinsel in the hair, even on the very last day of term. He also limited the number of carols sung in the end of term assembly to one (Hark the Herald Angels Sing, a nice religious one), which was not met with popular approval. I played in the band and happily occupied the role of principal flute, a pleasant improvement on last year when my arch nemesis Katherine took on the role. The day after the end of term my friends and I went to Gill's 18th birthday party, which was basically just a pizza and video evening and swapping Christmas presents. I didn't enjoy it much, as I never really enjoy being in groups of more than three or four people. I find it intimidating!<br /><br />Corsley Choir is going well. Our concert at the beginning of December seemed to be a success, though I must admit I found the repertoire rather boring. Natalie came to the concert, and I introduced her to the famous John. I was in turn introduced to John's wife and John's wife's mother, and I found that his wife was really nice! I've since come to the conclusion that John seems more of a family man than he likes to make out sometimes, and he's finally learnt to kiss me on the cheek and not on the lips. So good progress there! We are now singing the Mozart Requiem (and will be singing the Ave Verum too), which I'm really excited about. I'm finding it harder than I expected, but I love the music so much that I don't find that problematic in the slightest! I have also been getting on well with Jason recently, although Rachel has had to tell him off for being too sarcastic with me (he claims I find it funny because I always laugh, which sadly is true... he is funny!)!<br /><br />I suppose the most major event before France was Christmas, which was enjoyable (though I would have liked to have been with Alan on Christmas Day, but nevermind! I hopefully will be this year!). My uncle Michael came on the day as he usually does, so that was fun. We went for a nice walk with the dog and took lots of photos, and in the evening watched a film (I can't remember what it was we watched!). On Boxing Day some old neighbours of ours came for lunch, which is something they always do and something which I personally find rather a bore.<br /><br />A notable absence from the Christmas festivities was my grandparents. This is because we are unfortunately no longer on good terms with them. Entirely their choice, and sparked off by events which began with the death of my great grandmother. My mum and I represented our part of the family at the funeral in November, and while we were there we met lots of relatives (many of whom I never knew existed) with whom we decided we would like to remain in contact. This appeared to be Grandad's intention too, for the relatives in question are his brothers (my great uncles), who have been estranged for many years for various reasons too complicated to go into. To cut a long story short, Nanny had other ideas, and very soon she had taken offence at my mum wanting to be on friendly terms with Grandad's brothers, and announced that they would not be spending Christmas with us, which they have done for as long as I can remember. Since then things have escalated, and they've announced that they're not going to speak to us again, which I frankly find ridiculous and hurtful. I never expected to fall out with them, and it's a great pity. They seem determined not to listen to any talk from us of reconciliation, and it seems that they have made their minds up and there is nothing we can do about it. So that's that! :-(<br /><br />January was very busy, what with revising for my geography resit exam. I spent a free period with Mrs Hand, who very kindly gave me a file and organised all my geography notes for me, so that I knew which ones I had to revise from (otherwise I'd have wasted time revising for stuff which wouldn't come up on the paper!). In the end, I don't know how the exam went - one never can tell! - but I'm not too bothered about it because I still got a B overall, and if it's any worse than last time I don't need to take the grade, I can keep the first one. At the end of January I went to Warwick University for an interview, which went disasterously. I didn't like the interviewer and she (why couldn't it have been a guy, they're so much easier to talk to!) clearly didn't like me, and asked lots of questions which didn't leave much scope for very stimulating replies, not to mention that she asked me about a book I'd mentioned in my personal statement which I hadn't finished reading, so I couldn't talk about it at all because she was asking about the ending. All in all it was a disaster, and I ended up disliking the university as a whole owing to that unpleasant experience. I didn't stay for the sample lectures, I just went straight home! As predicted I was rejected, and it's just a good job I didn't want to go there!<br /><br />My job at the cafe I mentioned is going well. I'm still doing it, remarkably (I've been wanting to leave), though I do find it very hard work and stressful. It's rather making me appreciate Longleat! Incidentally, I did get that bonus I spoke of in my last entry! £108! They also paid me £120 of holiday pay, so that was great - it worked out really well in the end! My mum applied for a job there this year, but sadly didn't get the job because there were an incredible thirty applicants just for six places! I don't think it can have been that competitive last year, when I was applying for the job, otherwise I doubt I would have got the job.<br /><br />At the beginning of this month (February) I had my A level recital, which was traumatic. I played the Telemann Viola Concerto, Glasunow "Elegie" (also for viola) and "Idylle" by Benjamin Godard (for flute), and Gerry, the guy who accompanies Corsley Choir, accompanied me, which was great as I get on very well with him. The recital could have gone worse, but it could also have gone a lot better. My viola playing really let me down, and the question on everyone's lips after the recital was why didn't I do the whole recital on the flute! The answer being that I was advised by people who know better than me about these things not to do the recital on the flute, since I no longer have lessons. Let's face it, I hadn't played the flute properly for over a year, and yet my playing was still infinitely superior to my viola playing, despite having lessons most weeks. I have no decided I'm going to do the recital again, but entirely on the flute, and I'm having a flute lesson with Jonathan as a birthday present from my parents (it's horrendously expensive) in order to help me prepare. I'm quite excited about that!<br /><br />The state of my health has been somewhat less exciting. My cough having returned, I began to experience a shortness of breath about which I went to see the doctor and was then diagnosed with some kind of asthma. I now have to have an inhaler, which is a pain, and some time in the next few days I will be having to go to the hospital to have a chest x-ray, which is annoying. I just hope it doesn't reveal anything potentially nasty!<br /><br />It was half term last week and I spent the week with Alan, naturally. I went to his place on Friday night, but unfortunately came down with a really severe fever, and spent the whole of the next day and much of Sunday as well in bed. On Monday it was Valentine's Day, and Alan and I went to collect the gorgeous ring he has bought me, which was very exciting! It's a pink sapphire gem with a diamond either side, and I'm still captivated by the way it sparkles in the light! In the afternoon, we dressed up in smart clothes (he looked absolutely gorgeous in his suit.... I felt so proud to be with him!) and set off somewhere (I didn't, at that point, know where we were going!). It turned out that we were going to London, to a Valentine's concert given by the London Concert Orchestra at the Barbican Hall! It was tremendously exciting, although I got very cold on the streets of London and my shoes weren't the most comfortable in the world! It was worth it though, and it was a super evening. We even made it back to Oxford in time to go to Domino's Pizza before it closed at midnight, hurrah!<br /><br />The rest of the week, Alan had to be at work during the day, so I worked on my coursework back in his room, which was boring and claustrophobic, but worth it to be able to spend the evenings and nights together. I can assure you, however, that you do *not* want to get me started on the subject of his landlady, so I shall say no more about her than that. Last Wednesday, we went to look at an apartment in Abingdon, just south of Oxford, and decided very quickly that it's the place for us, so we've reserved it! It's so exciting! It's a really nice top floor apartment with a great kitchen, and we'll be moving into it when it becomes available in May (though I won't be able to live there until the end of May when I go on study leave, but it's only a few weeks!). I shall then be commuting from Abingdon to Reading when I'm at university. It's all happening at the moment! :-D<br /><br />Except that technically, it's not all happening, since Alan is in Japan for five weeks. He left on Saturday and won't be back until March 27th (when I will be meeting him at Heathrow), which, though exciting for him, is almost unbearable for me because we hardly get to talk at all because of the time difference (Japan is nine hours ahead) and because he only gets internet access when he's at work. I can't believe it's going to be so long before I see him again... in fact, it seems like an eternity. I've felt really depressed over the last few days, and I didn't expect to find this so difficult to cope with. I think I'm beginning to come to terms with it, but the prospect of the next few weeks seems frightfully gloomy (in particular when he leaves Kyoto and will only have internet access sporadically... his phone doesn't work in Japan, so we'll be totally without means of communication). *sigh* It's really testing me to the limits, and on top of everything else I'm kind of jealous that he gets to travel to so many interesting places.... I just really hope I will be as lucky some day.<br /><br />It has been snowing here a lot today, and BBC News Online (a site to which I've been addicted since Alan left because I've got nothing else to do) informs me that the worst is yet to come. I really crave somewhere warm at the moment, or at the very least I crave the arrival of summer!<br /><br />I shall sign off here, for this entry is now ridiculously long; congratulations if you have made it this far! I'll try and update again soon.<br /></span>

title: Journal from Korea

title: Installed XP SP2 - hold thumbs
author: DomAbr
post_content: <span style="font-family: arial;">Ok, so like the rest of the sentient universe I'm playing Oblivion. Lots of fun and I wont even try to review it here. But what is it missing, multiplayer? Well no, the genius behind Oblivion is the very nature of the single player experience. But after playing World of Warcraft and getting used to being *part* of a community thats what I really miss. Playing Oblivion feels lonely.<br /><br />Has WoW ruined single player games for me? Has the feeling of belonging to a Guild ruined the enjoyment of a lone experience? And solo questing doesnt count as a truly lone experience - I'd estimate that a very large percentage of all inter-personal interaction between players on WoW is not directly related to the quest or adventure being played by the people chatting away. People chat about how to beat a mob, or how cool your latest gear is, perhaps discuss raid tactics or your latest spec lists. Often the conversation mutates into interesting but nonetheless unrelated topics such as your latest gadgets, where you're going on holiday or what your favourite artist is up to. Thats the thing - its a community<br /><br />Perhaps WoW has ruined single player games. But how about this - introduce the feeling of an online community into the existing Oblivion game using a 'chat' mod. Imagine playing Oblivion but having access to a similiar type of chat function as in WoW. Form and join guilds, interact online with friends while playing Oblivion, get tips on the quests and the world....think of it as WoW but in a very large 1 player instance.<br /><br />I reckon that would be fun, and if some intrepid developer comes up with the mod, I'll pay a dollar for it!<br /></span>

title: Resort fun circa 1986
author: rasti
post_content: <span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">Indeed it is good to be back home. Although I had a kick arse time in Montreal and Debs was an incredible hostess I missed my bed and the random dog hair which normally covers all my clothing. Naturally after any sort of short holiday/trip Aiya and I have a debriefing session. You know, just to catch up on what heinous things Ammi and Thathi have been up to. Naturally one thing leads to another and we either end up watching a stupid WIll Ferrell/Ben Stiller vehicle, or revert to our castle in the sky. Last night we decided on the latter. (For those of you who are unfamiliar with our castle in the sky. For shame! It's not as if either of us doesn't talk about it incessantly!)</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>Scene:</strong> Checking out the Sri Lankan restaurant talent, to see what kind of pathetic competition Aiya would have</span><br /><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"><strong>Me:</strong> <em>OO look there's a place called </em><a href="http://www.clancys.lk/html/venue.htm" target="_blank"><em>Clancy's Pub</em></a><em> in Sri Lanka and it's Irish!</em><br /><strong>Aiya:</strong> <em>Looks like we'll have to buy some pints of Guiness and scope the place out when we go there.<br /></em><strong>Me:</strong> <em>Yeah and we can pretend to be Irish right?<br /></em><strong>Aiya:</strong> <em>*attempting Irish accent* Arghh!<br /></em><strong>Me:</strong> <em>Um, okay so instead of just being plain Irish, we can be Irish Pirates?<br /></em><br /><strong>Scene:</strong> Looking over the menu from <a href="http://www.athulacaterers.com/menumain.html" target="_blank">Athula Caterers</a> and attempting to calculate the price for a 100 person function</span><br /><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;"><strong>Aiya:</strong> <em>Okay, convert that now, so per head it's 500 RS, so how much would that be for a 100 people?<br /></em><strong>Me:</strong> <em>Uh, 500x100?<br /></em><strong>Aiya:</strong> <em>Yeah what is that?<br /></em><strong>Me:</strong> <em>I think it's 5000 right? No wait, there's 4 zeros so it'd be 50,000?<br /></em><strong>Aiya:</strong> <em>Just get the calculator and double check.</em></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>Me:</strong> <em>When'd you become so smart?!</em></span><br /><em><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"></span></em><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>You might want to skip this</strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;">So on Sunday we were having lunch at a restaurant called the <a href="http://english.montrealplus.ca/portal/profile.do?profileID=558808" target="_blank">Three Amigos</a></span> <span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">and conveniently enough they had paper placemats. Given my inability to see a piece of paper, or napkin without writing on it, we naturally had an impromptu handwriting analysis session. Which really blew because I couldn't remember how to analyse jack ;) But I hunted up the original analysis test and re-did it (today). Is it still disgustingly accurate? You bet! Joycie and Abs were wondering about the scientific accuracy of these things, and there doesn't seem to be a whole lot, but here's some useful sites. <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphology" target="_blank">Wikipedia's take on things</a> and the <a href="http://myhandwriting.com/FAQ/" target="_blank">FAQ</a> from the place I did the analysis from. And of course, for those of you who might be interested, here's the <a href="http://www.handwritingwizard.com/index.html" target="_blank">test</a> itself.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;">Here are a few of my results, and for those in the know, none of them will be very surprising!</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong></strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>Margins:</strong> Far left margins indicate fear of the future and apprehension of moving forward.</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong></strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>My 'Y's:</strong> Selective in choosing friends, does not truly trust everyone, has a select group of people who are truly close and is careful in choosing inner circle of friends</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong></strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>My 'T's:</strong> Extremely ambitious, very sarcastic with comments that are funny but at times are harsh, bitter and caustic (so creepily true!!!)</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong></strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>My 'M's:</strong> Has a very investigative and creative mind. Investigates things rapidly b/c of intense curiosity. Extremely logical and ordered way of thinking. Takes on way too many projects at a time. Diplomacy is a strong suit; has the ability to say what others want to hear, tells things straight without offending and can disagree without being disagreeable.</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong></strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>My 'O's:</strong> Is highly opinionated and will be candid and direct when exrpressing opinions. Will give straight opinion when asked for it.</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong></strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>The stems on my 'D's and 'T's:</strong> Demands respect and will expect others to treat her with honor and dignity. Believes in her ideas and will expect other people to also respect them. Has a lot of pride (<-- WORD!)</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong></strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>The Left slant of my writing and pressure:</strong> Is withdrawn into herself, reserved and shows her feelings only at times of great anger, extreme passion, or tremendous stress. Is an introvert who makes decisions based on logic, therefore is rarely impulsive. Doesn't find any need for expressing emotions and sees this as an unnecessary waste of time. Many people do not understand and it is difficult for them to really know how she feels. Enjoys being alone, and prefers working alone. Working with her hands is a pleasure. Does feel emotions, as deeply as anyone else, but they're harboured inside. The first time someone angers her, she probably will not say anything to that person. However, she will mentally keep track of everything this person does wrong to her until she cannot hold her emotions inside any longer. Then, Boom! Will never regret telling someone off, because she knew what she was saying the entire time. She won't impulsively tell someone off. Emotional stories will not sway her. Thinks totally with judgment, first considering every situation by the effect it will have on her. Needs space and time alone. </span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong></strong></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong>My 'K's:</strong> Can be defiant. Sometimes has the attitude that if someone doesn't like it the way she is doing it, then they can just "go to hell!" This trait may reveal itself in a rebellious nature that is always ready to resist forces which she thinks are infringing upon her freedom of action.</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;">Are you all believers now?! *shudder* That whole thing was disturbingly accurate. Other than the diplomacy thing of course ;) Go do the test and tell me what your results are!</span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"><strong><em>Well, if you're still here after all of the above lol, check back in a little bit, maybe towards the middle of next week for pictures and other scintillating things from my trip to Montreal!</em></strong></span>

title: Has anyone seen a Mr. T. Sumani?
author: rasti
post_content: <span style="font-family:trebuchet ms;font-size:85%;">What's up with the "ironic" trend and when will it go away?! It was kitschy five years ago when UO started putting sexually charged slogans on seemingly innocent looking t-shirts, but now it's just getting plain tasteless. Sure FCUK is actually a nifty little acronym for French Connection: UK, and G-Sus isn't supposed to be another way of saying Jesus, it's supposed to mean G suspended as in the guitar chord. But does anyone know what TNA's excuse is? Because i have no idea. At the risk of sounding like a prude i find all of the above and then some really tasteless. Honestly what's the point of walking around with clothes that have the above brandings on them? (I don't even think FCUK clothes are even nice to begin with, but the <a href="http://www.burner.de/start/shop.produkte/sxx_filter[reset]/true/sxx_filter[brand]/156" target="_blank">G-Sus stuff</a>, i'll admit, it's tempting ;) But not tempting enough!) It's not ironic! If anything it's borderline offensive, just like the Parasuco lesbian tag-team billboards. Just recently there was a bit of a brouhaha over someone wanting to use the acronym "WTF?" as a stand in for "Where's The Faith?" In my opinion that completely dilutes the point of the message. It's just as offensive as the <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/3790315.stm" target="_blank">underwear and bikini bottoms that Harrods was selling this summer</a>. The ones with the hindu goddesses on them. Another example of pure tastelessness and lack of decorum. Yeah i'll shut up and have my high tea now. Everyone's entitled to be a bit prudish sometimes!</span><br /><br /><strong><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;">On a lighter note. Or perhaps a heavier one?</span><br /></strong><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;">After coming back from the motherland Ammi has re-acquainted herself with some old friends and there has been a flurry of e-mails going back and forth between them. They're all hardcore artsies with a propensity for drama. Most of them (when we were still in Sri Lanka) were really fond of Aiya due to his rampant ADD and bouts of dyslexia; they haven't seen him in many years, so Ammi decided to send them some pictures! Of course she picked the MOST unflattering picture of the two us from my 20th birthday soiree and promptly proceeded to e-mail them half way across the world. Everyone responded in the same manner, "Oh Eraj (Aiya) looks just like Eksath (Thathi)!" and everyone ignored the other half of the picture. Me. Then along came Richard Simon who said "Eraj still looks just like Eksath and D still looks just like you (only a little bit plumper.)" Only a little bit PLUMPER? What the heck is that?! Come on Richard, if you're going to say someone's fat, then be a little bit more eloquent! You are a professional writer after all. <a href="http://www.infolanka.com/discover/bevis/" target="_blank">Here is a sample of Richard's greatness.</a></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;"></span><br /><span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS;font-size:85%;">Speaking of people being fat, has anyone caught the new George Stroumboulopoulos show on CBC Newsworld?  <em>The Hour</em>?  Anyone else noticed how much weight he's lost?!  And a little tip to his make-up artist, go easy on the blush, the rosy cheeked thing doesn't really fly well on him.  I'm a little bit disappointed about the show i must say, and i consider myself a fan!  He was really the only redeeming thing about MuchMusic but the CBC's trying too hard to market his show as "edgey" and in your face, but poor Georgie's left looking like a try hard.  He <em>is</em> edgey, and in your face; now he just comes across as unnatural.  Sadly that's what happens on the CBC don't you think?  They try sooo hard to market a person as being a certain way that they end up making caricatures of them.  For example <em>This Hour Has 22 Minutes</em> and <em>The Royal Canadian Airfarce</em>, they'd have you believe that these shows are side splittingly funny.  They have their moments, but by and large it's cheese.  I guess that's marketing for you, but if that's the case then the CBC should get a new marketing company, our move out of doing it in-house!</span>

title: introduction
author: single guy
post_content: o.k. i can type well enough to do this but my thoughts don't always run in complete sentences or use proper punctuation so deal with it.  I'm a 33 yr. old man, divorced for 4 years with 2 daughters ages 12 and 6 and i'm going to attempt to chronicle my life as a single man to shed a little bit of insight to my newly found life as an extremely sexy, single guy. The first thing that you have to learn as a single guy is how to deal with alcoholism.. not really the destructive stumbling falling down drunkeness, but the daily drinking that seems to come naturally with being a single male.  you see, after spending your day at work, you come home to an empty house on the nights that you don't have your kids around and you have two choices..either make yourself dinner which causes dirty dishes and trash, or go to the bar and get a sandwich and a beer.. well, obviously the latter choice results in becoming a much better pool player and obtaining your very own beer gut.. these things i've found are much easier to get than a decent woman but not nearly as pleasurable... so after a couple years of experimenting with this behavior you decide on an alternative, which for me included joining a gym and making deals with yourself to get along without ending up looking like that guy down the street that you can't for the life of you understand what his motivation to live is. (see the complete and runon sentence thing is already a problem) so you make a pact with yourself to not drink monday thru thursday and make it to the gym every morning at 5:30 a.m. to get your workout in before work, eat right, work on basketball, boxing, and golf skills at lunch time, and generally be the guy that every married woman on the planet would rather have than their husband, and still be able to not get one single (single) woman interested in you. so here's were we're at in my first blogamadiggy.. i have great days because i'm physically fit, controlled my demons, enjoy my time with my children, and can do virtually anything that i want to do.. and at the same time have no good outlook on ever having a positive relationship because of the comfort level that i've found within myself.  so now the real story starts, how does a man find a woman he can have a relationship with when he has made himself so independant and in all reality the perfect man? well, the answer of course is that he can't so that's why these weblogs will continue for quite some time and i plan to log my dating experiences, both horrible and notsohorrible for your reading pleasure.  the first thing i had to deal with is the fact that even at 33 years of age i had never asked a girl out face to face.. this is a serious problem for someone like me, i was fixed up with my wife through a friend, and fixed up with my last serious girlfriend through my ex-wife so i've really never been single or had to ever ask a female out before.. so i needed some guidance, that's where the internet comes in handy.. you see, there is no need for things like eye contact, nice cloths, good breath to chat with strangers on the internet.. where in real life this can be both challenging and terrifying, online you have the ability to treat everyone like the girl on the playground you used to torment. so that's how i get my start in this whole singles thing and thanks to aol groups, you can simultaniously e-mail everyone in a group with one stupid comment like "why is it so damn funny when you see someone slip on ice and fall flat on their ass?" well, needless to say, this comment caused several reactions with our more sensitive of the female gender, and i got called all sorts of unapropriate things.. but it also gave me a chance to privately e-mail all of these ladies back and looking back i actually made a friend out of the deal (and got some much needed casual sex from another).. i've lost my train of thought and must go play mindless computer games now, this blog will continue as long as i'm single so sign up for your 4 year subscription now while quantities last! ..peace. d

title: I don't normally do this sort of thing but....
author: Big Al
post_content: I waited until I was sure that we were down in print and I'd actually seen it, but our <a href="http://www.berkswelldirect.com">plus size dress </a> business - Berkswell Direct was in the Friday 15th July edition of the Daily Express.<br /><br />Its not a big article, but it is a start, and of course they didn't get the name correct either its "Berkswell Direct" rather than "Berkswell", but beggars can't be choosers.<br /><br />The journalist yesterday couldn't believe we went up to a UK size 44 rather than a 44" waist, but I guess there was not a great deal of room in the article to put those details down.  I think it might have upstaged the designer they were showcasing in the main article as they go up to a maximum UK size 24 (or maybe thats just my wishful thinking).

title: The problem with blogs
author: Big Al
post_content: Was talking to my mummy (adults of Norn Iron extraction nearly always call their mother - mummy especially when talking directly to them, it may sound childish, but we don't tend to care about that) this evening and she said that all of her joints seized up yesterday and that she ended up being taken in an ambulance to the area hospital.  This is the first time anything like this has ever happened to her and apparently the pain was something else.<br /><br />She had blood tests and a few injections and tablets and was sent home a good deal more comfortable, so I guess we will have to wait and see.  The Dr thinks it is an attack of arthritis, I've never heard of it presenting like this, but then again I'm not a Dr.<br /><br />My mum thinks she will be okay, but will have to skip work for a while, until she is better.  I hope she is right, I did mention that quitting smoking would probably help, but didn't want to push it too much.<br /><br />Both my Uncle and Annas Uncle have recently had relatively mild strokes in the last few months so I guess that is a sign they are getting on a bit and that we are no longer youngsters.

title: A Christmas Present Disaster
author: Big Al
post_content: I've been writing a few articles for a new plus size fashion blogger today (currently at <a href="http://berkswelldirect.com/blog/">plus size fashion blog</a>), its not exactly ready to integrate into the <a href="http://www.berkswelldirect.com/cgi-bin/cp-app.cgi">Berkswell Direct </a>site yet, but hopefully with a bit of tweaking it will take on "our corporate identity" while still offering details of available plus size fashions which are not necessarily available from us.<br /><br />Okay, what do I know about fashion, not a great deal, but I know what I like and besides I thinking more along the lines of articles, like visiting the Opera, Royal Ballet, a wedding, a medieval banquet, a cruise holiday and other dressing up occasions. I'm not sure they will bring in as much traffic as I would like, nor as quickly, but if you are not in you don't win.<br /><br />As for bargains to buy, Annie is definitely the person for this, I don't know how she finds all the links and sales that she does, many years of practice is my guess.

title: Cycling and Running Log
author: Only You
post_content: Spring is here and the latest fashions are out. I have been struggling with Lust. I thought I would look it up in my Thompson Chain Reference Bible (topic 667) and here are the verses they listed (all of these are from the King James Version--not copyrighted).<br /><br />Proverbs 6:25 <span style="font-style: italic; font-weight: bold;">Lust not after her beauty in thine heart; neither let her take thee with her eyelids. </span>This is interesting, because Solomon says there is a two-way relationship: we lust, and she takes. This gives us two opportunities to stop the cycle.<br /><br />Matthew 5:28 <span style="font-style: italic; font-weight: bold;">But I say unto you, That whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.</span> And we thought we were better because we didn't actually DO something, just thought or saw it.<br /><br />Romans 13:4 <span style="font-style: italic; font-weight: bold;">For he is the minister of God to thee for good. But if thou do that which is evil, be afraid; for he beareth not the sword in vain: for he is the minister of God, a revenger to execute wrath upon him that doeth evil.</span> Not pretty to hear, but eventually we could be judged for our wrongs.<br /><br />Galatians 5:16 <span style="font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;">This I say then, Walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh. </span>A solution, keep reading the Bible and praying and stay in the Spirit and we can conquer sin. It has been conquered for us if we simply claim the victory in Jesus.<br /><br />Colossians 3:5 <span style="font-style: italic; font-weight: bold;">Mortify therefore your members which are upon the earth; fornication, uncleanness, inordinate affection, evil concupiscence, and covetousness, which is idolatry:</span><br />concupiscence (def) A strong desire, especially sexual desire; lust.  Mortify means put to death, if I am correct.  Do not even give it a CHANCE to live, or continue.<br /><br />1 Thessalonians 4:5 <span style="font-style: italic; font-weight: bold;">Not in the lust of concupiscence, even as the Gentiles which know not God:</span><br /><br />2 Timothy 2:22 <span style="font-style: italic; font-weight: bold;">Flee also youthful lusts: but follow righteousness, faith, charity, peace, with them that call on the Lord out of a pure heart.</span>  Keep good company.<br /><br />James 1:15 <span style="font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;">Then when lust hath conceived, it bringeth forth sin: and sin, when it is finished, bringeth forth death.</span>  The pleasure of sin is temporary, and it puts you in a downward spiral towards death.  Maybe not <span style="font-style: italic;">always </span>Physical death but definitely a spiritual death.  It leaves us alienated from the Father, unable to hear His voice.  Of course, in this day and age, physical death can be associated with lust.<br /><br />1 Peter 2:11 <span style="font-style: italic; font-weight: bold;">Dearly beloved, I beseech you as strangers and pilgrims, abstain from fleshly lusts, which war against the soul;</span>  He is calling them "beloved" even though they may be involved with fleshly lusts.  This shows the love of God for even "strangers and pilgrims."<br /><br />Out of nine verses, one talks about judgement, and another one about the consequences of sin and lust.  This tells me how loving God is, that in this area where we struggle there is instruction and encouragement, rather than death and destruction.  Which is what we like to say to others, but never want it to apply to ourselves.

title: The Yankees lose!
author: Only You
post_content: The good news about the exam thus far is that, when I read Pathology<br />before, there were things I didn't quite understand. Nothing major,<br />but points here and there...I would say a dozen or so things.  Well,<br />upon reading it now, I know allthose things, or at least I can<br />understand them better.  Also I am doing better on the questions from<br />the Kaplan Q Bank.  Things look ok.  Of course, there is still a lot<br />to do, and the next 10 days will decide whether I can pass or fail. <br />But lets see what happens.  I am optimistic.  Will I be optimistic in<br />one month?  (That will be a few days before the result becomes<br />known!).  I hope so.  That will be a great time of tension....it<br />always is.  Those are the days that if you could put them in a bottle,<br />and save that tension for the months before the next exam, well that<br />would guarantee passing.  ok...that is it for now....<br />

title: my first blog...
author: whispers_that_shouldnt_echo
post_content: how honest should i be to a computer?....mark let me know about this...could be good for me, cause ive learnt bottling things up sucks balls. Things kinda look better, im still kinda confused, worried...maybe anxious about my future and what it holds...but who isnt...just feels like tomorrow there may be no one, i may not have options.  Im really thankful to Denny now, he told me honestly and straight why people have a problem with me. I hope itll end my confidence being below zero, i hated walking into a room and feeling everyone hated me, watching people leave and thinking its cause of me. I felt it most with Ben, Bens a guy i really kinda admire...is admire the right word?um..i hold him in high esteem, and i could see the way he acted towards me changing and it was horrible, i wouldve give my right arm to make things the way they used to be with him.  Id give anything to go back and change alot of things thats been happening but all i can do is learn from it and make sure the futures different. I wanna change the veiws people have got of me and make life a lil more stable, all the ups and downs are doing my head in!

title: Cry - Lasgo
author: Zeina Buhatem
post_content: Oies e olás pessoas.<br /><br />Bem... Todos sabem que, a princípio, esse seria prá ser um diário... Um confidente... E, ele acabou se tornando um amigo nas horas mais difíceis enquanto eu estava apaixonada e passando por maus bocados por não ser correspondida... Escutando meus lamentos, dividindo minhas felicidades, me dando o ombro prá chorar...<br /><br />Estava triste, estava magoada... E decidi que não escreveria mais enquanto estivesse assim... Não queria (e nem quero) a pena de ninguém... Só quero ser forte e voltar a ter aquela força que eu tinha há algum tempo... Uma força que me permitia agüentar o mundo nas costas... Uma força que me deixava invulnerável a toda forma de amor. Por isso, resolvi deixar o tempo passar...<br /><br />E o tempo passou...<br /><br />Dizem que o tempo é o grande mestre que cura todas as feridas...<br /><br />A verdade é que ele não cura!<br /><br />A verdade é que, quando amamos de verdade uma pessoa, esse sentimento vai nos acompanhar por toda a vida... A única coisa que o tempo nos permite fazer é varrer esse sentimento prá um cantinho escondido bem no fundo de nossas almas para que, pelo menos às vezes, possamos fazer de conta que ele não está lá e, mesmo assim, quando vemos uma imagem ou escutamos uma música ou nos aproximamos de datas especiais, esse sentimento volta à tona nos pegando de surpresa e nos arrastando pro fundo do poço mais uma vez.<br /><br />Isso aconteceu de novo na páscoa... Tantos planos... Tanta coisa boa planejada... Tanta coisa boa sonhada... Mas eu estava longe... E meu amor, vivendo uma nova paixão.<br /><br />E, novamente, decidi que era hora de deixar o tempo passar...<br /><br />E o tempo, novamente passou...<br /><br />O mundo não parou para que eu pudesse lamber minhas feridas, deixá-las cicatrizar e olhar orgulhosa para as cicatrizes das batalhas que travei sozinha.<br /><br />Então pessoas...<br /><br />Venho aqui hoje me despedir desse blog... Venho aqui trazendo meu amor nas mãos, como se fosse um passarinho e libertando-o, deixando que ele voe e alcance os céus e a felicidade que um dia tentei dar... A felicidade que, por muito e muito tempo tentei, desesperadamente participar.<br /><br />Então é isso...<br /><br />Fá... Uma nova e feliz vida prá você...<br /><br />Você sabe que vai ser sempre especial prá mim, né?<br /><br />Quando precisar de mim prá qualquer coisa, pode ter certeza que vou estar ao teu lado... Não importa a hora nem o dia nem o lugar... Eu vou estar lá! A partir de hoje, você é meu irmão querido.<br /><br />E, como não podia deixar de ser... Aqui vai mais uma música... A última... A que vai sempre me fazer lembrar de um final de semana em Porto Alegre... A música que, enquanto existir, não vai deixar que eu me esqueça dos melhores dias da minha vida.<br /><br />Muito obrigada por tudo...<br /><br />Zeina<br /><br /><br /><strong>Legião Urbana - Índios<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Ter de volta todo o ouro que entreguei<br />A quem conseguiu me convencer<br />Que era prova de amizade<br />Se alguém levasse embora até o que eu não tinha.<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Esquecer que acreditei que era por brincadeira<br />Que se cortava sempre um pano-de-chão<br />De linho nobre e pura seda.<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Explicar o que ninguém consegue entender:<br />Que o que aconteceu ainda está por vir<br />E o futuro não é mais como era antigamente.<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Provar que quem tem mais do que precisa ter<br />Quase sempre se convence que não tem o bastante<br />E fala demais por não ter nada a dizer.<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Que o mais simples fosse visto como o mais importante,<br />Mas nos deram espelhos<br />E vimos um mundo doente.<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Entender como um só Deus ao mesmo tempo é três<br />E esse mesmo Deus foi morto por vocês -<br />É só maldade então deixar um Deus tão triste.<br /><br />Eu quis o perigo e até sangrei sozinho.<br />Entenda - assim pude trazer você de volta para mim,<br />Quando descobri que é sempre só você<br />Que me entende do início ao fim<br />E é só você que tem a cura para o meu vício<br />De insistir nessa saudade que eu sinto<br />De tudo que eu ainda não vi.<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Acreditar por um instante em tudo que existe<br />E acreditar que o mundo é perfeito<br />E que todas as pessoas são felizes.<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Fazer com que o mundo saiba que seu nome<br />Está em tudo e mesmo assim<br />Ninguém lhe diz ao menos obrigado.<br /><br />Quem me dera, ao menos uma vez,<br />Como a mais bela tribo, dos mais belos índios,<br />Não ser atacado por ser inocente.<br /><br />Eu quis o perigo e até sangrei sozinho.<br />Entenda - assim pude trazer você de volta para mim<br />Quando descobri que é sempre só você<br />Que me entende do início ao fim<br />E é só você que tem a cura para o meu vício<br />De insistir nessa saudade que eu sinto<br />De tudo que eu ainda não vi.<br /><br />Nos deram espelhos e vimos um mundo doente<br />Tentei chorar e não consegui.</strong>

title: Mud is Smooth...not always I guess, but sometimes.
author: Cindooella
post_content: Today I woke up. Amazing huh?  I wished i could have gone back to bed, cuz i wasnt feeling the greatest. i think it had something to do with that red capsule my friend slipped in my soda last night.  Nah, just kidding. But i <em>DO</em> think it had to do with some kinda "non-alcoholic" drink my friend gave me last night.  (thats the truth)  Good thing Im never plannin on drinkin the real stuff. I wouldnt be able to handle it very well i have a feeling. But newho, I got a quick shower (which prolly is equal to 3 or 4 averagely-timed showers)for me, and then i headed off to my church. My dad let me drive. I only have my permit.  and a good thing too, cuz you prolly wouldnt want me to be reigning the roads at the same time as yourself.  im perty bad at the skill so far.  I forgot to signal all of my turns on the drive over to the church and i was in la-la land. Couldnt even park straight.  But i made it there safely.  Then i headed off with my youth group to our church camp for "Mud Day".  I bet you'll never guess wut we all did--oh shoot. Youre smart. Yea, thats right; we played in the mud.  The ppls had filled a dirt pit with water and then we all hopped on in. It was a bit chilly, but hey, its not every day one is allowed to flop around in some fresh mud. So I hardly minded the temperature.  After we rinsed off, we headed back home. I listened to "Barlow Girls" the entire ride back.  Then i got a shower.  Now im sittin here.  Crazy, huh?  Alright, i feel like crap. And im tired if typing. Besides, who would wanna talk to <em><strong>you</strong></em> anways?  im outtie. peace.
