title: Not Safe For Work
author: Yaox
post_content: This morning it really sucks, because I am having a hard time trying to stay awake. I actually managed to sleep a bit longer this morning. The day before sleep started at 12am, which only gave me 4:30 hours to sleep. Last night I went to sleep at 11pm, which is 5:30 hours of sleep, but still not enough. I need to start going to sleep around 8-9pm. I get off work at 3:00pm, and at that time I usually meet up with a friend of mine who gets off at 3pm for lunch, so we hang out and talk for a bit. Today I am just going to go to home and probably sleep for a bit.<br /><br />I have to concider moving out here pretty soon, because Dell is moving from the downtown core, and it may prove to be difficult to make it to work. Hopefully by the time Dell moves, I will have a raise of my salary and I will be able to manage a bit better with rent and that kind of thing. Its probably going to end up costing me about 1200 in living expenses (rent, food, internets, heat, water) that sort of thing. Although I am pretty sure I can find some rent for very decent price. I don't believe I will be living paycheck to paycheck though, especially if I work everyday and I don't take any time off..<br /><br />I'm starting to wake up now. I guess I just had to be a big groggy this morning, it can't be dodged I am going to feel this way no matter what. Unfortunately I seem to have the bad end of the spectrym. I guess I just need to work out a bit and get my endurance back. Perhaps purchasing a bike isn't such a bad idea for the summer. It wouldn't be so bad. But if it was raining heavily, or snowing like it was yesterday, then I'd probably have to plan ahead and take the bus, and whether I can rely on myself to check on that is another question. I honestly though I was going to give up after the 1st day, but I'm starting to obsorb the material in class, and I am learning it at a good pace. There is a lot to cover in this course, and I can't wait to start this job soon. Only 2 more weeks of training after this and we hit the floor.<br /><br />When the building moves... timing expected to be in July, I'll start to move. That or I'll ask my parents if I can pay rent without any more questions, and they can let me have the basement. I'm willing to pay $500 for room and board which is pretty sweet deal. That would definately look good. That $500 could go a long way for my parents, and help out a lot when it comes to having things like Food and having bills paid for, and ease the tension in the house a whole lot. My income would definately be a great asset. However I don't want to live at home forever, but for now that actually seems quite feasible. I know I don't cost much to maintain, concidering I actually take a good job of taking care of myself... feeding and clothing myself. All I need is a place to sleep that is hopefully warm, and I don't even want to know what it feels like sleep on a bench.<br /><br />But for now this is the way things are. My life seems to be really taking off, and hopefully things will only improve from here on in.

title: Writer with no Readers
author: Yaox
post_content: Everyone i've seen seems to think they are automagically aloud to poor there heart out for an old man, who was on his last legs. When my grand father died, I didn't cry, shed a tear, mourn. In fact I forgot about it in less then a week. The pope is like my grand father in the sense, that I never really knew him, never knew what he did or what exactly his impact was on society. I've heard stories about the pope and what he has accomplished, but has any of that directly impacted me? Some say he is the liberator of womans rights. Some say he was the binding of religions and teachings. Did I know him personally? Hardly.<br /><br />Your boss is probably comparible to the pope. Lets think about this for a second. The pope is assumed to have some sort of artificial power, much the same like your boss. Your boss basically tells you what to do all day, like the pope. You are essentially a sheep to the boss and the pope has many flock. You do as the boss says your or fired, or in the case of the pope, you can continue living on a normal life like it didn't matter. This is why I think the pope isn't at all powerful, worthy, or even remotely interesting.<br /><br />Just because someone pushes the button's on CNN to have John Paul 2nd's carcus shown to the rest of the world for a week straight doesn't mean he is super important. Infact, that is a complete waste of air time. Who needs to see someone's dead body? Did you know that during the coverage of the pope's funeral, insurgence in Iraq invaded a prison in Iraq (the one now made famous for being a sexual torture chamber), and killed 15 soldiers? Are the lives of the people you sent to war to 'defend' your country so lack luster that they shouldn't be counted or recongized for there 'sacrifice' that in fact because the pope dies that his life is more important then anyone elses?<br /><br />The problem I have with all this is that we always try and value another person to be better then ourselves or one another. We all know that when the ship is sinking, the only person we are going to care about is ourselves. To assume that the pope would bend over backwords to save your skin in the same instance is flawed, and he probably wouldn't even care about you. The pope was given some of the most robust medical treatment in the world to keep him going this long, especially for 6 more weeks then what most people would of even dreamed of living in there own current state of affairs.<br /><br />We mourn the death of a loved one, thats one thing. But to mourn just for the sake of mourning? Grow up. You may know of someone or met them once or twice, but that doesn't automagically make them a spokesperson for there identity. You leave that to the priest who has to make this stuff up at the funeral. I know when I die, the last thing I want is some person I've only met once in my life start fuming and greaving over my coffin.<br /><br />Terri and the Pope. They are tied together, because we value human life so much. But we turned a blind eye on our soldiers defending a prison camp that made them look like putrid and inhumane members of society. Get over it. No one cares.

title: Someone's Been Eating My Porridge Too!
author: Blonde Justice
post_content: Alright, this new "Buzzed Driving is Drunk Driving" ad campaign is killing me.  And I haven't even seen the first ad yet.  <br /><br />Actually, I have seen <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/emayoh/62678035/">this photo of a billboard</a> and I just watched the commercial which is available <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=1448925">here</a> from <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/">abcnews.com</a>.<br /><br />For those of you who don't want to bother to watch it, I'll give you the rundown:<br /><br /><blockquote>The scene is a wedding reception, winding down, slow song at the end of the night.  You see one young man who is obviously wasted, stumbling around, stumbling up to the stage and banging on the band's drums.  <br /><br />The voiceover says, "It's easy to tell when you've had way too many.  But what about when you've had one too many?"  <br /><br />Now you see an apparently sober looking man, drinking a last gulp from his drink before he and his wife head out the door.<br /><br />Finally, the voiceover says, "Buzzed Driving is Drunk Driving."</blockquote><br />First, let me start with the personal and get it out of the way.  I don't condone drunk driving, I don't drive drunk.  Throughout college, my friends and I always had a designated driver or just walked home.  Now, I'm lucky to live in an area where I pretty much never drive anywhere, so it's not much of an issue.  But if I go somewhere and I know I'm going to have to drive, say a wedding, I would probably have only one drink, two at the most, depending on how many hours I'm going to be there.  It's fair to say that I err on the side of caution when it comes to drinking and driving.  <br /><br />Now the legal.  The point of this ad campaign, I believe, is to draw the following line of thought:<br /><br />Buzzed Driving = Drunk Driving = Illegal...<br />Therefore, Buzzed Driving = Illegal<br /><br />Which just simply isn't true.  It's a clear misstatement of the law.  In fact, as a defense attorney, when we voir dire in drunk driving cases, one of the things that we want to be sure that every juror understands is that it is not illegal to drink and drive, it is only illegal to drive while legally intoxicated.  <br /><br />So, what is the legal definition of intoxicated?  Simple.  And very objective.  A blood alcohol level above .08 is legally intoxicated.  <br /><br />How drunk is .08?  Well, that's the part that's kind of subjective.  Different people are going to feel and function differently at .08.  <a href="http://www.ou.edu/oupd/bac.htm">This BAC calculator</a> is kind of fun to play with and gives you an idea of what your BAC.  Even MADD  tells us that:<br /><blockquote>To reach a .08 BAC level, a 170-pound man would have to drink approximately four drinks in one hour on an empty stomach or a 137-pound woman would have to drink approximately three drinks in one hour on an empty stomach.</blockquote><br />That's quite a bit.  But, I think the question remains, how do you feel at .08?  Do you feel, "Whoa, I'm wasted!" or do you feel, "Hey, I've got a little buzz on, but I'm good to drive?"<br /><br />In speaking to experts on the subject (and I mean actual PhDs, not just <a href="http://nakeddrinkingcoffee.blogspot.com/2005/12/im-magic.html">people who drink a lot</a>), it really just depends on the person.  Experts tell us that people who drink very frequently may be able to function quite well, even at very high BACs.  Likewise, ask around and you'll find that many people have been to parties where the drinks were either very watered down or not alcoholic at all, and yet one person who didn't know this stumbled around saying, "I'm getting sooo drunk!"  Are they just faking?  No, experts say that a large part of how drunk we feel or act is in our heads.<br /><br />Other factors, besides a person's drinking history, is how much they've had to eat, their size, the types of drinks, the time period during which they had the drinks and the time period since the last drink.  <br /><br />(For example, imagine someone doing four shots of tequila and then immediately getting into a car to drive just a few blocks.  Science tells us that they can't yet be intoxicated - the alcohol hasn't had time to enter their bloodstream.  But imagine a cat jumps out in the street, they swerve to avoid it, and hit a parked car.  When the police come, they're going to smell the alcohol.  And by the time you get down to the station and take the test, he's going to blow a BAC much higher that what he had at the time of the accident.)<br /><br />So, why is this ad campaign driving me nuts?  What's so untrue about it?  It's a real under-exaggeration of the legal standard for intoxication.  <br /><br />Look again at the "buzzed" guy.  There aren't even any other empty glasses on the table!  And he didn't even finish that one drink!  True, he kind of bumped into the door.  Maybe he's just klutzy.  Or being gentlemanly and making sure there's enough room for his wife to get through the door.  I don't think there's anything to lead us to believe he's had much to drink except that one gulp we saw - and there's certainly nothing to lead us to believe he has had "one drink too many."  Unless we're going along with MADD and saying that even one drink is one drink too many.<br /><br />Finally, what does all of this have to do with driving?  Are buzzed drivers causing accidents?  In general, the answer is no.  <br /><br />In the cases I've seen where a DWI arrest is made for someone driving with a BAC between .08 and around .12, nearly 100% of those arrests are made as the result of a checkpoint stop.  In other words, the drivers with BACs at or near .08 simply aren't drivers that are causing accidents.  Instead, in most of the DWI accident cases I've seen, and there's a lot of empirical evidence to support this, the BACs are higher - usually over .12.  These are clients that, even when I interview them hours later, still smell like alcohol, still have slurred speech, and often can't remember what happened.  <br /><br />But I understand that a cutoff needs to be set.  And I even agree that it should be set on the lower side, again, erring on the side of caution and keeping in mind that alcohol effects each person differently.  <br /><br />My real problem is with the use of the word "buzzed," a very subjective word, that to some people may mean that first warm feeling you get from just a sip of alcohol, and to others it may mean something a lot closer to "drunk."  <br /><br />(Kind of like some people think "hooking up" is something along the lines of making out or fooling around or whatever, and other people think "hooking up" means actual sex.  It's all just slang.  It's not like you can look it up in the dictionary and see what "buzzed" or "hooking up" means.)<br /><br />And it seems that maybe this commercial wants you to believe that "buzzed" could mean one drink or less.  There certainly is no further explanation as to how much the "buzzed" man in the commercial has had to drink.  And yet, it's being equated to drunk and illegal driving.  <br /><br />It's misleading and it's a misstatement of the law.  Many people rely on the media to tell them the state of the laws.  When a new law goes into effect, or a law is changed, people expect to hear about it on television.  I'm concerned that people will mistake this advertisement for a report on the current state of the law.  And, I don't want any juror who has seen this commercial or who believes it, for fear that they may substitute this advertisement's misstatement of the law for the actual law, despite the correct instructions from the judge.

title: Will Blog For Books
author: Blonde Justice
post_content: Let's talk about the first three minutes of this past week's Law & Order.  You know, the first scene, which usually ends with a "witty" one-liner and leads into the theme song.<br /><br />Ok, so this past week, the scene starts with pages and papers flying around the street.  An older woman is clutching some of the pages, and she approaches a police officer, who is writing a parking ticket.<br /><br />Immediately, the police officer says to her, "It's too late, lady, I already started writing the ticket."  <br /><br />After she tries to explain, he realizes that the pages she's holding have blood on them.  <br /><br />He finds the dead body, Detectives Fontana and Green show up.  They talk to the woman briefly about what she saw, and tell her that they'll get a car to take her home.<br /><br />Stop!  What's wrong with this scene?<br /><br />Yes, they would've gotten a car for the woman.  A police car.  To the station.  Where she would have been charged for bribery.  For approaching an officer who was writing a ticket, while holding papers out to him.<br /><br />The fact that it wasn't her car, or that she wasn't trying to get him to stop writing the ticket don't really matter.  That can all be sorted out after she spends a night in central booking.  <br /><br />And some brand new D.A., who took the job thinking she'll get some trial experience and make a difference in the world, makes a bail application about how this old woman obstructed justice AND bribed a police officer.  That she's a flight risk because she has a winter home in Florida.  Maybe, with the wrong judge on the bench, her kid will have to come post bail for her. <br /><br />Don't believe me?  Come follow me in arraignments one day.

title: Book For New PDs
author: Blonde Justice
post_content: Look at me!  I'm up on current events!<br /><br />A fan, who has been my tipster for a couple of posts now (and who wants to be a Public Defender when he grows up - that is, graduates from law school - because he thinks I'm super cool), pointed me toward this story.<br /><br />It seems that this woman, <a href="http://papersplease.org/davis/index1.html">Deborah Davis</a>, was arrested in Colorado for failure to show proper identification when riding a bus.  <br /><br />This leads me to wonder... what is the proper identification required for riding a bus?  A passport?  Driver's license and birth certificate?  Proof of citizenship?  A letter from your mom?<br /><br />The case has now been dropped, but <a href="http://papersplease.org/davis/rally.html">a rally</a> is still planned for tomorrow (Friday).  People are also encouraged to ride the buses without identification tomorrow (and anytime thereafter, of course).  <br /><br />Not within commuting distance to Colorado?  Letters to the editors of the local newspapers are also appreciated, as are donations to the ACLU.

title: Absolute MUST READ
author: Blonde Justice
post_content: I've got a rant brewing inside me.  It started to peek out in the comments to two of my recent posts (<a href="http://blondejustice.blogspot.com/2005/11/trading-spouses.html">here</a> and <a href="http://blondejustice.blogspot.com/2005/11/amazing-race-zen.html">here</a>).  At this point, I think I just need to put it out there.  So, here it goes.<br /><br />Where should I start?  I was raised Christian.  Protestant.  When I was young, my family and I went to church pretty regularly.  We didn't talk about God or religion a lot in my house, but my parents were involved in a bit of charity, particularly through community work.  We didn't pray before dinner, except on Thanksgiving or Christmas.  <br /><br />By the time I was in high school, my family became Christmas-and-Easter churchgoers.  I went to church a few times on campus in college, but just never really got into the habit.  <br /><br />In my current town, I'm a member of a church.  I, once again, go to Church regularly.  I volunteer, I do some community work, and I feel pretty strongly, as I've written here previously, that the work that I do has a strong religious component.<br /><br />But I've always just been very turned off by what I feel are "preachy" Christians.  Sure, you've found happiness in your Christianity, and you want to share that.  But I feel like there's a time and a place.  And, I know, I can see the obvious argument against that.  That Jesus didn't just spread the word when the time was right, but He did it all the time.  And maybe the fact that I'm uncomfortable with it somehow makes me less of a good Christian.<br /><br />But, I feel like some people spend too much time talking about what good Christians they are, and not enough time being good Christians.  And I feel that actions speak louder than words.  <br /><br />Last week, I was waiting in the doctor's office waiting room.  A woman came in, went up to the desk to check in for her appointment, and I noticed that she was up there for a long time, talking to the receptionist.  She then went and started talking to a woman in the waiting room.  I assumed that the woman she was talking to was a friend that was waiting with her.  I could overhear parts of her conversation.<br /><br />"Ever since I found God in my life..."<br />"The Lord is my Shepard..."<br />"I am a woman of God..."<br /><br />It was none of my business, so I tried not to pay attention.  But she was loud.  She was talking about how she had moved to a new neighborhood last year.  And before she even moved in, she had printed up flyers.  "To tell them about me, about my kids, about my miracle of how I found God..."  She invited everyone in the neighborhood, through these fliers, to a meeting at her house because she wanted to organize a neighborhood watch group.  "I wanted them to know what my car looks like, and know what their cars look like, so if Satan comes to take our children, we're on the lookout."  (Wow, Satan drives a car now?)  To her surprise, no one from the neighborhood showed up at her meeting.  "I guess they couldn't face a woman of God, knowing that they're all sinners."  Hmmm, gee that's it.  I couldn't help but think, "Or maybe they already had a neighborhood watch group.  How about that?"  But, like I said, none of my business.  I just wanted to read my crappy magazine from two years ago.<br /><br />She then got up, though, and went to an empty chair near two other women on the other side of the waiting room.  And I could hear her talking again.  I started to pay more attention, because I realized she wasn't with any of these people, she was just evangelizing to them.  <br /><br />I could hear her telling them this story.  Her kids, apparently, had either called the police on her or went to court about her.  (Or both.)  "I never beat my kids," she said.  "Sure, I spanked them, when they needed to be spanked, but I never beat them."  I don't know much about family court, but her children must have gone to court and gotten a restraining order and permission to live with their aunt.<br /><br />"My sister!  My sister!  And she's a thief.  She used to steal from me all the time.  And she's not even a Christian!"  So, the police had come to her house, and served her with the papers.  She started telling them about the word of God, and one of the police officers said something along the lines of, "Yes, we were warned you were a lunatic."  <br /><br />And, now the woman was shouting in the waiting room.  "I told him, you can call me crazy.  You can call me a Jesus freak.  But you cannot ever ever, I mean ever, call me a lunatic.  Because that is what they called My Lord.  And I'm not even half as good as Jesus Christ to fill his sandals!"  <br /><br />All I could think was "WTF?  When did they call Him a lunatic?  And, even if it's in your Bible, isn't that just a translation, when maybe a translation of 'crazy' could've been just as appropriate?"  <br /><br />Well, finally, someone in the little reception window looked out to see what was going on, and I heard her say, "Ethel, she's at it again, you have to go get her."<br /><br />And, with that, they called the lunatic's name to bring her into the doctor's office.  <br /><br />And as she walked in, she turned around to the entire waiting room and said, "There's too much sin here on earth.  You've all invited Satan into your hearts.  And that's why you're sick and in the doctor's office."<br /><br />Me?  I was just there for a physical.  But I think we can all guess who the sick one is.<br /><br />That very night, I happened to catch <a href="http://blondejustice.blogspot.com/2005/11/trading-spouses.html">this crazy episode of Trading Spouses</a>.  One of the women was a Christian (the woman you see screaming in the commercials), and the other was more... spiritual.  (She classified herself as a Christian, but she also believes in astrology, hypnotism, etc.)  The Christian woman was very upset to be in a "darksided" home.  <br /><br />But what upset me more was the way that the Christian woman's friends treated the hypnotist lady.  They're in Louisiana, and the hypnotist lady invites all of the Christian lady's friends over for a dinner.  She hopes that it will be good for her to get more insight into the family she's staying with, and ways to connect with the kids.  <br /><br />One of the women, as soon as she walked in, said "Are you a Christian?"  The hypnotist answered, "Yes."  The woman asked, "Well, do you believe in (finger quotes) 'God' or do you believe in (finger quotes) 'a higher power'?"  The hypnotist lady answered, "I believe in God."  "Well, when was the last time you went to Church?"  <br /><br />The hypnotist explained that she was raised Catholic, and that she's now a member of a Unitarian congregation.  "Well, what do they believe?" the Christian friend asked.  <br /><br />"We believe that all people are created equal..."  before she could even finish, the woman interrupted, "What?  Like the terrorists and the pedophiles?"  <br /><br />I just think this is so hypocritical.  First of all, this woman is welcoming you into "her" home.  (No, it's not really her home, but it is for the time being.)  And before you even get in the doorway, you're interrogating her, interrupting her, and judging her?  To me, that's not Christian.  The hypnotist woman is a better Christian, because she's the one who is taking the time to get to know other people, and to try to understand them and connect to them.  <br /><br />Then, finally, on that same night, was <a href="http://blondejustice.blogspot.com/2005/11/amazing-race-zen.html">this episode of Amazing Race</a>, which, through the miracle of Tivo, I didn't watch until the next night.  <br /><br />This season, there's a family called The Weavers (also known as "the Florida family").  They make for the best television, and I think that all of the dumb American quotes that I've featured here have been from them.  <br /><br />And, as you can see from the comments, they're rude to other teams, make fun of other teams (not that I wouldn't), and then say, "Why doesn't anyone like us?  We're good Christians!"  <br /><br />Being a good Christian isn't something you just say, it's something you do.  In fact, I think that the more you have to say it, probably the less you're actually doing it.  <br /><br />And, <a href="http://blondejustice.blogspot.com/2005/11/amazing-race-zen.html#c113128713484645759">as my father says</a>, "Be nice, those people chose your President."  I guess he's right.  I guess there's some majority in this country of people who are more comfortable saying "I'm a Christian" and telling others how to live a Christian life, then they are just living a Christian life - accepting others, and practicing peace.<br /><br />And they chose one for President too.  He can sure talk about Christianity, all the while standing by while people get killed in war and by the death penalty, obviously ignoring the commandment, "Thou shall not kill."  But, maybe he figures if he gets someone else to do it for him, it doesn't count?<br /><br />So, that's all for my rant.  I'm annoyed at these people.  I think they give a bad name to Christians everywhere.

title: Trading Spouses
author: Blonde Justice
post_content: I know this woman.  And she has the most annoying voice.  <br /><br />I'm not being mean.  Really, I'm not.  It's just a fact.  <br /><br />If I were to say, "She makes Fran Drescher sound like a lullabye," that might be mean.  But all I'm saying is that her voice is really really annoying.  More annoying than Fran Drescher.  And that's just a statement of fact.<br /><br />It'd be really mean to say that her voice is worse than fingernails on a chalkboard and a car alarm, combined.    So, I won't say that.  <br /><br />One of my friends summed it up when she said, "It always suprises me when she says something not dumb.  I mean, usually, someone with that kind of voice, you expect even the content of their statements to be annoying and dumb.  But with her, it's just that her voice is that bad."  <br /><br />So, imagine my surpise when I got an email stating that this woman - this woman <em>of all people</em> - will be performing a spoken word / poetry reading this weekend.<br /><br />All I can hope is that maybe she recognizes her vocal tone and built it into her reading somehow.  Maybe she wrote a poem about a cat being run over by a car.  Because a poem about love or flowers or the sunset, just wouldn't be the same as read by her.<br /><br />I'm sort of interested in seeing it... just to find out.

title: NJ to Require Recording of Interrogations
author: Blonde Justice
post_content: <a href="http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/0916051disk1.html">This</a> is pretty funny (you have to read both pages to get it.)<br /><br />And law related!  What more could you ask for?<br /><br />In other news, I have been watching <a href="http://www.bravotv.com/The_Law_Firm/">The Law Firm on Bravo</a>, and there's been a few pretty interesting episodes.  It's unfortunate that it's not on NBC, I think it'd make good law school viewing (and, I assume law students are more likely to catch something that's on NBC than on Bravo).  One of the recent episodes (1 or 2 weeks ago, I guess?  I've been watching them off Tivo, so I'm not sure when it aired) brought up an interesting ethical issue:  Can you read to the jury from a document that you know to be untrue, a document signed by your client, after you didn't allow your client to testify because you knew she'd be perjuring herself (and the document that you read was essentially the same as what her perjured testimony would've been)?  What if your adversary opens the door by mentioning another part of the same document?<br /><br />My best instincts say no, duty of candor to the court, blah blah blah, but I guess if I were in that situation at the very least I'd request a recess and research it and speak to someone about it.  (Some states have an ethics hotline that you can call with this kind of dilemma, if you don't have a senior attorney that you can consult.)<br /><br />In the end, though, it didn't seem to make a difference to Roy Black, or whoever is actually making the decisions, because the attorney who engaged in the ethically questionable behavior was not dismissed.  In fact, I don't think he even commented on it in the final "board room" scene.<br /><br />Also, my favorite attorney, Chris, who I believe may have been a public defender was "dismissed" in the most recent episode, so I was disappointed by that.<br /><br />The point is, it's getting pretty good, so tune in if you've got Bravo.

title: Fantasy Baseball Recap

I saw on television, a picture of that FEMA room.  And, I don't mean to be sexist, but there wasn't one woman in that room.  I say, "If you can't plan a wedding, you can't plan for a hurricane."  Their wives probably pack for those guys when they go on vacation! </blockquote><br />And she's right.

title: Trust Me, I'm a Lawyer
author: Blonde Justice
post_content: I am always so fascinated when people blog their jury duty experience.  I like to hear how they come to their decisions, what they view as important in the jury room, and how they view the attorneys.  <br /><br />I found <a href="http://www.happyscapula.com/">Happy Scapula</a>'s jury duty review via <a href="http://www.skellywright.blogspot.com/">Arbitrary & Capricious</a>, and I actually was the first to comment on his blog!  <br /><br />So, first, read it (if you like) and then I'll give you my comments:<br /><br /><a href="http://www.happyscapula.com/blog/2005/9/3/jury-duty-part-1-before-the-trial.html">Part 1</a><br /><a href="http://www.happyscapula.com/blog/2005/9/8/jury-duty-part-2-the-trial.html">Part 2</a><br /><a href="http://www.happyscapula.com/blog/2005/9/11/jury-duty-part-3-the-trial-concludes.html">Part 3</a><br /><br />Of course, I read this from a defense point of view.  But, here of a few of my general thoughts. <br /><br />I haven't yet had a juror stick around to talk to me - whether they convicted or acquitted.  I'd like to hear what they'd have to say.  Although, I did have one trial where we dismissed the alternates before jury deliberations, and they stuck around because they wanted to know what the verdict would be.  I guess that means I kept it interesting.<br /><br />This write-up makes me wonder (again) how my would jurors describe me?  Hopefully not something like "too big lips."  <br /><br />Now onto this case specifically... For example... "Happy" wonders why the prosecutor didn't present more evidence about when the defendant was moved from one police car to another.  For example, he didn't mention how far the distance was, whether she was assisted, etc.  But, I would wonder if he didn't bring it up because it was a bad fact for him.  Maybe she walked a few hundred feet gracefully and without assistance, so it wouldn't be something the prosecutor would mention.   I'm not saying that would have made a difference in the verdict, but I guess that's how I would analyze the evidence that is presented (or isn't).<br /><br />"Happy" also wonders whether the defendant was represented by a public defender, based on the fact that there was a law student second seating the trial.  I'd say that that's probably true.  (Unless it was summer, which makes it slightly more likely that the law student was a summer associate at a law firm.)  But what I really want to know is, would it have made a difference if you knew that?<br /><br />I would think that in a drunk driving case, it wouldn't really matter whether the client is rich or poor.  Rich people are just as capable of committing this crime as poor people (and celebrities get arrested for it all the time).  <br /><br />On the other hand, I do worry about jurors knowing that my client is represented by a public defender in a case like crack possession or shoplifting (although, who can forget Winona Ryder?)  <br /><br />Here's what I think is more interesting... do you think the defendant was in jail while the case was pending?  Probably not, on a drunk driving, but it might give you a clue as to what her warrant was for (presumably something more serious if she was in jail).  Generally, courts try to hide this information, but sometimes it's unavoidable that a juror sees the defendant entering the courthouse, either in handcuffs or not.  And, of course, is it a good factor or a bad factor?  <br /><br />Perhaps a juror, learning that a client was in jail, would think, "She may be guilty of something, but not something <i>that</i> serious, she shouldn't be in jail, I'll lean toward acquittal."  On the other hand, I think a juror might just as easily say, "If they put her in jail during this case, she must have some really bad criminal record or done something more serious that they didn't tell us about... and therefore she's more likely to be guilty of whatever she's accused of now."  <br /><br />So, I guess that's all my thoughts on that.  Except...<br />Next time, ACQUIT!  <br /><br />Just kidding.  =) <br />At least partially.

title: 27 Tips for Vibrant Living
author: BarbaraC. Phillips, NP
post_content: Simply stated, menopause is a biological event that marks the end of a woman’s menses and hence her natural <span style="font-size:85%;">reproductive</span> cycle. Perimenopause is defined as the period beginning with the signs of approaching menopause and ending about 12 months after “the menopause”.<br /><br />Worldwide, menopause has as a variety of meanings. Each and every woman’s experience is based on her physical and emotional well being as well as her social and cultural environments. While some view menopause as a decline in status, others see it as a rite of passage. In other words, there are huge physical, emotional and social influences involved in your experience of menopause and aging.<br /><br />That said, what you really want to know is – “What will I experience”?<br /><br />This is tricky, as the answer is different for every woman. Some women barely notice a warm flush, while others have an intense reaction. So as you read some of the more common occurrences, please keep in mind – you will do your own thing.<br /><ul><li>Power Surges, night sweats (they can be all day!) and chills</li><li>Insomnia, and/or poor quality of sleep</li><li>Urinary frequency, discomfort and sometimes leakiness</li><li>Vaginal dryness, irritation and possibly discomfort with sexual activity</li><li>Moodiness. Perhaps some irritation, nervousness, anxiety and depression.</li><li>Diminished libido (sexual desire)</li><li>Memory issues! Some women call this “the pause” (among other things).</li><li>Joint pain and stiffness</li></ul><p>In case you think all the reactions are negative, take a look at some of the more positive and more important changes that happen to women. </p><ul><li>Freedom</li><li>Joy</li><li>Greater sense of Creativity</li><li>A sense of peace that has not been previously been present.</li><li>Wisdom that only comes to those with time and conscious living.</li></ul><p>Just as there are many responses to the onset of menopause, there are many approaches you can take to meet these changes. As with anything, you must weigh any risk against the benefit (this is especially true when you consider hormone therapy), your belief system, and finally, you must find something that works for you.<br /><br />Most approaches are common sense and actions we need to take daily. Others are meant to challenge your thinking and open your mind. Possible ways to approach menopause include: </p><ul><li>Healthy food and fluid intake</li><li>Nutriceuticals such as vitamins and herbal supplements</li><li>Exercise at least 30 minutes daily</li><li>Traditional Chinese Medicine such has acupuncture, Chinese herbs, Qi Gong and Tai Chi</li><li>Adjust your attitude! Laugh and have fun. Hang out with your girlfriends and delight in NOT being 25 again!</li><li>Meditation, visualization and biofeedback</li><li>Natural, Bio-identical and pharmaceutical grade hormone therapy</li><br /></ul>This is a time of your life where you can count on change, and the growth that comes from it. As the power surges through our bodies, we grow into the women we are meant to be. We fulfill our goals and move on to make new ones. While our focus is inward, our outward gaze sharpens and our dreams are manifested for all to celebrate. It really is a magnificent time.<br /><br />In the coming months, OlderWiserWomen will explore these areas in greater detail, so stay tuned.<br /><br />©2005 Barbara C. Phillips, MN, NP<br /><a href="http://www.OlderWiserWomen.com">OlderWiserWomen™</a>

title: Laughter and Medicine
author: BarbaraC. Phillips, NP
post_content: <ol><li>I had a wonderful dog named Geisha.</li><li>I’m the Daughter of Carol and the grand daughter of Mama Phillips. </li><li>I was born in Seattle, WA.</li><li>I grew up in San Francisco, CA.</li><li>The first college I attended was in San Jose, CA.</li><li>I use to dream of flying without wings. </li><li>I dream of the stars and wonder who is out there.</li><li>At one time I wanted to be a marine biologist.</li><li>The Ocean/Beach runs in my blood and spirit.</li><li>I have a secret dream of being a photographer for National Geographic Magazine. My job is to photograph tide pools all over the world.</li><li>I love to watch women’s track (ie Summer Olympics).</li><li>One of my friends whom I greatly admire is Willow. She has taught me more about me than she knows. </li><li>To my recall, I did not go through the “I hate my mother” phase that many young women go through. I rather enjoy my mother…always have.</li><li>I use to smoke and am very glad that it’s past tense! </li><li>I spent 3 weeks in NZ in March 2000. </li><li>My favorite part of NZ was the east coast of the South Island. </li><li>I had to run from a Sea Lion (they are fast!).</li><li>I love watching birds, and was thrilled to see an Albatross. </li><li>I was the oldest of 5, now we are 3. </li><li>I am Multi-Ethnic and hate having to “check one”.</li><li>I was once a politically active student.</li><li>I finished high school 1 semester early. </li><li>My favorite subject in high school was biology. </li><li>I don’t care for buzzing insects. </li><li>I became a mother at the age of 24. </li><li>I love spinach. </li><li>I love purple. </li><li>I love soft music, such as soft jazz violin, piano and flute.</li><li>One of my favorite pianist is George Winston. </li><li>No, it’s not a perm. </li><li>I used to go to every Dionne Warwick concert regardless of the location. </li><li>I’ve had my hand inside someone chest, around their heart. </li><li>I underwent Lasik! Thank you! </li><li>INFP </li><li>I’m a Gemini. </li><li>I don’t understand narrow minded people. </li><li>I don’t understand people who seem to have a sense of being better than others. </li><li>I was NEVER a hippy. </li><li>I was a Motown snob growing up. </li><li>I’m left handed. </li><li>I have realized my childhood dream of having a library…and it continues to grow. </li><li>The best job I ever had was to work with those dying of AIDS. </li><li>Death teaches you about living. Blessings to all my teachers. </li><li>My life gets better with age. </li><li>Childbirth? Once was enough. </li><li>I love my bed. </li><li>As a child, my Dad brought home a friend of his named - nice man, but I still don't like baseball. </li><li>I adore good coffee. </li><li>I have seen wild cougars twice. </li><li>I love the <a href="”" target="”_blank”">Olympic Peninsula </a>. </li><li>The first time I saw a Bald Eagle was in British Columbia, and I cried. </li><li>I like to wear black. </li><li>I look good in red. </li><li>I want to climb a pyramid. </li><li>I want to see a <a href="”" target="”_blank”">Blue Footed Boobie</a>. </li><li>I love to travel. </li><li>I love gadgets.</li><li>My son is taller than me. </li><li>I learned to drive at age 13 in Golden Gate Park. </li><li>My father taught me. </li><li>I stayed on the Island of Bermuda for several months. </li><li>I love to be behind the camera lens. </li><li>I dislike being in front of it. </li><li>I once saw an <a href="”" target="”_blank”">American Bittern</a>. </li><li>I love gardening. </li><li>I cycled the Tulip Pedal in wind and rain. </li><li>I’ve been cultivating grey hair for many years.</li><li>I once drove a motor cycle into the side of a house. </li><li>I lived to tell about it. </li><li>My favorite months are August and September. </li><li>There are many women with my name. </li><li>Fall is my favorite season. </li><li>I like good sci-fi.</li><li>I finally have the most fantastic partner. </li><li>I get better with age! </li><li>I want to orbit the Earth. </li><li>I don’t eat red meat. </li><li>My spirit needs the beach, the stars, the wind, the birds, the trees, space and my mountains. </li><li>I honor the spirit in you. </li><li>I’m thankful when people pick up their own trash. </li><li>Sunrises and sunsets make my heart sing. </li><li>I see that I will have to revise this list as I learn more about me. </li><li>In 4th grade, I was the jacks champion. </li><li>When my son was a toddler, he asked me not to sing anymore. </li><li>I love a good challenge…at least for a while. </li><li>I actually do make a difference in some people’s lives in the work I do. </li><li>I enjoy good fresh food. </li><li>Life is meant to be lived, explored. </li><li>I am suppose to grow, even though it hurts sometimes.</li><li>I make paper. </li><li>My right brain is aching to get away from my left brain. </li><li>I’m entering the best time of my life. </li><li>My fathered died when I was 16….I still miss him.</li><li>We really do need to save our planet. </li><li>I dislike meetings.</li><li>I’m a very spiritual person.</li><li>I love the early mornings. </li><li>I want to cycle long distance.</li><li>I would like to be alive in 200 years just to see what advances we have made.</li><li><a href="”" target="”_blank”">Meteor showers</a> are awesome!</li></ol>

title: Feeling Edgy
author: Eunice
post_content: <p>At this point I am wondering how many people are truly content with where their lives seem to be heading. I am feeling edgy and wondering what life will be like, really, in the MFA. Singaporeans have pigeonholing deeply ingrained as a habit in their minds; it begins with streaming which our dear LKY so very recently confirmed was here to stay. </p><p>S is right; there is a hierarchy where scholars are ranked higher than non-scholars. Scholars are also ranked, however. The OMS males then OMS females then SGS males then SGS females then Local scholar males then Local scholar females then everybody else. In the MFA at least. There's a large bit of me that yells at my brain that it's no fair, stop pigeonholing, just because i fell down the wrong side of the pinball machine earlier doesn't mean that i ain't just as good as the other pinballs! But the small bit of me that's control freaky and pro-establishment says 'but that's the most efficient way...'. I'm just wondering if the pinball is really different from the other pinballs that went to pinball heaven but is blind to its own imperfections. I don't want to be blind. And I don't want to be pigeonholed. They might well both be facts of life, the latter especially on our Little Sunny Island set in the Sea, Inc.</p><p>Once my hair dries I will go to sleep. Why is there a loud drunk man yelling at the street outside my place yet again? </p>

title: The Undisputed World Chess Champion
author: Dennis Monokroussos
post_content: Online chess is wonderful in all sorts of ways, but gather enough people anywhere and even the best things will be misused. Scourge in point: the computer cheater. All too often, people will fire up their chess software in the background, or on a second machine, or even directly to the server interface and attempt to steal victories, rating points and occasionally even money from their victims. Often they're caught - sometimes sooner, sometimes later - but they're always a nuisance.<br /><br />They don't always succeed, however - sometimes the good guys absorb the computer's blows and survive or even win. What follows is one of my more satisfying online victories, over a player I realized early on was a computer cheat.<br /><br />Bad Guy-DM, 15-minute game, ICC 2000<br /><br />1.Nf3 Nf6 2.d4 d5 3.Bf4 g6 4.e3 Bg7 5.Be2 Nbd7 6.O-O O-O 7.Nbd2 b6 8.c3 Bb7 9.Qa4 c5 10.Rfe1 a6 11.Qd1<br /><br />At this point, I suddenly feel suspicious. My opponent is a good player, his rating is fairly high, so what's with 9.Qa4 one move and 11.Qd1 two moves later? The retreat might be sensible, but it's not the sort of move a human would just play, and quickly, if only because of the embarrassment factor.<br /><br />11...Ne4 12.Rb1 Rc8 13.Qc2<br /><br />Okay, now I'm getting <span style="font-style: italic;">really</span> suspicious! Why not 9.Qc2 or 11.Qc2? And who makes such a move in response to my putting a rook on the c-file? That's the sort of thing strong players typically (though defeasibly) avoid!<br /><br />13...Re8 14.Rbc1 Nxd2 15.Qxd2 Nf6 16.Qd1<br /><br />Sigh. I always make a point of not bothering playing computers, but it's clear that's what I'm up against. As it's against the rules to use a chess engine (unless one's account is explicitly marked as a computer account), I started to request that the game be aborted. My opponent refused, and we continued:<br /><br />16...Ne4 17.Bd3 b5 18.a4 Qb6 19.axb5 axb5 20.Ne5 Red8<br /><br />Annoyed though I was, I felt pretty good about my position, but I was in for a surprise, as my opponent produced an extremely strong idea:<br /><br />21.Ra1! b4 22.Qb1!<br /><br />This is a fantastic prophylactic idea, as playing 22...bxc3 23.bxc3 favors White. I attempt a tactical solution to my problems, but my opponent is more than up to the challenge:<br /><br />22...Nd2 23.Qc2 bxc3 24.bxc3 Nb3 25.Ra4! c4 26.Rb4! Qa7<br /><br />Very nice play by White, who was moving extremely quickly, too, and taking pretty much the same amount of time on every move (another tell-tale sign of the computer cheat). What follows now is even more impressive, both as a chess idea and as evidence of the cheating claim:<br /><br />27.Bf1 e6 28.Bxc4!<br /><br />A very strange sequence - why not 27.Bxc4 straight away? That sort of freedom from embarrassment about past moves is typical of computers, but not at all of humans.<br /><br />28...dxc4 29.Nxc4 Bd5 30.Nb6 Nxd4 31.exd4 Rc6 32.Qb2 Bf8 33.Nxd5 exd5 34.Rb7 Qa3 35.Qxa3 Bxa3 36.Rb3 Bf8 37.h3 Re6<br /><br /><img src="http://chessmind.powerblogs.com/files/NN_DM_1.jpg" /><br /><br />White's play so far has been quite strong, and although overall I've played pretty well for a 15-minute game, my inaccuracies here and there have left it with an extra pawn. It's not the greatest extra pawn in the world, but it's certainly up to me to prove that I can hold the position.<br /><br />From here on out, however, White's play is bad in a way that would have been impossible for a human player exhibiting White's strength so far. The problem for White is that his queenside pawns are on dark squares while Black's are on light squares, thereby making White's bishop essentially impotent. Thus what's clear is that if the rooks are removed, it's a trivially easy task for Black to hold. Accordingly, White should avoid the exchange of at least one pair of rooks, when Black will have to suffer and grovel. But behold!<br /><br />38.Rxe6?! fxe6 39.Rb6 Kf7 40.Rb7+ Kg8 41.Kf1 Rc8 42.Rc7?? Rxc7 43.Bxc7<br /><br /><img src="http://chessmind.powerblogs.com/files/NN_DM_2.jpg" /><br /><br />Wow, that was easy! The position is perfect for me now - all my pawns are ideally placed, and White pawn advances simply lead to exchanges. I was way behind on the clock (I had two minutes left to White's seven and a half), but as I only need to play Kf7, Be7-f8-e7-f8-e7-f8 and trade the pawns as they come, I figured I'd have good chances to save the draw in spite of the clock.<br /><br />43...Kf7 44.Be5 Be7 45.Ke2 Bf8 46.Kd2 Be7 47.c4 dxc4 48.Kc3 Bf8 49.Kxc4 Be7<br /><br /><img src="http://chessmind.powerblogs.com/files/NN_DM_3.jpg" /><br /><br />and now check out White's next three moves, which taken together are completely insane.<br /><br />50.g3?! Bf8 51.h4?? Be7 52.f4? h5!<br /><br />Now it's really, really, really a dead draw, as White can never create so much as a single target in my position. But White finds resources in the position...for Black.<br /><br />53.Kd3 Bf8 54.Ke4 Be7 55.d5 exd5+ 56.Kxd5 Bf8 57.Kc6? Ke6 58.Kb5 Kf5 59.Kc6?? Bb4<br /><br /><img src="http://chessmind.powerblogs.com/files/NN_DM_4.jpg" /><br /><br />and now, of course, it's over, as my bishop hoovers the White pawns.<br /><br />60.Kd7 Be1 61.Ke8 Bxg3 62.Kf8 Bxh4 63.Kg7 Bg3 64.Kh6 Bxf4+ 65.Bxf4 Kxf4 66.Kxg6 h4 0-1<br /><br />After the game I reported my opponent to the server's computer-cheat police, and some time later my judgement was confirmed. It's disappointing when people do that, but to be honest, it did make the win much, much sweeter than it would otherwise have been! (Not because it was a computer that was defeated, which is certainly pleasant enough, but because a cheater got his just desserts.)

title: What Computers Can't Do, Part 2
author: Dennis Monokroussos
post_content: The following position is quite simple to assess and solve, but it's a neat idea I thought up on my own. I've since discovered a couple of antecedents in ChessBase's Study Database, but as neither my skeleton nor its antecedents are particularly artistic or well-developed, there's plenty of room for the enterprising composer to create something worthwhile and original.<br /><br />The <span style="font-style: italic;">really important thing</span>, however, is that the diagram problem has been solved! (Many thanks to <a href="http://www.blogger.com/profile/4317086">DG</a> of the <a href="http://world.std.com/%7Eboylston/">Boylston Chess Club</a> and their fine <a href="http://boylston-chess-club.blogspot.com/">blog</a>- see his comment <a href="http://chessstuff.blogspot.com/2005/02/is-chess-sport.html#comments">here</a> for the how-to details.)<br /><br />White to move and draw (but Black is the one needing to save the half-point)<br /><br /><img src="http://chessmind.powerblogs.com/files/Study_1.jpg" /><br /><br />White can draw this lots of ways, but the variation illustrating the neat point goes like this:<br /><br />1.Rf1+ Re1 2.Rxe1+ Kxe1 3.a6 h3 4.a7<br /><br /><br /><img src="http://chessmind.powerblogs.com/files/Study_2.jpg" /><br /><br /><br />and now Black must play accurately: 4...h2! (4...hxg2? 5.a8Q g1Q 6.Qe4+ Kd1 [6...Kf2 7.Qe2#] 7.Qe2+ Kc1 8.Qc2#) 5.a8Q h1Q 6.Qa1+ (White has no other way to progress) Kf2 7.Qxh1 stalemate!

title: Can Christians Play Chess?
author: Dennis Monokroussos
post_content: <strong>Welcome to my blog!</strong><br /><br />Inspired by sources like Tim Krabbe's "<a href="http://www.xs4all.nl/%7Etimkr/chess/chess.html">Chess Curiosities</a>" and the daily paper "<a href="http://www.chesstoday.net/">Chess Today</a>," as well as by the desire to share the occasional chess goings on in my own life and those of my friends and students, I'm beginning this open-ended, occasional foray into my own web presence. Welcome aboard - enjoy!
